explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Sickle cell disease (SCD) is caused by a β-globin gene mutation leading to HbS polymerization, red-cell sickling, endothelial injury, and large-vessel vasculopathy. Children with SCD develop intracranial stenosis—especially of the middle cerebral and internal carotid arteries—predisposing them to ischemic strokes. Primary prevention uses transcranial Doppler (TCD) screening and transfusions for those with elevated velocities; secondary prevention (after an initial stroke) requires more aggressive measures. Chronic transfusion lowers HbS <30%, reduces blood viscosity, and mitigates endothelial adhesion. Understanding the difference between primary (prevent first event) versus secondary (prevent recurrence) stroke strategies in SCD is key.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Chronic transfusion remains the gold standard for secondary stroke prevention in SCD. The STOP trial established transfusions for primary prevention, and subsequent data confirmed indefinite transfusion reduces recurrence by >90%. The SWiTCH trial (Stroke With Transfusions Changing to Hydroxyurea; 2016) showed that switching to hydroxyurea plus phlebotomy led to higher recurrence and iron overload complications. The 2019 AHA/ASA Pediatric Stroke Guidelines (Class I, Level A) and the 2020 American Society of Hematology (ASH) Guidelines (Grade 1A) both recommend continued transfusion therapy post-stroke, targeting HbS <30% and hemoglobin ~10 g/dL, with iron chelation to prevent overload. Antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapies lack efficacy in this vasculopathic, non-embolic context.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Reason incorrect: Antiplatelet alone does not address the underlying sickling-driven vasculopathy or reduce HbS.
• Misconception: Assuming pediatric arterial strokes mirror adult atherosclerotic mechanisms.
• Differentiator: Aspirin reduces platelet aggregation but fails to prevent sickle-cell occlusive events.

C. Anticoagulation
• Reason incorrect: SCD strokes are due to non-embolic large-vessel stenosis, not cardioembolism or hypercoagulability amenable to heparin/warfarin.
• Misconception: All pediatric strokes benefit from anticoagulation.
• Differentiator: No evidence for anticoagulants in primary or secondary prevention of SCD-related infarcts.

D. Hydroxyurea
• Reason incorrect: Effective for primary prevention (TWiTCH trial) but inferior for secondary prevention (SWiTCH showed higher recurrence when replacing transfusion).
• Misconception: Belief that hydroxyurea’s fetal-hemoglobin induction suffices post-stroke.
• Differentiator: Hydroxyurea does not reduce HbS fraction as rapidly or predictably as transfusion.

Comparison Table

FeatureChronic TransfusionAspirinAnticoagulationHydroxyurea
MechanismLowers HbS, reduces viscosityInhibits platelet COX-1Inhibits thrombin/coagulation cascadeIncreases HbF, reduces sickling
Evidence for secondary strokeSTOP/SWITCH: ↓recurrence >90%No proven benefit in SCDNo role in non-embolic strokeSWiTCH: ↑recurrence
Guideline recommendationAHA/ASA Class I, ASH 1ANot recommendedNot recommendedOnly primary prevention
Main adverse effectsIron overload, alloimmunizationBleeding riskBleeding riskMyelosuppression

Clinical Pearls

- Maintain HbS <30% and total hemoglobin ~10 g/dL during transfusion therapy; initiate chelation (deferoxamine or deferasirox) early.
• Annual TCD screening remains vital even after transfusion; velocities >200 cm/s warrant review of adherence.
• Transfusion breaks must be avoided: missed sessions rapidly increase stroke risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating adult platelet-mediated stroke prevention (aspirin) with pediatric SCD vasculopathy.
• Believing hydroxyurea can fully replace transfusion after a documented stroke.
• Overlooking iron chelation in chronic transfusion protocols, leading to secondary hemochromatosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, Pediatric Stroke Guidelines (2019): Recommends indefinite regular transfusions for secondary prevention in SCD (Class I, Level A).
• American Society of Hematology, Sickle Cell Disease Management Guidelines (2020): Endorses chronic transfusion targeting HbS <30% post-stroke (Grade 1A).
• SWiTCH Trial (Stroke With Transfusions Changing to Hydroxyurea; 2016): Demonstrated higher stroke recurrence when substituting hydroxyurea for chronic transfusions in secondary prevention.
• TWiTCH Trial (2016): Established hydroxyurea’s non-inferiority to transfusion for primary prevention but not tested post-stroke.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

SCD-related strokes arise from chronic endothelial activation, intimal hyperplasia, and smooth muscle proliferation in intracranial arteries (particularly MCA/ICA). Sickled erythrocytes adhere to endothelium, occlude microvasculature, and trigger collateral shear stress. Repeated vaso-occlusive events foster vessel stenosis and luminal thrombosis. Chronic transfusion dilutes HbS, improves rheology, and interrupts this cycle, thereby stabilizing vessel walls and preventing new infarcts.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam.
Secondary stroke prevention in SCD is a high-yield topic on pediatric neurology; exam vignettes often describe recurrent strokes or rising TCD velocities to test knowledge of chronic transfusion protocols.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] - The cerebral venous system comprises superficial/deep veins draining into dural sinuses (e.g., superior sagittal, transverse) that empty into the internal jugular veins.
• CVT occurs when a thrombus obstructs these venous channels, causing increased intracranial pressure, venous congestion, and potential hemorrhagic infarction.
• Virchow’s triad (hypercoagulability, stasis, endothelial injury) underlies CVT pathogenesis; systemic inflammatory conditions like Ulcerative Colitis (UC) drive hypercoagulability.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ulcerative Colitis is a well‐established acquired prothrombotic state. Chronic gut inflammation elevates fibrinogen and factor VIII levels, activates platelets, and downregulates protein C/S. A 2020 meta-analysis (Kumar et al., J Neurol Sci) demonstrated a 3.5‐fold increased risk of CVT in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients. The 2018 AHA/ASA CVT guidelines classify IBD as an acquired thrombophilia warranting targeted screening (Class I, Level B). Prothrombotic conditions—particularly IBD in young women—account for up to 70% of CVT cases, making UC the correct risk factor among the options.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Hypertension (HTN)
• HTN damages arterioles leading to arterial ischemic stroke or intracerebral hemorrhage, not venous thrombosis.
• Misconception: assuming all cerebrovascular risk factors apply to venous events.
• Differentiator: CVT arises from coagulopathy/inflammation, not pressure‐induced vascular injury.

B. Diabetes Mellitus (DM)
• DM drives atherosclerosis and microangiopathy, predisposing to arterial infarcts.
• Misconception: conflating metabolic arterial risk with venous clotting.
• Differentiator: no direct effect on venous clotting factors or endothelial procoagulant activity.

D. Migraine
• Migraine causes headache via neuronal hyperexcitability and vascular dysregulation, without promoting thrombosis.
• Misconception: equating headache disorders with risk for thrombotic events.
• Differentiator: migraine lacks systemic hypercoagulability or venous flow obstruction.

Comparison Table

FeatureUlcerative Colitis (UC)Hypertension (HTN)Diabetes Mellitus (DM)Migraine
MechanismSystemic inflammation → ↑ coagulationArteriolar hyaline changeAtherosclerosis, endothelial dysfunctionNeuronal hyperexcitability & vasodilation
Association with CVTHigh (≈3.5× risk)None/rareNoneNone
Typical stroke subtypeVenous thrombosisArterial ischemia/hemorrhageArterial ischemia/microvascularNo structural stroke
Coagulation profile↑ Fibrinogen, ↑ factor VIII, ↓ protein C/SNo significant prothrombotic changeNo direct prothrombotic effectNormal coagulation

Clinical Pearls

- Young women with CVT should be screened for IBD, OCP use, pregnancy/postpartum state, and inherited thrombophilias.
• MR venography is the gold standard for CVT diagnosis; look for absence of flow in the affected sinus.
• Anticoagulation with low–molecular–weight heparin is indicated even if small hemorrhages are present, unless there is a contraindication.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overlooking gastrointestinal history in CVT workup and missing IBD as a key risk factor.
• Attributing headache solely to migraine or tension headache without considering CVT in the differential.
• Failing to apply Virchow’s triad when evaluating venous stroke presentations.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines on Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (2018): Recommends evaluation for acquired prothrombotic conditions—including IBD—in all CVT patients (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization Guidelines (2021): Support direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) as alternatives to vitamin K antagonists for CVT and highlight long‐term thromboprophylaxis considerations in IBD patients (Level IIb).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus impedes drainage from cortical veins, leading to diffuse intracranial hypertension and potential bilateral hemorrhagic infarcts. Transverse sinus involvement may present with focal hemispheric signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

In Ulcerative Colitis, cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6) induce endothelial activation and tissue factor expression, shifting hemostasis toward thrombosis. Platelet hyperreactivity and impaired fibrinolysis further enhance clot formation in cerebral veins.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Risk factors for CVT—especially IBD—are commonly tested in vignette formats to assess recognition of prothrombotic conditions and guide appropriate hypercoagulability workup.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Intravenous tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA) remains the cornerstone of acute ischemic stroke therapy within 4.5 hours of onset. tPA promotes fibrinolysis by converting plasminogen to plasmin and thereby lysing intravascular thrombi. However, reperfusion into ischemic tissue—where the blood–brain barrier (BBB) is already disrupted—increases the risk of hemorrhagic transformation. The integrity of microvessels may remain impaired for weeks to months following an initial stroke, especially in peri-infarct regions with fragile neovascularization. Stroke management protocols categorize contraindications as absolute (therapy always withheld) or relative (therapy may be considered if benefits outweigh risks). Recognizing the graded risk associated with each exclusion criterion is essential for making informed, guideline-based decisions about thrombolysis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Answer A correctly identifies “ischemic stroke within the prior 3 months” as a relative contraindication per the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class III: No Benefit or Harm; Level C-EO). The landmark NINDS trial (1995) and subsequent registries (e.g., SITS-MOST) outlined exclusion criteria that balanced thrombolytic efficacy against hemorrhagic risk. In subgroup analyses from IST-3 (Lancet, 2012), patients with a prior stroke <3 months had a symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH) rate of ~9% versus ~6% overall (OR ~1.5), underscoring elevated bleeding risk. Mechanistically, upregulation of matrix metalloproteinases (particularly MMP-9) and persistent BBB disruption post-infarct predispose to reperfusion hemorrhage. Clinicians must therefore weigh the modest benefit of reperfusion against the quantified risk of sICH when a recent stroke is in the history.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. It is an absolute contraindication
• Why incorrect: Guidelines classify recent ischemic stroke (<3 months) as relative rather than absolute; absolute exclusions (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage on CT) prohibit tPA under any circumstance.
• Misconception: Equating all exclusion criteria with absolute contraindications.
• Differentiator: Absolute exclusions have zero tolerance for variation.

C. It is safe to administer
• Why incorrect: Administering tPA within 3 months of a prior stroke markedly increases hemorrhagic transformation risk.
• Misconception: Belief that only time from symptom onset matters, not prior events.
• Differentiator: Safety profile is compromised by recent tissue vulnerability.

D. It is only contraindicated in patients over 80 years old
• Why incorrect: Age >80 is not a contraindication; in fact, tPA is approved for all adults up to 4.5 hours—with careful blood pressure control.
• Misconception: Confusing age-related exclusion in extended window trials (e.g., WAKE-UP) with standard eligibility.
• Differentiator: Age and recent stroke are distinct considerations in thrombolysis guidelines.

Comparison Table

OptionGuideline ClassificationHemorrhagic RiskKey Point
ARelative contraindicationModerately elevatedHistory of stroke <3 months increases sICH risk; clinician judgement required.
BMisclassification (not used)N/ARecent stroke is not absolute exclusion.
CNot recommendedHighIgnores enhanced BBB disruption.
DIrrelevant age-based exclusionVariableAge >80 is not an exclusion for standard window.

Clinical Pearls

- Always review the timeline of prior neurologic events; even “silent” infarcts on imaging can influence hemorrhagic risk.
• Relative contraindications demand individualized risk–benefit assessment; obtain advanced imaging (CT perfusion or MRI diffusion) if uncertainty exists.
• Blood–brain barrier integrity may remain compromised for weeks; infarct volume and location further modulate risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Students often conflate “exclusion criteria” with absolute contraindications, leading to inappropriate refusal of tPA.
• Misremembering age cutoffs: age >80 is not an exclusion for the standard 0–4.5 hr window—only for certain extended-window protocols.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines (Stroke, 2019)
• Recommendation: History of ischemic stroke within 3 months is a relative exclusion to IV alteplase (Class III: No Benefit or Harm; LOE C-EO).
2. European Stroke Organisation Guidelines 2021
• Recommendation: Advise caution and individualized decision-making for patients with prior stroke <3 months; advanced imaging to exclude hemorrhage or large infarct (Level B).
3. IST-3 Trial (Lancet, 2012)
• Secondary analysis: Prior stroke <3 months associated with increased sICH (9% vs. 6.5%; OR ~1.5), supporting cautious use.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.
Exclusion criteria for IV thrombolysis—especially timing of prior stroke—are frequently tested as single best–answer items, often in clinical vignettes emphasizing hemorrhagic transformation risk.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Autoregulation of cerebral blood flow maintains perfusion over a range of mean arterial pressures but shifts upward in chronic hypertension.
• In acute ischemic stroke, elevated BP helps maintain perfusion in the ischemic penumbra (“permissive hypertension”).
• AHA/ASA guidelines recommend treating BP only if systolic >220 mm Hg or diastolic >120 mm Hg in patients not receiving reperfusion therapy.

(Word count: 84)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct response is “No intervention needed.” Per 2018 AHA/ASA Acute Ischemic Stroke Management Guidelines, in patients not eligible for thrombolysis or endovascular therapy, antihypertensive treatment is indicated only if SBP exceeds 220 mm Hg or DBP exceeds 120 mm Hg (Class I; Level of Evidence B-R). Our patient’s BP of 170/95 mm Hg supports permissive hypertension to preserve collateral perfusion of the ischemic penumbra. Lowering BP below this threshold risks expansion of infarct size. Large observational studies correlate more aggressive BP lowering in early stroke with larger final infarct volumes. Randomized trials have not demonstrated benefit from early BP reduction in ischemic stroke absent other indications.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV Hydralazine
• Hydralazine causes reflex tachycardia and unpredictable cerebral vasodilation, potentially increasing intracranial pressure.
• Misconception: Any vasodilator is equally acceptable.
• Differentiator: Hydralazine is not recommended in acute ischemic stroke due to hemodynamic instability.

B. IV Labetalol
• While labetalol is the preferred agent when BP lowering is indicated (e.g., SBP >220 mm Hg), our patient’s BP is below the treatment threshold.
• Misconception: Treat all elevated BPs in stroke.
• Differentiator: Threshold-based therapy dictates when labetalol is used.

D. Oral Amlodipine
• Oral agents have slow onset and lack titratability; not recommended for acute BP control in stroke.
• Misconception: Any antihypertensive method will suffice.
• Differentiator: Acute management requires IV agents only when necessary.

Comparison Table

FeatureNo InterventionIV LabetalolIV HydralazineOral Amlodipine
Indication in AIS (no tPA)SBP ≤220 mm HgSBP >220 mm HgRarely usedNot recommended
MechanismPermissive hypertensionα- and β-blockadeDirect arteriolar vasodilationL-type Ca²⁺ channel blockade
Onset of actionN/A2–5 minutes10–20 minutes6–12 hours
Evidence/Class of RecommendationClass I; maintain BP ≤220/120Class I; treat if >220/120Not recommendedNot indicated

Clinical Pearls

- Permissive hypertension up to 220/120 mm Hg is protective in acute ischemic stroke by supporting penumbral perfusion.
• When treating high BP in stroke, IV labetalol or nicardipine are first-line due to rapid onset and titratability.
• Overaggressive BP lowering can worsen neurological outcomes by reducing collateral blood flow.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating any elevated BP in acute ischemic stroke, ignoring permissive hypertension guidelines.
2. Using oral antihypertensives or hydralazine with unpredictable cerebral hemodynamics instead of recommended IV agents when treatment is indicated.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends treating BP only if SBP >220 mm Hg or DBP >120 mm Hg in non-thrombolysis candidates (Class I; Level B-R).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines: Echoes permissive hypertension strategy; recommends IV labetalol or nicardipine if BP exceeds 220/120 mm Hg (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Blood pressure management in acute ischemic stroke is frequently tested in vignette format, emphasizing permissive hypertension thresholds and choice of IV agents when lowering is required.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] • Spinal dural arteriovenous fistulas (SDAVF) are the most common spinal vascular malformation, typically in males aged 40–60.
• Pathophysiology: an abnormal connection between a radiculomeningeal artery and a dural vein causes venous hypertension, cord edema and progressive myelopathy.
• MRI hallmarks: longitudinal T2-hyperintense signal spanning multiple segments (often conus), T1 hypointense “rim” from slow flow/hemosiderin, and dilated perimedullary flow voids.
• Clinical clue: symptoms worsen with maneuvers that increase venous pressure (standing, Valsalva).
(Word count: 103)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dural venous fistula produces chronic venous congestion leading to progressive, insidious myelopathy. MRI demonstrates a longitudinally extensive T2 lesion in the conus with a hypointense rim on T1 due to slow flow and hemosiderin deposition; perimedullary flow voids are often present (Rodesch et al., 1994). Symptom exacerbation on standing or straining reflects increased intrathecal venous pressure (Aminoff & Logue, 1974). Definitive diagnosis requires spinal digital subtraction angiography (DSA). Current consensus guidelines (Spetzler et al., J Neurosurg Spine 2018) recommend prompt microsurgical disconnection or endovascular therapy to prevent irreversible cord injury. No inflammatory markers or antibodies are present, distinguishing it from NMO, and the subacute progression is too slow for infarction. Acute hemorrhage or nidus seen in true AVM is absent.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. NMO
– Incorrect: Neuromyelitis optica causes longitudinal transverse myelitis but with acute relapsing course, serum AQP4-IgG positivity, and often optic neuritis. No flow voids or T1 rim.
B. Spinal Infarction
– Incorrect: Infarction is abrupt, painful onset with maximal deficit at onset; MRI shows restricted diffusion and “owl’s eye” T2 hyperintensity in anterior horns, not chronic hypointense rim or flow voids.
C. AVM of the spine
– Incorrect: Spinal cord AVMs have a compact nidus with acute hemorrhage risk, present with subarachnoid hemorrhage or high-flow signs, not insidious worsening with posture and without nidus or cord expansion patterns typical of SDAVF.

MRI T2 signalLongitudinal conus edemaLongitudinal, centralFocal “owl’s eye”Focal nidus, variable edema

Perimedullary flow voidsYesNoNoYes (nidus)

Diagnostic gold standardSpinal DSAAQP4-IgG + MRIClinical + diffusion MRISpinal DSA

Clinical Pearls

• Always inspect T1 and T2 sequences for a hypointense rim and dilated dorsal flow voids when evaluating progressive myelopathy.
• Symptoms that worsen with standing or Valsalva suggest venous hypertension—key for SDAVF.
• Misdiagnosis as inflammatory myelitis and steroid treatment can exacerbate cord edema in SDAVF.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing a longitudinally extensive lesion solely to demyelination and starting immunotherapy without vascular imaging.
2. Failing to identify subtle flow voids on MRI, leading to delayed DSA and irreversible spinal cord injury.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Spetzler RF et al., J Neurosurg Spine 2018: International consensus on classification and management of spinal vascular malformations recommends early DSA and microsurgical disconnection or endovascular occlusion (Level II).
2. Hurst RW et al., Neurology 2020: Systematic review found microsurgical treatment achieves >95% obliteration vs. 75–80% for endovascular approaches; early intervention correlates with better functional outcomes (evidence level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Spinal dural arteriovenous fistulas are frequently tested as a cause of subacute myelopathy with longitudinal MRI lesions, and distinguishing features (flow voids, T1 rim, posture-dependent symptoms) are high-yield for boards.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor used in atrial fibrillation to prevent cardioembolic stroke. Intracerebral hemorrhage in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory after reperfusion therapy constitutes a life-threatening bleed requiring immediate reversal of anticoagulation. Knowledge of specific versus non-specific reversal agents and their mechanisms is critical in acute neuro-emergencies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment that binds dabigatran with ~350-fold higher affinity than thrombin, neutralizing its anticoagulant effect within minutes. The RE-VERSE AD trial (Pollack et al., NEJM 2017) demonstrated rapid normalization of coagulation parameters and cessation of bleeding in nearly all patients. The 2016 ISTH guidance (level 1C) and the 2018 AHA/ASA acute stroke guidelines (class I, level B-NR) recommend idarucizumab for life-threatening hemorrhage on dabigatran. No other reversal agents have comparable specificity or efficacy for direct thrombin inhibitors.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Vitamin K
• Targets gamma-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, X; ineffective for direct thrombin inhibitors.
• Misconception: All anticoagulants respond to vitamin K.

C. Fresh frozen plasma
• Supplies coagulation factors but does not remove or neutralize dabigatran.
• Misconception: Volume replacement reverses all anticoagulants.

D. Protamine sulfate
• Binds and inactivates heparin and low-molecular-weight heparins; no affinity for dabigatran.
• Misconception: Protamine is a universal anticoagulant antidote.

Comparison Table

FeatureIdarucizumabVitamin KFresh Frozen PlasmaProtamine Sulfate
MechanismMonoclonal Fab binds dabigatranCofactor for γ-carboxylationReplacement of clotting factorsBinds heparin
Target AnticoagulantDabigatranWarfarin/VKAsVarious factor deficienciesHeparin/LMWH
Onset of ActionMinutes6–24 hours30–60 minutesMinutes
Indication for ReversalLife-threatening bleed on dabigatranVKA-related bleedingMassive bleed with factor deficitsHeparin overdose

Clinical Pearls

- Idarucizumab dosing is 5 g IV (two consecutive 2.5 g infusions) with no dose adjustment for renal function.
• Always obtain coagulation assays (e.g., dilute thrombin time) to confirm dabigatran activity when available.
• In DOAC-related hemorrhage, rapid reversal reduces hematoma expansion and improves outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Selecting vitamin K or FFP for DOAC reversal delays appropriate therapy—only idarucizumab neutralizes dabigatran directly.
2. Assuming protamine sulfate reverses all anticoagulants; it is specific to heparin and its derivatives.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Pollack CV Jr. et al., RE-VERSE AD trial (NEJM 2017): Demonstrated complete reversal of dabigatran anticoagulation in 100% of bleeds; onset <5 minutes (level A evidence).
2. ISTH Guidance on DOAC Reversal (2016): Recommends idarucizumab for dabigatran-associated life-threatening bleeds (grade 1C).
3. AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018 update): Class I recommendation for idarucizumab prior to surgery or in hemorrhage (level B-NR).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

MCA territory hemorrhage often involves the lateral frontal and parietal lobes and can lead to contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and aphasia when dominant hemisphere is affected.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Dabigatran directly inhibits thrombin (factor IIa), preventing fibrin formation. Accumulation in overdose or procedural contexts (thrombectomy) can precipitate hemorrhage by blocking clot stabilization.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Non-contrast CT shows hyperdense regions in MCA distribution. Serial imaging guides management of hematoma expansion.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Idarucizumab: 5 g IV over 5–10 minutes; monitor coagulation (dilute thrombin time, ecarin clotting time) post-administration.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam.
Reversal of DOACs, particularly specific antidotes like idarucizumab for dabigatran, is a high-yield topic on neurology and internal medicine boards, often tested in acute hemorrhagic stroke scenarios.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Cranial nerve III (oculomotor) carries motor fibers to four extraocular muscles and parasympathetic fibers to the pupil. The parasympathetic fibers run peripherally in the nerve, making pupillary function exquisitely sensitive to compressive lesions. A saccular aneurysm at the junction of the internal carotid artery and posterior communicating artery (Pcom) can enlarge and directly compress CN III, leading to an acute, pupil-involving third nerve palsy. Distal ischemic causes (e.g., microvascular infarction) typically spare the pupil. Recognition of this pattern on clinical exam and confirmation with vascular imaging (CTA/MRA/DSA) is critical for prompt neurosurgical or endovascular intervention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior communicating artery aneurysms account for approximately 20–25% of all intracranial aneurysms. When they compress the oculomotor nerve, patients present with ipsilateral ptosis, “down and out” eye position, and dilated pupil due to parasympathetic fiber involvement. A meta-analysis by McLaughlin et al. (Stroke, 2014) found that 85% of patients with Pcom aneurysm–induced CN III palsy experienced partial or complete recovery after timely clipping or coiling. The 2022 AHA/ASA Guideline for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Class I, Level B) recommends early repair of symptomatic aneurysms to prevent rupture and reverse compressive neuropathies. High‐resolution CTA or digital subtraction angiography confirms the diagnosis by visualizing the saccular outpouching at the ICA–Pcom junction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRESS)
• PRES presents with headache, seizures, and visual disturbances due to vasogenic edema in parieto-occipital lobes on MRI.
• Misconception: PRES can cause “visual” symptoms, but it does not produce an isolated cranial nerve III palsy.
• Differentiator: MRI shows bilateral edema, not a focal vascular lesion compressing CN III.

C. Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS)
• RCVS features thunderclap headache and segmental arterial narrowing on angiography, often without focal neuropathies.
• Misconception: Sudden headache syndromes always implicate vascular etiologies compressing nerves.
• Differentiator: Angiography shows “string-of-beads” vasoconstriction; no cranial nerve compression.

D. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection
• HSV encephalitis produces fever, altered mental status, and temporal lobe lesions on MRI, not isolated oculomotor palsy.
• Misconception: Viral infections can lead to any focal deficit.
• Differentiator: CSF pleocytosis and temporal lobe enhancement, without aneurysmal dilation.

Clinical Pearls

• Pupillary involvement in third nerve palsy is a red flag for compressive lesions; microvascular palsies spare the pupil.
• The oculomotor nerve runs between the posterior cerebral and superior cerebellar arteries, making it vulnerable to adjacent aneurysms.
• Early endovascular coiling or microsurgical clipping often leads to full or partial recovery of nerve function.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any acute headache with aneurysmal compression; isolated CN III palsy localizes lesion better than headache quality alone.
2. Assuming viral encephalitis can present with isolated cranial nerve palsies without encephalopathy or fever.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Heart Association/American Stroke Association. 2022 Guideline for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage. Recommends early elective repair (Class I, Level B) of unruptured aneurysms causing cranial neuropathies to prevent rupture and reverse symptoms.
• European Stroke Organization. 2023 Guideline on Endovascular Treatment of Intracranial Aneurysms. Advises endovascular coiling for Pcom aneurysms <10 mm with symptomatic nerve compression (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Vascular compressive cranial neuropathies—particularly Pcom aneurysm causing third nerve palsy—are frequently tested as image-based vignettes in both neurology and neurosurgery sections of board examinations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] • Hypercoagulability and Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT): OCPs increase clotting factors (II, VII, X) and reduce anticoagulants (protein S), predisposing to dural sinus thrombosis.
• Clinical Triad of CVT: headache (often severe), focal neurological deficits or seizures, and signs of intracranial hypertension. A normal non-contrast CT does not exclude CVT in ~30% of cases.
• Imaging Hierarchy: After non-contrast CT, targeted venous imaging (CTV or MR venography) is required to visualize thrombi in dural sinuses.

(Approx. 100 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT venography directly visualizes dural venous sinuses, detecting filling defects (e.g., “empty delta sign”) with sensitivity/specificity > 95% (Ferro et al., ISCVT JAMA 2004). The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 guidelines recommend CTV or MRV as the diagnostic standard when non-contrast CT is equivocal (Class I, Level B). Early diagnosis allows prompt anticoagulation, improving functional outcomes (Einhäupl et al., ESO 2017). MRI without venography sequences lacks the spatial resolution to reliably detect sinus thrombosis; hence MRI alone is insufficient. EEG evaluates cortical irritability but does not localize venous obstruction. Lumbar puncture risks herniation in raised intracranial pressure and has low yield for CVT.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Lumbar puncture (LP)
• Incorrect: LP opening pressure may be elevated but does not visualize thrombi.
• Misconception: Assuming all headache/seizure workups require LP.
• Differentiator: LP cannot confirm CVT and risks herniation if intracranial pressure is raised.

B. Electroencephalogram (EEG)
• Incorrect: EEG assesses electrical activity post-seizure but cannot diagnose structural vascular lesions.
• Misconception: Seizures always require EEG before imaging.
• Differentiator: EEG findings (e.g., epileptiform discharges) do not identify venous thrombosis.

D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
• Incorrect: Conventional MRI without MR venography misses up to 25% of dural sinus clots.
• Misconception: MRI is a one-stop modality for all cerebral pathologies.
• Differentiator: MR venography sequences (MRV) are required; plain MRI lacks venous phase imaging.

Comparison Table

- In OCP users with new-onset headache and seizures, maintain high suspicion for CVT even if non-contrast CT is normal.

1. Over-reliance on a normal non-contrast CT: up to 30% of CVT cases are radiographically occult without venous imaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2011 Guidelines on CVT: Recommend CTV or MRV for diagnosis after non-contrast CT (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization (ESO) 2017 Guidelines: Endorse CTV as first-line venous imaging in acute settings (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis commonly affects the superior sagittal sinus, transverse sinuses, and sigmoid sinus, impairing cortical venous drainage and causing parenchymal edema or hemorrhage.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

OCP-induced hypercoagulability leads to thrombus formation in dural venous sinuses, elevating intracranial pressure and provoking venous infarcts, hemorrhages, and seizures.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Non-contrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. If CT normal/suspicious, perform CTV (or MRV).
3. Confirm CVT → start anticoagulation.
4. Evaluate for prothrombotic states.

Neuroimaging Pearls

The “empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CTV indicates a filling defect in the superior sagittal sinus. Direct visualization of thrombus via CTV increases diagnostic confidence.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) may arise from hypertension (deep nuclei) or amyloid angiopathy/vascular malformations (lobar cortex). Non-contrast CT rapidly confirms hemorrhage. Vascular imaging then seeks treatable lesions (e.g., aneurysm, AVM).
Key points:
• Lobar hemorrhages warrant early angiographic evaluation for macrovascular causes.
• CT angiography (CTA) is rapid, noninvasive, and sensitive for aneurysms/AVMs.
• Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is gold standard but invasive, reserved when CTA is inconclusive.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTA is the recommended first-line vascular study in acute lobar ICH. The 2015 AHA/ASA ICH guideline (Hemphill et al., Stroke. 2015;46:2032–2060) gives CTA a Class I, Level B recommendation to identify structural lesions. CTA sensitivity for aneurysms/AVMs approaches 85–95%, with sub-5-minute acquisition in most centers. CTA also identifies the “spot sign,” an independent predictor of hematoma expansion (Delgado Almandoz JO et al., Radiology. 2009;251(1):206–213), guiding hemostatic interventions.
Conventional angiography (DSA) is Class IIa, LOE C—reserved when CTA is nondiagnostic but suspicion remains high. MRI/MRA, while excellent for cavernomas or amyloid microbleeds, has longer acquisition times, limited acute sensitivity for active bleeding, and often is impractical in unstable patients. Observation without vascular imaging risks missing treatable etiologies that alter management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. MRI
• Incorrect because acute MRI is time-consuming, less reliable for active vessel bleed detection, and less available in unstable ICH patients.
• Misconception: MRI is always superior for brain pathology.
• Differentiator: CTA provides vascular detail in minutes.

C. Conventional angiography
• Incorrect as initial test due to invasiveness, higher complication risk (stroke, groin hematoma), and longer procedure time.
• Misconception: DSA should always precede noninvasive studies.
• Differentiator: Reserve DSA for CTA-negative cases with ongoing suspicion.

D. Observation
• Incorrect because delaying vascular imaging may miss aneurysms/AVMs amenable to intervention, worsening outcomes.
• Misconception: Small or lobar bleeds in the elderly rarely have structural causes.
• Differentiator: Early CTA changes management by identifying treatable lesions.

2. Believing that deep hypertensive bleeds never warrant vascular imaging—atypical presentations (e.g., younger age, lobar location) require CTA.
3. Omitting CTA in elderly lobar hemorrhages, attributing all to amyloid angiopathy without ruling out AVM or aneurysm.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) Guidelines, 2015: Recommends CTA in acute lobar ICH to identify structural lesions (Class I, Level B).

• Delgado Almandoz JO et al., Radiology. 2009: Prospective cohort demonstrating CTA “spot sign” predicts hematoma expansion (Level II evidence).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Stroke classification (TOAST) divides ischemic stroke by mechanism: large-artery atherosclerosis, cardioembolism, small-vessel occlusion, other determined, and undetermined. Occipital lobe infarcts produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia. In a young trauma patient, consider vascular injury (dissection) leading to thrombus formation and distal embolization. Dissections most often involve the carotid or vertebral arteries after neck trauma, creating an intimal flap and intramural hematoma that can shed emboli into cerebral circulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Artery-to-artery embolism is correct: motor vehicle collisions commonly cause cervical artery dissection. An intimal tear in the vertebral or carotid artery produces an intramural thrombus, which embolizes distally to occlude cortical branches of the posterior cerebral artery, resulting in occipital infarction and homonymous hemianopia. A meta-analysis (Debette et al., Neurology 2015) showed 85% of traumatic dissections present with embolic strokes. AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines recommend vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) in suspected dissections and antithrombotic therapy to prevent recurrent embolism (Class I, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Large vessel atherosclerosis
• Incorrect: Usually chronic plaque in older patients; acute trauma does not induce rapid atherosclerotic plaque rupture.
• Misconception: Conflating dissection with atherosclerotic plaque disease.

C. Cardioembolic
• Incorrect: No evidence of arrhythmia, intracardiac thrombus, or valvular disease; mechanism here is arterial wall injury, not cardiac source.
• Misconception: Attributing all cortical strokes to the heart without vascular imaging.

D. Small vessel disease
• Incorrect: Causes lacunar infarcts in deep structures (basal ganglia, pons), not large cortical occipital infarcts.
• Misconception: Overextending lacunar syndromes to cortical deficits.

1. In trauma patients with focal deficits, always suspect cervical artery dissection and obtain CTA/MRA of head and neck.
2. Occipital lobe strokes manifest as contralateral homonymous hemianopia, often with macular sparing due to dual occipital supply.
3. First-line treatment for cervical artery dissection is antithrombotic therapy (aspirin or anticoagulation), individualized by bleeding risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming trauma must cause hemorrhage; arterial dissections can lead to ischemic stroke without hemorrhage.
• Misidentifying cortical homonymous deficits as occipital migraines or seizure phenomena.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 "Guidelines for Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke"
• Recommendation: Perform CTA/MRA in suspected cervical dissection (Class I, Level B).
2. CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurology 2015)
• Found no significant difference in recurrent stroke between antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy in cervical artery dissection (Level of Evidence A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The posterior cerebral artery (PCA), a branch of the vertebrobasilar system, supplies the occipital cortex. Emboli lodging in PCA branches produce contralateral visual field deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Trauma → intimal tear in cervical artery → intramural hematoma → luminal stenosis and platelet aggregation → distal artery-to-artery emboli → cortical infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect dissection in trauma with focal deficits.
2. Obtain CTA or MRA of head/neck.
3. Identify vessel wall irregularity, “string sign,” or intramural hematoma.
4. Initiate antithrombotic therapy.
5. Follow-up imaging at 3–6 months to ensure vessel healing.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT may miss early infarction; diffusion-weighted MRI is more sensitive.
• CTA/MRA can detect vessel wall hematoma and flap; digital subtraction angiography remains gold standard but is invasive.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Aspirin 75–325 mg daily is first-line for dissection (Class I, Level B).
• Consider anticoagulation (e.g., heparin to warfarin) in select cases based on CADISS trial data.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA) is a large-vessel vasculitis affecting branches of the external carotid artery, notably the superficial temporal artery. Key features include:
• Granulomatous inflammation of medium/large arteries leading to luminal narrowing and ischemia
• Jaw claudication and temporal headache from ischemia of masticatory muscles and periosteum
• Ocular involvement (transient or permanent vision changes) due to ophthalmic artery ischemia
Rapid initiation of high-dose corticosteroids is critical to prevent irreversible vision loss; diagnostic biopsy should follow but not delay therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

IV methylprednisolone is the recommended first step in suspected GCA with visual symptoms. EULAR 2018 guidelines (Hellmich et al., Ann Rheum Dis 2018) advise 500–1000 mg IV for 3 days in ocular involvement, then switch to high-dose oral prednisolone. Immediate therapy before biopsy reduces risk of anterior ischemic optic neuropathy. ACR/Vasculitis Foundation 2021 recommendations reinforce prompt high-dose steroids and suggest tocilizumab as a steroid-sparing adjunct (Stone et al., NEJM 2017). Starting IV methylprednisolone addresses acute ischemia faster than oral prednisone, halting inflammatory arteritis and preserving vision.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Why incorrect: Low-dose aspirin may reduce ischemic events but is adjunctive, not primary therapy.
• Misconception: Assuming antiplatelet therapy alone can prevent vision loss.
• Differentiator: Does not target granulomatous arterial inflammation.

C. Prednisone
• Why incorrect: Oral prednisone (40–60 mg/day) is standard when no visual symptoms; slower onset in acute visual threat.
• Misconception: Equating any corticosteroid route as equally effective in ocular involvement.
• Differentiator: Delayed peak concentrations vs. IV route.

D. Temporal artery biopsy
• Why incorrect: Biopsy confirms diagnosis but should follow, not precede, urgent steroid therapy.
• Misconception: Prioritizing tissue diagnosis over vision preservation.
• Differentiator: Diagnostic tool vs. therapeutic urgency.

• Jaw claudication has ~90% specificity for GCA.
• Always initiate high-dose steroids before temporal artery biopsy to prevent vision loss.
• Consider low-dose aspirin as an adjunct to reduce stroke risk in GCA.

1. Waiting for biopsy results before starting steroids, risking irreversible blindness.
2. Using only oral prednisone in acute visual symptoms, leading to delayed therapeutic levels.

• EULAR Recommendations 2018 (Hellmich et al.): For GCA with ocular involvement, start IV glucocorticoids (500–1000 mg/day for 3 days); then switch to oral prednisolone (LoE C).
• ACR/Vasculitis Foundation 2021: Endorses prompt high-dose steroids; tocilizumab added for steroid sparing (Level II evidence from Stone et al., NEJM 2017).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Inflammation of the superficial temporal artery (branch of external carotid) and its ophthalmic branch compromises blood flow to the optic nerve head, leading to anterior ischemic optic neuropathy.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Granulomatous infiltration of the arterial media and adventitia by multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes leads to intimal hyperplasia, luminal occlusion, and downstream ischemia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion with headache, jaw claudication, visual changes, high ESR/CRP
2. Start high-dose corticosteroids immediately
3. Ultrasound “halo sign” or MRI angiography if available
4. Temporal artery biopsy within 2 weeks of steroid initiation for confirmation

Neuroimaging Pearls

Ultrasound of temporal arteries may show a hypoechoic “halo sign” reflecting vessel wall edema; FDG-PET can detect large-vessel involvement.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

IV methylprednisolone: 500–1000 mg/day for 3 days, then switch to oral prednisolone 1 mg/kg/day. Monitor for steroid side effects; initiate bone protection.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] - Autoimmune hypercoagulability: Anti-phospholipid syndrome (APS) features autoantibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin, anti-β2-glycoprotein I) that activate endothelial cells and platelets, promoting thrombosis.
• Obstetric manifestations: Recurrent early pregnancy loss results from placental thrombosis and infarction.
• Dermatologic sign: Livedo reticularis arises from segmental cutaneous vascular occlusion.
• Diagnostic criteria: Sydney criteria require at least one clinical event (thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity) plus persistent antibody positivity ≥12 weeks apart.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-phospholipid antibody testing is the definitive laboratory evaluation for suspected APS in patients with thrombotic events or recurrent pregnancy loss. The 2006 Sydney update (Miyakis et al., J Thromb Haemost 2006) mandates testing for lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin IgG/IgM, and anti-β2-glycoprotein I. APS is identified in up to 15% of women with recurrent miscarriages (Branch et al., Blood 1998). Although lupus anticoagulant prolongs aPTT in vitro, routine coagulation profiles lack specificity and sensitivity for APS. Early diagnosis allows initiation of low-dose aspirin plus heparin, reducing miscarriage recurrence by 70–80% (Empson et al., Lancet 2005).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Complete blood count
• Incorrect: Evaluates anemia or thrombocytopenia but does not detect antiphospholipid antibodies or hypercoagulability.
• Misconception: Belief that a normal platelet count excludes clotting disorders.
• Differentiator: APS diagnosis relies on serologic antibody panels, not cell counts.

C. Thyroid function tests
• Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can cause miscarriage but does not explain livedo reticularis or thrombotic risk.
• Misconception: Assuming all recurrent pregnancy losses are endocrine in origin.
• Differentiator: APS presents with cutaneous vasculopathy and requires antibody detection.

D. Coagulation profile
• Incorrect: PT/aPTT may be paradoxically prolonged by lupus anticoagulant yet does not confirm APS.
• Misconception: Interpreting prolonged aPTT as bleeding tendency rather than thrombosis risk.
• Differentiator: Specific antiphospholipid antibody assays are necessary for diagnosis.

Clinical Pearls

- Lupus anticoagulant often prolongs aPTT in vitro but indicates thrombosis risk in vivo.
• Confirm persistent antibody positivity ≥12 weeks apart to avoid false positives from transient infections.
• Combined low-dose aspirin and heparin therapy in pregnant APS patients reduces miscarriage rates by up to 80%.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overreliance on PT/aPTT: Not pursuing specific antiphospholipid antibody testing when aPTT is normal or paradoxically prolonged.
2. Attributing all recurrent miscarriages to endocrine causes: Overlooking hypercoagulable evaluations in patients with livedo reticularis or thrombotic history.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EULAR 2019 Recommendations for managing APS: Advocate testing for lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, and anti-β2-glycoprotein I in women with ≥2 unexplained pregnancy losses (Level 1B evidence).
• ISTH SSC 2013 Guidelines: Recommend using a combination of lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, and anti-β2-glycoprotein I assays to improve diagnostic accuracy (Grade A recommendation).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] 1. Oculomotor (III) nerve anatomy: motor fibers (medial) and parasympathetic fibers (superficial) travel together; compressive lesions selectively impair peripheral parasympathetic fibers first, causing pupil dilation.
2. Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage classically presents with “thunderclap” headache (“worst headache of life”) and may produce acute cranial nerve palsies via mass effect.
3. The posterior communicating artery (PCom) arises from the internal carotid and lies adjacent to CN III; aneurysms here compress the nerve and cause an ipsilateral dilated, non-reactive pupil.
(Word count: 102)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior communicating artery aneurysms account for up to 50% of internal carotid aneurysms presenting with oculomotor palsy. The peripheral location of parasympathetic fibers makes them more vulnerable to compression; this explains the early pupillary involvement seen here. Aneurysm rupture into the subarachnoid space produces a sudden, severe headache (AHA/ASA 2022 guidelines recommend emergent non-contrast CT followed by CT angiography [Class I, Level B]). Early diagnosis and microsurgical clipping or endovascular coiling reduce rebleeding risk (ISAT trial 2005; long-term follow-up in Lancet Neurology 2023 confirms coiling superiority in suitable PCom aneurysms).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Anterior communicating artery
• Incorrect: ACom aneurysms predominantly impinge on the optic chiasm or frontal lobes, causing visual field deficits or personality changes, not CN III palsy.
• Misconception: Confusing location near optic apparatus with oculomotor nerve anatomy.
• Differentiation: ACom lesions rarely present with isolated third nerve signs.

C. Superior cerebellar artery
• Incorrect: SCA arises from the basilar artery near CN III exit but aneurysms here rarely compress the nerve; patients develop ataxia or cerebellar signs.
• Misconception: Any posterior circulation aneurysm can involve CN III.
• Differentiation: SCA aneurysms more often cause cerebellar dysfunction and headache without isolated pupillary dilation.

D. Internal carotid artery dissection
• Incorrect: Dissection causes ipsilateral Horner syndrome (miosis, ptosis), not dilated pupil.
• Misconception: Attributing sudden headache + oculomotor signs to any ICA pathology.
• Differentiation: In dissection the pupil is constricted due to sympathetic chain disruption.

Clinical Pearls

- Compressive III palsy (aneurysm/tumor) = pupil involvement; ischemic (diabetic) III palsy = pupil-sparing.
• In acute pupil-involving CN III palsy, obtain non-contrast CT ± CTA emergently to exclude PCom aneurysm.
• Nimodipine improves outcome in aneurysmal SAH by reducing vasospasm (AHA/ASA 2022).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing miosis of Horner syndrome (ICA dissection) with dilated pupil in III palsy.
2. Assuming all posterior circulation aneurysms (e.g., SCA, PCA) equally cause oculomotor palsy—only PCom lies in direct contact with CN III.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2022 Guideline for Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
­– Recommendation: Non-contrast CT followed by CTA or DSA in any suspected aneurysmal SAH with cranial nerve palsy (Class I, Level B).
2. International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT) long-term follow-up, Lancet Neurol 2023
­– Finding: Endovascular coiling of PCom aneurysms reduces 5-year morbidity compared to clipping in selected patients.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The oculomotor nerve exits the midbrain medial to the superior cerebellar artery and lateral to the PCA, then courses between the PCA and superior cerebellar artery before running adjacent to the PCom; superficial parasympathetic fibers on the nerve’s periphery mediate pupillary constriction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Aneurysmal dilation at the PCom segment exerts mass effect on the adjacent oculomotor nerve, compressing peripheral parasympathetic fibers first (causing mydriasis) and then motor fibers (ptosis, “down and out” deviation).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical identification of pupil-involving CN III palsy + thunderclap headache
2. Immediate non-contrast head CT to detect SAH
3. CT angiography for aneurysm localization
4. Digital subtraction angiography if CTA equivocal
5. Neurosurgical consultation for clipping vs endovascular coiling

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT angiography >95% sensitive for aneurysms >3 mm.
• “Fusiform dilation” at the ICA–PCom junction on CTA is pathognomonic.
• DSA remains gold standard for small aneurysms and surgical planning.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Nimodipine 60 mg orally every 4 hours for 21 days post-SAH to prevent vasospasm.
• Blood pressure control: systolic 120–160 mm Hg, avoid hypotension.
• Analgesia with acetaminophen; avoid NSAIDs to reduce bleeding risk.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Warfarin inhibits vitamin K–dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX and X, prolonging INR. In ICH, rapid correction is critical to limit hematoma expansion. Prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) provides concentrated factors II, VII, IX and X for speedy normalization of INR, whereas fresh frozen plasma (FFP) and vitamin K alone act more slowly. Key concepts:
• Vitamin K antagonist mechanism (warfarin)
• Hematoma expansion risk correlates with elevated INR
• Speed of reversal directly impacts clinical outcomes

Evidence-Based Analysis

PCC is superior to FFP for warfarin reversal in ICH due to:
1. Faster INR correction: Four-factor PCC normalizes INR within 30–60 minutes versus 4–6 hours for FFP.
2. Lower volume: PCC requires <200 mL infusion (vs >1 L for FFP), reducing risk of volume overload and transfusion‐related acute lung injury.
3. Guideline support: The 2015 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines (Hemphill JC et al., Stroke 2015) give Class I, Level A recommendation for four-factor PCC plus IV vitamin K for warfarin‐associated ICH.
4. Mortality benefit: Observational studies associate PCC use with reduced hematoma growth and lower 30-day mortality compared with FFP (Steiner T et al., Haematologica 2016).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP)
• Incorrect: Slower INR normalization (requires blood typing, thawing, large volumes).
• Misconception: Belief that broader factor replacement (including fibrinogen) is superior.
• Differentiator: Volume and time delay vs PCC’s rapid, low-volume correction.

C. Recombinant activated factor VII (rFVIIa)
• Incorrect: Off-label for warfarin reversal; limited to hemophilia A with inhibitors.
• Misconception: Overestimation of clotting boost from single factor.
• Differentiator: Does not replace factors II, IX, X and carries higher thrombosis risk.

D. Vitamin K alone
• Incorrect: Necessary adjunct but too slow (6–24 hours) to correct INR acutely.
• Misconception: Vitamin K monotherapy suffices in emergencies.
• Differentiator: Enhances endogenous factor synthesis only; no immediate reversal.

- Administer IV vitamin K (5–10 mg) concurrently with PCC to sustain reversal.
• Use four-factor PCC rather than three-factor PCC for comprehensive factor replacement.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on FFP delays reversal and increases volume overload risk.
2. Assuming vitamin K alone is sufficient in acute ICH leads to preventable hematoma expansion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2015 ICH Guidelines (Hemphill JC et al., Stroke 2015): Class I, Level A for four-factor PCC + IV vitamin K in warfarin‐related ICH.
• ASH 2016 Guidelines on Reversal of Antithrombotics: Recommends four-factor PCC over FFP for vitamin K antagonist reversal (Grade 1B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Warfarin inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, depleting reduced vitamin K needed to γ-carboxylate clotting factors. In ICH, continued anticoagulation leads to hematoma growth and raised intracranial pressure. Rapid factor repletion with PCC halts hemorrhage extension by restoring thrombin generation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- PCC dosing: 25–50 IU/kg based on baseline INR and product specifications.
• Concurrent vitamin K: 5–10 mg IV over 30 minutes to support endogenous synthesis.
• Monitor for thrombosis; consider patient comorbidities (e.g., DVT history).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Ischemic strokes are classified by mechanism:
• Lacunar infarcts result from small vessel disease (lipohyalinosis) often due to HTN/DM and local occlusion of penetrating arterioles.
• Large‐artery atherosclerosis (e.g., carotid stenosis) causes cortical or territorial infarcts when high‐grade stenosis leads to embolism or hypoperfusion.
• Cardioembolic strokes (e.g., from PFO or atrial fibrillation) often cause cortical infarcts and may warrant anticoagulation or closure.
Secondary prevention tailors therapy to the dominant mechanism: antiplatelet (small‐vessel), endarterectomy (high‐grade carotid), or anticoagulation/closure (cardioembolic).

Evidence-Based Analysis

The patient’s prior infarct was lacunar in the posterior limb of the internal capsule—classic for small‐vessel lipohyalinosis driven by HTN/DM. CTA showed extracranial atherosclerosis but without mention of ≥70% stenosis required for endarterectomy (ACAS/ACST trials). PFO closure trials (RESPECT, CLOSE) included cryptogenic cortical strokes in younger patients, not lacunar strokes in older hypertensive diabetics. NAVIGATE ESUS (2018) and RE-SPECT ESUS (2018) trials demonstrated no benefit of anticoagulation over aspirin in embolic‐stroke‐of‐undetermined‐source populations. The 2019 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines (Class I, Level of Evidence A) recommend antiplatelet monotherapy (aspirin 81–325 mg daily) for non‐cardioembolic ischemic stroke, particularly lacunar subtype.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Closure of PFO
• Incorrect because PFO closure is indicated in cryptogenic stroke with high‐risk PFO anatomy in patients <60 years without alternative mechanisms; lacunar infarct here points to small‐vessel disease, not paradoxical embolism.

B. Carotid endarterectomy
• Only indicated for symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥70% (NASCET criteria) or select 50–69% cases; “extracranial atherosclerosis” alone without degree of stenosis ≥70% does not meet surgical criteria.

D. Anticoagulation with warfarin
• Reserved for cardioembolic sources (e.g., atrial fibrillation, mechanical valves); small‐vessel lacunar strokes do not benefit and carry increased hemorrhagic risk (SPA therapy trials).

1. 2019 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The posterior limb of the internal capsule contains corticospinal fibers; lacunar infarcts here produce pure motor hemiparesis without cortical signs, characteristic of small‐vessel disease.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension and diabetes cause lipohyalinosis and fibrinoid necrosis of penetrating arterioles, leading to small (<15 mm) “lacunar” infarcts. These do not involve large carotid or cardiac embolic sources.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Brain MRI with DWI to confirm lacunar infarct.
2. Vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) to assess extracranial/intracranial stenosis.
3. Cardiac workup (echo, ECG) to rule out embolic sources.
4. Laboratory risk factor optimization (BP, glucose, lipids).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Lacunes appear as small (<15 mm) cavitary lesions on T1 hypointense/T2 hyperintense sequences.
• CTA noninvasively evaluates carotid/vertebral stenosis; avoid overcalling mild atherosclerotic plaques as surgical lesions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase‐1 (COX‐1), reducing thromboxane A2–mediated platelet aggregation. Standard dosing: 81–325 mg once daily; monitor for gastrointestinal side effects.

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Secondary stroke prevention questions frequently test matching stroke mechanism to targeted therapy, emphasizing the importance of lacunar vs large‐artery vs cardioembolic etiologies.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Watershed (border-zone) infarctions occur at junctions between major cerebral artery territories (most often ACA-MCA or MCA-PCA). These distal arterioles rely on adequate perfusion pressure and are most vulnerable when systemic or regional blood flow falls. Imaging shows wedge-shaped or linear DWI hyperintensities parallel to the cortical surface. Unilateral watershed patterns typically reflect focal hypoperfusion rather than embolic occlusion. Key terms: perfusion pressure, collateral circulation, hemodynamic stroke. Differentiating hemodynamic from embolic patterns is critical for targeted workup and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hypoperfusion is the direct pathophysiologic mechanism in watershed infarcts. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke classify border-zone infarctions under hemodynamic strokes due to reduced perfusion pressure (Class IIa, Level B-R). Bang et al. (Stroke.2011;42:391-397) demonstrated that patients with ≥70% ipsilateral ICA stenosis displayed ACA-MCA watershed infarcts on MRI, correlated with prolonged time-to-peak on CT perfusion. Distal arterioles in these zones have limited collateral support; when systemic blood pressure or carotid inflow drops below autoregulatory thresholds, cytotoxic edema ensues, seen as DWI hyperintensity. Thus, hypoperfusion—often secondary to large-artery stenosis—is the immediate mechanism.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Internal carotid artery (ICA) stenosis
– Incorrect because stenosis is an underlying etiology, not the direct mechanism.
– Misconception: equating cause with mechanism.
– Differentiator: steno­sis leads to hypoperfusion; the mechanism is reduced cerebral blood flow.

B. Cardiac embolism
– Emboli lodge in cortical branch arteries causing territorial infarcts, not border-zone patterns.
– Misconception: assuming all cortical infarcts are embolic.
– Differentiator: embolic strokes produce wedge-shaped territorial lesions with abrupt diffusion/ADC changes.

D. Venous thrombosis
– Venous outflow obstruction causes hemorrhagic infarcts with vasogenic edema, often in deep or cortical veins.
– Misconception: conflating venous infarcts with arterial border-zone strokes.
– Differentiator: venous infarcts show mixed signal on T1/T2 with possible hemorrhage, not pure DWI wedge shapes.

- In acute watershed infarcts, avoid aggressive antihypertensive therapy to preserve collateral perfusion.
• Carotid duplex ultrasound is first-line to detect high-grade ICA stenosis in suspected hemodynamic strokes.
• CT/MR perfusion imaging differentiates hypoperfusion from embolic penumbra, guiding revascularization decisions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking cortical watershed infarcts for lacunar strokes; lacunes are small (<15 mm), subcortical, due to small-vessel lipohyalinosis.
2. Attributing all cortical infarctions to embolism without assessing hemodynamic factors like carotid stenosis or systemic hypotension.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guideline on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends carotid endarterectomy for symptomatic 70–99% ICA stenosis to prevent recurrent hemodynamic strokes (Class I, Level A).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guideline: Advocates routine perfusion imaging in acute stroke to distinguish hemodynamic from embolic mechanisms, optimizing reperfusion strategies (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Watershed zones lie at the distal territories of ACA-MCA (anterior border zone, “V”-shaped along the convexity) and MCA-PCA (posterior border zone, occipital‐parietal junction). These regions have the lowest perfusion reserve and are first to infarct when cerebral perfusion pressure falls.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Reduced perfusion pressure—due to systemic hypotension or proximal arterial stenosis—drops below autoregulatory capacity in distal arterioles. Oxygen deprivation triggers failure of ion pumps, leading to cytotoxic edema and infarction in border-zone territories.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. MRI with DWI/ADC to confirm watershed pattern.
2. CT/MR perfusion imaging to quantify cerebral blood flow/volume and mean transit time.
3. Carotid duplex ultrasound or CT angiography for ICA stenosis.
4. Echocardiography and ECG to exclude cardioembolic sources.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI: Wedge-shaped hyperintensities parallel to cortical surface in border zones.
• MR angiography/CTA: Identifies high-grade carotid stenosis or occlusion.
• Perfusion maps: Show prolonged time-to-peak and decreased cerebral blood flow in affected regions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Malignant MCA infarction involves extensive cortical and subcortical ischemia leading to cytotoxic and vasogenic edema that peaks 48–72 h after onset. Because the skull is a fixed volume (Monro-Kellie doctrine), this edema causes intracranial hypertension, midline shift, and risk of transtentorial herniation. Decompressive hemicraniectomy (DHC) removes a large bone flap and opens the dura to accommodate swollen brain tissue, rapidly lowering intracranial pressure (ICP) and preventing secondary ischemic injury. Key concepts: 1) Pathophysiology of cytotoxic vs vasogenic edema; 2) ICP dynamics and herniation syndromes; 3) Time-dependent intervention within 48 h.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 h for malignant MCA infarction in patients ≤60 years reduces 12-month mortality from ~80 % to ~30–40 % and increases chances of favorable functional outcome (mRS 0–4). This is supported by three randomized controlled trials—DECIMAL (2007), DESTINY (2007), HAMLET (2009)—and a pooled meta-analysis (Vahedi et al., 2009). The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines give DHC a Class I, Level A recommendation for these patients. By providing immediate relief of ICP, DHC preserves cerebral perfusion and prevents fatal herniation, benefits not matched by medical therapy alone.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Medical management with osmotic agents
• Only provides transient ICP reduction, without expanding intracranial volume capacity.
• Common misconception: osmotherapy suffices to manage malignant edema.
• Does not lower mortality or improve functional outcomes significantly.

C. Anticoagulation therapy
• High risk of hemorrhagic transformation in large infarcts; no role in acute malignant MCA.
• Misconception: extending cardioembolic stroke protocols to massive infarctions.
• Fails to address life-threatening mass effect.

D. Thrombolysis
• Therapeutic window is ≤4.5 h; at 48 h post-stroke, tPA is contraindicated.
• Misconception: tPA can reverse established edema.
• Does not mitigate cytotoxic and vasogenic edema once infarction is completed.

• Overreliance on hyperosmolar therapy can delay definitive treatment.
• Misapplication of thrombolysis or anticoagulation beyond approved time windows in large infarcts.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] • Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) involves bleeding into brain parenchyma, causing mass effect, tissue injury, and perihematomal edema.
• VKAs (e.g., warfarin) inhibit vitamin K epoxide reductase, reducing γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, thereby elevating INR and exacerbating bleeding.
• Rapid normalization of INR is critical to limit hematoma expansion and improve outcomes; this requires both vitamin K (to restore endogenous factor synthesis) and factor replacement (PCC preferred).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct because withholding the VKA and administering vitamin K addresses the root cause (vitamin K–dependent factor deficiency) and begins synthesis of new clotting factors within hours. The 2015 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines (Class I, Level A) mandate immediate reversal of VKA-associated coagulopathy with IV vitamin K (5–10 mg) plus four-factor PCC. Trials such as Sarode et al. (NEJM 2013) demonstrated that four-factor PCC normalizes INR in a median of 30 minutes in 70% of patients versus 10% with FFP (p<0.001), reducing hematoma growth without increased thrombosis. Neither rFVIIa (off-label, high thrombosis risk, no functional benefit) nor FFP alone (slow infusion, large volume, delayed INR correction) substitute for targeted vitamin K–mediated factor regeneration.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Continue VKA therapy
• Incorrect: perpetuates coagulopathy, risking hematoma expansion.
• Misconception: maintaining anticoagulation for stroke prevention outweighs acute hemorrhage risk.
• Differentiator: acute ICH management prioritizes hemostasis over long-term anticoagulation.

C. Administer rFVIIa
• Incorrect: rFVIIa can transiently correct INR but has no proven outcome benefit in ICH and carries a high arterial and venous thrombosis risk (up to 10%).
• Misconception: any factor concentrate is equally safe/effective.
• Differentiator: rFVIIa lacks vitamin K–dependent factor support and is not guideline-endorsed for VKA reversal in ICH.

D. Administer fresh frozen plasma
• Incorrect as sole therapy: FFP requires blood typing, thawing, and large volumes (≈15 mL/kg), delaying reversal; slower INR correction compared to PCC.
• Misconception: FFP is first-line when PCC is unavailable.
• Differentiator: FFP is a backup when PCC is unavailable; vitamin K remains mandatory.

Clinical Pearls

• In warfarin-related ICH, always co-administer IV vitamin K with factor replacement (PCC preferred).
• Four-factor PCC achieves INR <1.4 within 30 minutes in most patients; FFP is only if PCC is unavailable.
• Subcutaneous vitamin K is too slow; always use the IV route (5–10 mg) for acute ICH.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on FFP delays INR normalization and risks volume overload in older or heart-failure patients.
2. Assuming rFVIIa is safer than PCC; it increases arterial thromboses without improving neurologic outcomes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA ICH Guidelines 2015: “IV vitamin K (5–10 mg) plus four-factor PCC for VKA reversal in ICH” (Class I, LOE A).
• Sarode R. et al., NEJM 2013: Four-factor PCC achieved rapid INR reversal (median 30 min vs 4 h with FFP; p<0.001) with fewer transfusion complications.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Warfarin blocks vitamin K epoxide reductase → insufficient γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, X → impaired prothrombin activation → prolonged INR → unchecked bleeding in ruptured cerebral vessels → hematoma growth exacerbates intracranial pressure and secondary injury.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Vitamin K (IV 5–10 mg): restores γ-carboxylation of vitamin K–dependent factors over 6–12 h.
• Four-factor PCC (25–50 IU/kg): provides immediate clotting factors II, VII, IX, X; normalizes INR within 30 min.
• FFP (15 mL/kg): slower INR correction, requires thawing and blood-type matching.
• rFVIIa: generates thrombin burst locally but lacks sustained factor support; off-label in ICH.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] - Visual pathways: Lesion posterior to the optic chiasm produces homonymous hemianopia; involvement of left occipital cortex causes right hemifield loss.
• Disconnection syndromes: The splenium of the corpus callosum transmits visual information from the non-dominant (right) occipital lobe to the dominant (left) language cortex; its infarction yields alexia without agraphia.
• Alexia without agraphia: Characterized by preserved writing (intact language output) but inability to read due to disrupted interhemispheric transfer of visual word forms.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The classic “pure alexia” or alexia without agraphia arises from a posterior cerebral artery (PCA) infarct that damages both the left occipital cortex (causing right homonymous hemianopia) and the splenium of the corpus callosum (disrupting transfer of visual information from the right occipital lobe to the left angular gyrus/language areas). De Renzi et al. (1985) first delineated this syndrome, and subsequent imaging studies confirm that isolated splenial lesions in the dominant hemisphere reliably produce alexia without affecting writing. The splenium—rich in commissural fibers—when infarcted, prevents visual input from reaching Wernicke’s and angular gyri, thus abolishing reading despite intact language production.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Right occipital lobe
• Why incorrect: A right occipital lesion causes left homonymous hemianopia, opposite to the patient’s right field defect.
• Misconception: Assuming any occipital lesion yields alexia; does not explain right-sided visual loss or disconnect reading.
• Differentiator: Cannot produce right homonymous hemianopia nor selective reading deficit.

C. Left occipital lobe
• Why incorrect: Pure left occipital infarct gives right hemianopia but spares interhemispheric transfer via intact splenium; patients can still read left visual field stimuli.
• Misconception: Believing that occipital cortex damage alone causes alexia without agraphia.
• Differentiator: Requires additional splenial damage to block contralateral visual input for full alexia.

D. Left angular gyrus
• Why incorrect: Angular gyrus lesions produce alexia with agraphia (both reading and writing impaired) and Gerstmann’s constellation, not pure alexia.
• Misconception: Conflating language area damage with disconnection syndromes.
• Differentiator: Angular damage disrupts language output (writing) as well as comprehension.

Clinical Pearls

1. Alexia without agraphia signifies a PCA infarct that hits both left visual cortex and splenium—always inspect callosal splenium on MRI when reading loss is isolated.
2. In pure alexia, patients trace letters with a finger to read, demonstrating reliance on intact ipsilateral visual cortex.
3. Preservation of writing rules out angular gyrus lesions and points to a disconnection syndrome.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking pure alexia (alexia without agraphia) for global alexia; neglecting to assess writing.
• Confusing angular gyrus lesions (alexia with agraphia) with splenial disconnection syndromes.
• Overlooking homonymous hemianopia lateralization, leading to mislocalization of occipital lesions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2023 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Recommendation 1.1: Perform urgent neuroimaging (CT/MRI) to identify vascular territory and assess corpus callosum integrity (Class I, Level B-R).
2. ESO 2021 Guidelines on Diagnosis and Management of Acute Stroke
• Recommend systematic evaluation of visual and language deficits in posterior circulation strokes to refine localization and guide secondary prevention (Grade 1A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The splenium is the posterior thickened segment of the corpus callosum, containing fibres that interconnect occipital and posterior temporal lobes. Damage interrupts transfer of visual word-form information from the right hemisphere to the dominant left hemisphere language areas (angular gyrus, Wernicke’s area).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

A left PCA infarct involving the calcarine branch causes right homonymous hemianopia; extension into the callosal fibers of the splenium severs interhemispheric visual transfer, producing selective inability to read despite intact writing and oral language pathways.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT may show subtle hypodensity in the posterior corpus callosum; MRI DWI is more sensitive for early splenial infarcts.
• In pure alexia, concurrent lesions in left occipital cortex and splenium produce characteristic imaging findings—look for hyperintense signals on DWI in these regions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Internal carotid artery (ICA) dissection arises from an intimal tear allowing blood to track into the vessel wall, forming an intramural hematoma that narrows the lumen and predisposes to thromboembolism. The ICA supplies anterior circulation structures (MCA/ACA territories), so dissection often presents with contralateral motor deficits. Acute goals are to prevent clot propagation and distal embolism. First-line therapy is medical (antithrombotic) rather than mechanical intervention. Key terms: intramural hematoma, thromboembolism, anterior circulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medical therapy—specifically antithrombotic treatment—is the cornerstone of acute management. The 2018 AHA/ASA stroke guidelines give a Class I recommendation for antithrombotic therapy in cervical artery dissection, without specifying superiority of anticoagulation over antiplatelets. The CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol 2015) randomized 250 patients to antiplatelet vs anticoagulation arms, finding no difference in stroke recurrence at 3 months. More recently, the TREAT-CAD trial (Lancet Neurol 2022) demonstrated aspirin non-inferiority to vitamin K antagonists for preventing stroke/TIA in dissection. Endovascular approaches (stenting/angioplasty) carry risks of vessel injury and are reserved for cases with recurrent ischemia despite optimal medical therapy or expanding pseudoaneurysms.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Stenting – Endovascular stenting is an invasive option with risk of vessel rupture and in-stent thrombosis; reserved for patients with progressive ischemia or large pseudoaneurysms refractory to medical therapy. Misconception: that mechanical reconstruction always beats antithrombotic therapy.
B. Angioplasty – Balloon angioplasty alone risks vessel rupture and intimal re-tear. It does not address thrombus in the false lumen and is not first-line.
D. Anticoagulation – Although anticoagulants inhibit thrombus propagation, trials (CADISS, TREAT-CAD) show no clear benefit over antiplatelets and carry higher hemorrhagic risk; guidelines now favor antiplatelet therapy in most cases.
