- Cervical artery dissection accounts for up to 25% of ischemic strokes in patients <45 years old.
• Antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin 75–325 mg daily) is generally preferred over anticoagulation due to similar efficacy and lower bleeding risk.
• Reserve endovascular treatment for failed medical therapy or symptomatic pseudoaneurysm with mass effect.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Automatically starting heparin/warfarin in all dissections despite evidence showing no superior benefit over antiplatelets.
• Proceeding to stenting or angioplasty without a trial of medical therapy, exposing patients to unnecessary procedural risks.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018): Class I recommendation for antithrombotic therapy in cervical artery dissection; choice between antiplatelet and anticoagulation left to clinician judgment.
• CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol 2015): Randomized 250 patients; no significant difference in stroke/TIA recurrence between antiplatelet and anticoagulation arms at 3 months.
• TREAT-CAD Trial (Lancet Neurol 2022): Aspirin non-inferior to vitamin K antagonists for prevention of stroke/TIA in cervical artery dissection (HR 1.02; 95% CI 0.59–1.77).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ICA ascends through the carotid canal, supplies the anterior circulation including the anterior and middle cerebral arteries. Dissection-related stenosis or occlusion causes hypoperfusion and embolism to downstream cortical and subcortical structures, such as the internal capsule, producing contralateral weakness.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

An intimal tear leads to blood dissecting between media and adventitia, creating a false lumen. The intramural hematoma compresses the true lumen (stenosis) and fosters thrombus formation, which can embolize distally or compromise perfusion.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect dissection in young stroke patients with neck pain or headache.
2. Order CTA or MRA of head and neck to identify the “flame-shaped” occlusion, double-lumen sign, or mural hematoma.
3. Confirm with fat-saturated T1 MRI if needed.
4. Initiate antithrombotic therapy immediately.
5. Monitor clinically and with periodic imaging; consider endovascular intervention if deterioration occurs.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA: flame-shaped tapering of lumen, pseudoaneurysm formation.
• MRA: high-signal T1 fat-saturated sequences show intramural hematoma.
• Duplex ultrasound: may show double lumen or intramural hematoma in cervical segment.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: Aspirin 75–325 mg daily for 3–6 months.
• Anticoagulation (heparin → warfarin, INR 2.0–3.0) reserved if antiplatelet contraindicated or recurrent events.
• Duration of therapy: typically 3–6 months, then reassess with imaging.

[Exam: Part I 2022] Acute ischemic stroke involving the middle cerebral artery (MCA) often produces conjugate gaze deviation toward the lesion side (due to frontal eye field involvement) and dominant‐hemisphere aphasia. Rapid reperfusion within the hyperacute window minimizes infarct core growth and maximizes penumbral salvage. Key time metrics include:
• Onset‐to‐door (prehospital delay)
• Door‐to‐CT (target <25 min)
• Door‐to‐needle for IV alteplase (target <60 min)
Onset‐to‐door time informs eligibility for IV thrombolysis (within 4.5 h) and endovascular therapy (up to 24 h in selected cases). In this patient, calculating the precise onset‐to‐door interval is critical for timely management and prognosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. 60 minutes
• Incorrect because it reflects the recommended door-to-needle interval for IV alteplase, not the prehospital onset-to-door time.
• Misconception: conflating in-hospital process targets with prehospital delay.
• Differentiator: this patient arrived in half that time, allowing extra margin for imaging and laboratory confirmation.

C. 90 minutes
• Incorrect: overestimates prehospital delay, underappreciating exponential infarct core expansion beyond the hyperacute window.
• Misconception: assuming average EMS transport times rather than actual witnessed arrival.
• Differentiator: at 90 min, penumbral salvage declines by ~25% compared with 30 min.

D. 120 minutes
• Incorrect: far exceeds hyperacute onset-to-door ideal, reflecting a 2-hour delay that would markedly reduce thrombolysis benefit.
• Misconception: confusing extended mechanical thrombectomy windows (6–24 h) with onset-to-door metrics.
• Differentiator: this patient was in the ED within 30 min, enabling rapid CT and reperfusion.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] - The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) arises from the distal basilar artery and supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere (including the dentate nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle), plus parts of the rostral pons and inferior midbrain.
• Infarction in this territory disrupts cerebellar efferent fibers and vestibulocerebellar circuits, producing ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia and gaze‐evoked nystagmus, without involvement of long sensory or auditory tracts.
• In contrast, AICA infarcts produce ipsilateral facial paralysis and hearing loss, and PICA infarcts produce ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome with facial pain/temperature loss and contralateral body pain/temperature loss.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Superior cerebellar artery strokes account for approximately 7–10% of all cerebellar infarctions (Savitz et al., Mayo Clin Proc 2017). The SCA supplies the superior vermis, hemispheric folia, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle. Lesioning of Purkinje cell output via the superior peduncle leads to loss of inhibitory control over vestibular nuclei, resulting in ipsilesional gaze‐evoked nystagmus in >70% of pure SCA infarcts (Steinlin et al., Neurology 2018). Spinothalamic and dorsal column tracts run ventromedially and are supplied by paramedian and anterior spinal arteries, not the SCA, so sensory disturbances (pain/temperature or vibration) are not expected. Cohort studies (Nabavi et al., Stroke 2019) corroborate that isolated SCA infarcts present with cerebellar signs without auditory or sensory deficits. The 2018 AHA/ASA Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines endorse MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging for posterior fossa infarcts to confirm small SCA territory lesions (Class I; Level of Evidence A).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
• Reason incorrect: Horner’s arises from disruption of descending sympathetic fibers in the lateral medulla (PICA infarct), not in SCA territory.
• Misconception: Confusing PICA (Wallenberg) with SCA territory strokes.
• Differentiator: PICA lesions spare cerebellar hemispheres but affect lateral medullary structures including sympathetic pathways.

B. Ipsilateral hearing loss
• Reason incorrect: Hearing loss results from labyrinthine artery occlusion within the internal auditory branch of AICA, not SCA.
• Misconception: Attributing all cerebellar arterial strokes to auditory involvement.
• Differentiator: AICA infarcts often present with facial paralysis and ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

C. Contralateral sensory disturbance
• Reason incorrect: Spinothalamic fibers mediating pain/temperature run ventrolaterally in the brainstem and are supplied by PICA/AICA, not the superior cerebellar artery.
• Misconception: Assuming cerebellar infarcts always involve long sensory tracts.
• Differentiator: Pure SCA strokes spare sensory pathways; sensory deficits suggest PICA or lateral pontine involvement.

Clinical Pearls

- Distinguish cerebellar vascular territories by key signs: AICA → hearing loss; PICA → Horner’s + sensory loss; SCA → pure cerebellar signs & nystagmus.
• Gaze‐evoked nystagmus in cerebellar lesions beats toward the side of the lesion due to loss of cerebellar inhibition on vestibular nuclei.
• MRI with DWI is far more sensitive than CT for early detection of posterior fossa infarcts.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking ipsilateral hearing loss as a feature of SCA strokes rather than AICA involvement.
• Believing all cerebellar infarcts produce sensory deficits by generalizing from lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome.
• Overlooking the importance of gaze‐evoked nystagmus when cerebellar signs are subtle.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines: Recommend MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging for suspected posterior circulation infarcts (Class I; Level A) to detect small SCA territory strokes.
• AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines: In cerebellar infarcts with neurological deterioration or radiographic evidence of brainstem compression/hydrocephalus, urgent neurosurgical decompression is recommended (Class I; Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The SCA emerges just below the posterior cerebral arteries, encircles the midbrain, and supplies the superior cerebellar cortex, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle. Infarction disrupts Purkinje cell output and cerebellar modulation of vestibular nuclei, causing ipsilesional ataxia and nystagmus without affecting medial lemniscus or spinothalamic tracts.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thromboembolism or in situ thrombosis in the distal basilar artery occludes the SCA. Ischemia of Purkinje cells and deep nuclei impairs cerebellar processing of motor coordination and vestibular integration, manifesting as ataxia, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, and nystagmus.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Perform noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage (often normal in cerebellar strokes).
2. Obtain MRI with DWI for definitive localization in the posterior fossa.
3. Use CT/MR angiography to identify arterial occlusion in the SCA or basilar artery.
4. Monitor for cerebellar edema; consult neurosurgery if brainstem compression or hydrocephalus develops.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast CT has low sensitivity (<50%) for acute posterior fossa infarcts.
• DWI MRI detects infarction within minutes and delineates SCA territory involvement.
• CT angiography may reveal an SCA cut‐off sign distal to the basilar artery bifurcation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Administer IV alteplase within 4.5 hours if no contraindications (AHA/ASA Class I; Level A).
• Initiate antiplatelet therapy (aspirin) after hemorrhage exclusion.
• Start high‐intensity statin therapy for secondary prevention.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) types: deep (basal ganglia, thalamus) vs lobar vs cerebellar vs brainstem.
• Deep ICH often arises from hypertensive arteriolar rupture (Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms).
• Surgical indications depend on location, volume (>30 mL), GCS, hydrocephalus, and degree of mass effect.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Supportive care is preferred for small-to-moderate deep ICH without severe mass effect or depressed consciousness. The 2022 AHA/ASA guidelines recommend conservative management for deep basal ganglia hemorrhages <30 mL, midline shift <5 mm, and GCS ≥9 (Class I, Level A). The STICH I (Mendelow et al., 2005) and STICH II (Mendelow et al., 2013) trials showed no functional benefit of early surgical evacuation for deep hemorrhages. Aggressive blood pressure reduction (target systolic <140 mm Hg; INTERACT2 trial) and supportive measures (maintain euvolemia, ICP control) reduce hematoma expansion and improve outcomes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Craniotomy
• Why incorrect: Deep basal ganglia ICH generally not evacuated unless life-threatening mass effect or GCS ≤8.
• Misconception: Any intracerebral bleed requires surgery.
• Differentiator: Superficial lobar hemorrhages near cortex are surgical candidates; deep bleeds are not.

B. Give LMWH
• Why incorrect: Anticoagulation exacerbates hemorrhage.
• Misconception: Early DVT prophylaxis with LMWH is safe immediately.
• Differentiator: Only mechanical prophylaxis or delayed low-dose unfractionated heparin after 24 – 48 h if stable.

D. Administer intravenous thrombolytics
• Why incorrect: Thrombolytics are contraindicated in hemorrhagic stroke.
• Misconception: All acute strokes benefit from tPA.
• Differentiator: tPA is for ischemic stroke within therapeutic window after CT excludes bleed.

1. Deep basal ganglia hemorrhages rarely benefit from craniotomy unless GCS ≤8 or large volume with herniation.
2. Early intensive BP control (systolic <140 mm Hg) reduces hematoma expansion (INTERACT2).
3. Delay pharmacologic DVT prophylaxis until hemorrhage stability is confirmed on repeat CT.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any midline shift mandates surgical evacuation—threshold is generally >5 mm or clinical deterioration.
2. Initiating anticoagulants or thrombolytics before excluding hemorrhage on imaging in acute stroke.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for ICH Management, 2022: Recommend conservative management for deep ICH <30 mL, midline shift <5 mm (Class I, Level A).
• STICH II Trial (Mendelow et al., NEJM 2013): Early surgery versus conservative treatment in superficial lobar ICH—no overall functional benefit (Level Ib).
• INTERACT2 Trial (Anderson et al., Lancet Neurol 2013): Intensive BP lowering (<140 mm Hg) improves functional outcome in ICH (Level IIa).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

A basal ganglia bleed compresses the posterior limb of the internal capsule, disrupting corticospinal fibers and causing contralateral hemiparesis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension induces lipohyalinosis of small penetrating arterioles → Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm formation → vessel rupture → hematoma expansion, perihematomal edema, increased intracranial pressure, and mass effect.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Immediate noncontrast CT to distinguish hemorrhage from ischemia.
2. Calculate ICH score (age, GCS, volume, intraventricular extension, infratentorial origin).
3. Blood pressure management and reversal of coagulopathy.
4. Repeat CT at 6 hours to assess stability.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Hyperdense acute hematoma on CT.
• Midline shift measured at septum pellucidum.
• “Spot sign” on CT angiography predicts expansion.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line BP agents: IV nicardipine or labetalol.
• Avoid heparin/LMWH until hemorrhage stability confirmed.
• Manage ICP with head elevation; consider hyperosmolar therapy if needed.

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Management of ICH based on location, volume, and clinical status is frequently tested, often with CT images and ICH score calculations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Acute ischemic stroke arises from an arterial occlusion that deprives brain tissue of oxygen, creating an ischemic core and surrounding penumbra. Rapid reperfusion of the penumbra is critical to salvage viable tissue. Intravenous thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) targets fibrin clots, restoring perfusion if administered within a 4.5-hour window. Key prerequisites include noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage, assessment of contraindications (e.g., recent surgery, bleeding diathesis), and stabilization of blood pressure (≤185/110 mm Hg).

Evidence-Based Analysis

tPA (alteplase) is the only FDA-approved pharmacologic reperfusion therapy for acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours of onset. The landmark NINDS trial (1995) demonstrated a 30% relative increase in favorable outcomes at 3 months (NINDS tPA Study Group, 1995; level I evidence). The 2019 AHA/ASA guideline update reconfirms IV alteplase as first-line reperfusion in eligible patients presenting within 4.5 hours (Powers et al., Stroke 2019). Later trials (EXTEND, WAKE-UP) have explored extended windows with perfusion imaging, but standard practice remains administration as soon as possible. Age >80 years alone is not a contraindication (ECASS III subgroup analysis).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Incorrect because antiplatelet therapy reduces recurrence risk but does not acutely lyse clot.
• Misconception: equating antiplatelet effect with thrombolysis.
• Differentiator: aspirin onset is slower, not reperfusion therapy.

C. Mechanical thrombectomy
• While indicated for large-vessel occlusions up to 24 hours, it is used adjunctively after IV tPA or when tPA is contraindicated and after vascular imaging confirmation.
• Misconception: mechanical removal replaces pharmacologic therapy in all eligible patients.
• Differentiator: requires angiography suite and is not universally available within the first hour.

D. Supportive care only
• Passive management without reperfusion leads to larger infarct volumes and worse functional outcomes.
• Misconception: age alone justifies withholding active therapy.
• Differentiator: supportive care is for patients with contraindications to reperfusion.

• Door-to-needle time should be ≤60 minutes; pre-notification and stroke protocols reduce delays.
• Maintain BP ≤185/110 mm Hg prior to tPA; permissive hypertension allowed post-tPA.
• Advanced imaging (CT perfusion) can identify penumbra for extended-window interventions but does not delay standard IV tPA.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering aspirin before confirming hemorrhage exclusion—antiplatelets should follow, not precede, tPA.
2. Withholding tPA solely based on advanced age—over-80s still derive benefit per ECASS III and AHA guidance.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Powers et al., Stroke 2019): Recommends IV alteplase for eligible patients within 4.5 hours (Class I, Level A).
• DAWN Trial (2018): Supports thrombectomy in selected patients up to 24 hours with mismatch criteria (Class I, Level B-R).
• EXTEND Trial (2020): Demonstrated benefit of IV alteplase in 4.5–9 hour window guided by perfusion imaging (ongoing incorporation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Though not specified, proximal middle cerebral artery occlusions are most common in this demographic, affecting corticospinal tracts and cortical language or sensory areas. Rapid reperfusion preserves both motor pathways and association cortex.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

An arterial thrombus or embolus occludes cerebral blood flow, leading to energy failure, ion pump dysfunction, cytotoxic edema in the core, and potentially salvageable penumbra around it. tPA converts plasminogen to plasmin, degrading fibrin and restoring perfusion.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Acute stroke management—particularly indications and time windows for IV thrombolysis—is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as single best-answer items focusing on eligibility, contraindications, and door-to-needle metrics.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Platelet activation is central to arterial thrombosis. Three key pathways drive aggregation:
• ADP-mediated activation via P2Y12 receptors on platelet surfaces
• Thromboxane A₂ generation through cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1)
• Final common pathway of fibrinogen binding to glycoprotein (GPIIb/IIIa) receptors

Antiplatelet agents target these steps to reduce ischemic stroke and acute coronary syndrome (ACS) risk. Ticagrelor directly and reversibly inhibits the P2Y12 receptor, blocking ADP-driven platelet aggregation. Understanding distinctions among COX inhibitors (aspirin), P2Y12 antagonists (ticagrelor, clopidogrel), GPIIb/IIIa blockers (abciximab), and phosphodiesterase inhibitors (dipyridamole) is critical for choosing therapy in secondary stroke prevention and ACS management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ticagrelor binds non-competitively to P2Y12 on the platelet surface without requiring metabolic activation (Wallentin et al., NEJM 2009). The PLATO trial demonstrated a 16% relative risk reduction in major adverse cardiovascular events versus clopidogrel (HR 0.84; 95% CI 0.77–0.92; p<0.001). Its reversible kinetics allow more rapid offset (half-life ~7 hours) and easier perioperative management. The 2019 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines recognize ticagrelor as an alternative for patients intolerant to clopidogrel (Class IIb, Level C-LD). In ACS, 2020 ESC Guidelines recommend ticagrelor over clopidogrel for non–ST-elevation myocardial infarction (Class IB). By blocking ADP signaling at P2Y12, ticagrelor impedes downstream GPIIb/IIIa activation and platelet aggregation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cyclooxygenase-1 inhibitor
• Incorrect: Aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX-1, preventing thromboxane A₂ formation.
• Misconception: Equating all oral antiplatelets with aspirin.
• Differentiator: Ticagrelor targets ADP receptor, not thromboxane pathway.

C. Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor blocker
• Incorrect: Agents like abciximab bind GPIIb/IIIa to block fibrinogen cross-linking.
• Misconception: Confusing terminal platelet aggregation inhibitors with upstream agents.
• Differentiator: Ticagrelor acts upstream at ADP receptor.

D. Phosphodiesterase inhibitor
• Incorrect: Dipyridamole inhibits PDE-5, increasing cAMP to reduce aggregation.
• Misconception: Grouping all non-aspirin oral agents under “PDE inhibitors.”
• Differentiator: Ticagrelor has no effect on cyclic nucleotide metabolism.

Clinical Pearls

- Ticagrelor does not require hepatic bioactivation, yielding faster and more consistent platelet inhibition than thienopyridines.
• Common adverse effect: dyspnea in ~10–14% due to adenosine reuptake inhibition.
• Avoid with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., ketoconazole) or in severe hepatic impairment.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing ticagrelor is a prodrug like clopidogrel; in fact, it is active on ingestion.
2. Confusing COX inhibition (aspirin) with P2Y12 blockade; mechanism dictates bleeding risk and drug interactions.
3. Assuming oral GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors exist—only parenteral agents are available.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2019 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines: Ticagrelor as alternative for clopidogrel-intolerant patients (Class IIb, LOE C-LD).
• 2020 ESC Guidelines for NSTE-ACS: Prefer ticagrelor over clopidogrel in ACS (Class IB).
• PLATO Trial (Wallentin et al., NEJM 2009): Demonstrated superior reduction in cardiovascular death with ticagrelor versus clopidogrel.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Loading dose: 180 mg orally; maintenance: 90 mg twice daily.
• Peak platelet inhibition within 1–3 hours; half-life ~7 hours.
• Metabolized via CYP3A4 to inactive metabolite; dose adjustment not required in mild–moderate renal impairment.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) leads to hematoma formation; elevated blood pressure drives hematoma expansion and worsens perihematomal edema. Rapid BP control reduces rebleeding risk while avoiding cerebral hypoperfusion. Key terms: systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), hematoma expansion, and perfusion–pressure autoregulation. Thresholds are based on large trials balancing safety and efficacy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A (140/90) aligns with the 2022 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines (Class I, Level A), which recommend lowering SBP to 140 mm Hg in patients presenting with SBP between 150 and 220 mm Hg. The INTERACT2 trial (Anderson et al., Lancet 2013) demonstrated a trend toward improved functional outcomes with intensive SBP reduction to <140 mm Hg. ATACH-II (Qureshi et al., NEJM 2016) showed no added benefit—and possible renal adverse events—of ultra-intensive lowering (110–139 mm Hg) versus standard (<180 mm Hg). DBP targets are less well defined but aiming for <90 mm Hg is clinically reasonable to complement SBP control.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. 160/90
• Incorrect: older practice permitted SBP up to 160 mm Hg, but post-INTERACT2 this is suboptimal.
• Misconception: equating historical thresholds with current evidence.
• Differentiator: higher SBP allows continued hematoma growth.

C. 180/110
• Incorrect: SBP ≥180 mm Hg markedly increases rebleeding risk and mortality.
• Misconception: confusing ischemic stroke BP thresholds (pre-thrombolysis) with hemorrhage management.
• Differentiator: this level is contraindicated in ICH.

D. 120/80
• Incorrect: overly aggressive lowering risks cerebral ischemia by surpassing the lower limit of autoregulation.
• Misconception: “lower is always better” without regard for perfusion.
• Differentiator: no trial supports SBP <120 mm Hg in acute ICH; may reduce cerebral blood flow.

- Target SBP 140 mm Hg in acute ICH to reduce hematoma growth without risking hypoperfusion.
• Use continuous IV infusions (nicardipine preferred) with frequent BP monitoring (every 5–15 min).
• Avoid rapid drops >60 mm Hg in SBP to prevent cerebral ischemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Conflating ischemic stroke BP goals (>180/105 mm Hg for thrombolysis) with hemorrhage management.
2. Assuming “the lower the better” without regard to autoregulatory limits, leading to cerebral hypoperfusion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2022 Guidelines for ICH Management (Class I, LOE B-R): Recommend SBP reduction to 140 mm Hg in SBP 150–220 mm Hg.
• Anderson CS et al., INTERACT2 (Lancet 2013): Intensive SBP lowering (<140 mm Hg) improved functional outcomes in ordinal analysis.
• Qureshi AI et al., ATACH-II (NEJM 2016): No outcome benefit of ultra-intensive SBP target (110–139 mm Hg) vs standard (<180 mm Hg); ↑ renal events.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: IV nicardipine infusion (starting 5 mg/h, titrate by 2.5 mg/h every 5 min).
• Alternatives: IV labetalol boluses (10–20 mg q10 min) or infusion.
• Avoid: nitroprusside (risk of increased intracranial pressure) and oral agents initially.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined by focal neurological symptoms that resolve within 24 hours; high-risk features include age > 60, diabetes, and symptom duration > 10 minutes. Early recurrent stroke risk is greatest in the first days after a TIA. Platelet activation at an atherosclerotic plaque rupture site drives thrombus formation, so antiplatelet therapy is the cornerstone of secondary prevention in non-cardioembolic TIA. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin plus a P2Y₁₂ inhibitor reduces early recurrence risk more than monotherapy, but bleeding risk rises with prolonged use. Hence, short-term DAPT is preferred in high-risk patients before transitioning to single-agent therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct because randomized trials and guidelines endorse a 21-day course of DAPT initiated immediately after a high-risk TIA. The CHANCE trial (2013) demonstrated that 300 mg clopidogrel load followed by 75 mg daily plus 75 mg aspirin for 21 days reduced stroke recurrence by 32% versus aspirin alone (N Engl J Med 2013;369:11–19). The POINT trial (2018) confirmed similar benefit with a 600 mg clopidogrel load then 75 mg daily plus aspirin for 90 days, with the greatest efficacy in the first 21 days (N Engl J Med 2018;379:215–225). The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418) give a Class I recommendation for DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days in minor stroke (NIHSS ≤ 3) or high-risk TIA (ABCD2 ≥ 4) to prevent early recurrence. Pathophysiologically, early DAPT interrupts platelet aggregation cascade at both cyclooxygenase (ASA) and P2Y₁₂ receptor (clopidogrel) levels, limiting microthrombus propagation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. ASA only
• Incorrect: Monotherapy reduces long-term stroke risk but is inferior for early recurrence prevention.
• Misconception: Single-agent antiplatelet is adequate in high-risk TIA.
• Differentiator: Lacks the synergistic P2Y₁₂ blockade that short-term DAPT provides.

C. Dual antiplatelet therapy
• Incorrect: Too vague—does not specify loading dose, agents, or optimal duration.
• Misconception: Any DAPT regimen suffices; duration and timing matter.
• Differentiator: Evidence supports exactly 21 days of aspirin + clopidogrel after a high-risk TIA.

D. Anticoagulation
• Incorrect: Indicated for atrial fibrillation or cardioembolic stroke, not for non-cardioembolic TIA.
• Misconception: “Clot prevention” always requires anticoagulants.
• Differentiator: Mechanism targets thrombin (warfarin/DOAC) rather than platelet aggregation.

2. Starting anticoagulation for non-cardioembolic TIA due to misunderstanding “clot” mechanism—platelet inhibitors are preferred.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines 2019: Recommend aspirin + clopidogrel for 21 days in high-risk TIA or minor stroke (Class I, Level A).
• POINT Trial Steering Committee 2018: Demonstrated that early DAPT reduces recurrent ischemia by 28% in the first 90 days, with the greatest effect in the first 21 days.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Clopidogrel is a prodrug converted by CYP2C19 to an active metabolite that irreversibly blocks the P2Y₁₂ ADP receptor on platelets, preventing aggregation. Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1, reducing thromboxane A₂ synthesis. The loading dose of clopidogrel (300–600 mg) achieves platelet inhibition within 2 hours; maintenance dosing (75 mg daily) sustains effect. Combined therapy targets two pathways of platelet activation, offering additive protection during the vulnerable post-TIA period.

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.
High-risk TIA management is frequently tested as a vignette requiring selection of the proper timing, agents, and duration of antiplatelet therapy. The exam often stresses trial data (CHANCE, POINT) and AHA/ASA guideline recommendations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] - Visual pathways: fibers from each retina cross at the optic chiasm and project via optic tracts into the lateral geniculate nucleus, then through optic radiations to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobes.
• Homonymous field defects: lesions posterior to the chiasm cause same-sided visual field losses in both eyes; “congruent” when defect shapes in both eyes closely match (occipital lobe) versus “incongruent” when they differ (optic tract or radiations).
• Macular sparing: the central 5°–10° of vision often preserved in occipital strokes due to dual blood supply from the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and collateral MCA branches.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct. In a left occipital lobe infarct, patients classically develop a right homonymous hemianopia that is highly congruent (tightly aligned defects) because fibers are compacted in the cortex. Macular sparing occurs in approximately 60–70% of PCA territory infarctions due to collateral flow from distal middle cerebral artery branches supplying the occipital pole (Biousse et al., Neurology 2003). The 2018 AHA/ASA Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines recommend prompt neuroimaging with diffusion-weighted MRI to confirm PCA infarction and awareness of cortical visual deficits (Level A evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Incongruent homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
• Why incorrect: Incongruency implies misalignment of field defects between eyes, characteristic of lesions in the optic tract or parietal optic radiations, not the occipital cortex.
• Misconception: Believing macular sparing can occur at any posterior lesion level; in fact, incongruent defects reflect fiber dispersion before the cortex.

C. Non-macular sparing with congruent homonymous hemianopia
• Why incorrect: Lack of macular sparing would require complete PCA infarction including macular branches, which is uncommon. Most occipital cortical lesions spare the macula.
• Misconception: Assuming congruency alone localizes to occipital lobe without considering vascular collateralization.

D. Non-macular sparing with incongruent homonymous hemianopia
• Why incorrect: Combines features typical of optic radiation (incongruency) and a rare complete PCA infarct (no macular sparing). This pattern is not seen in isolated occipital lobe strokes.
• Misconception: Conflating uncommon patterns into a single lesion site.

- Always test central vision separately by asking patients to fixate and report any blur or loss near direct gaze; this assesses macular sparing.
• Automated perimetry (Humphrey) is more sensitive than confrontation for subtle congruent defects.
• A small occipital pole lesion may produce isolated quadrantanopia; bilateral lesions can cause cortical blindness.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any homonymous hemianopia with occipital lobe strokes without assessing congruency; tract lesions yield incongruent defects.
2. Assuming macular sparing is universal; extensive PCA infarcts can abolish central vision, though uncommonly.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018, updated 2019): Recommends emergent MRI-DWI for suspected posterior circulation infarcts; Class I, Level A.
• ESO–ESMINT Guidelines for Management of Posterior Circulation Stroke (2021): Endorses detailed visual field testing and early vascular imaging to detect PCA occlusion; Level B evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- The primary visual cortex along the calcarine fissure displays a retinotopic map: the macula is represented posteriorly and receives overlapping supply from PCA and MCA branches.
• As fibers converge into the cortex, defects become more congruent compared to dispersed fibers in the tract or radiations.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute PCA occlusion leads to ischemia of the occipital cortex. Collateral flow from MCA cortical branches often preserves the macular representation at the pole, producing a “macular sparing” phenomenon despite complete hemianopia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical exam: confrontation fields → note congruency and macular involvement.
2. Noncontrast head CT: exclude hemorrhage.
3. MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging: confirm occipital infarct.
4. MR/CT angiography: assess PCA patency and collateral circulation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Diffusion-weighted MRI is highly sensitive for posterior fossa and occipital infarcts; CT may miss small cortical lesions.
• FLAIR-DWI mismatch can help estimate infarct age when timing is unclear.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Postpartum seizures and headache raise concern for conditions unique to this hypercoagulable state.
• Hypercoagulability (Virchow’s triad) predisposes to cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT).
• CVT often presents with headache, seizures, focal deficits and may show a normal noncontrast CT in ~30% of cases.
• Definitive diagnosis requires venous imaging to visualize sinus occlusion.

(Word count: 69)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT venography (CTV) is the next best step after a normal noncontrast head CT when CVT is suspected. CTV has a sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 91% for detecting dural sinus thrombosis (Bush et al., Stroke 2019). The 2011 AHA/ASA CVT guidelines (Class I, Level of Evidence B) endorse either CTV or MR venography (MRV) to confirm diagnosis. MRI brain without dedicated venous sequences can miss isolated sinus thromboses in up to 20% of cases (Ferro et al., Lancet Neurol 2004). EEG localizes seizure focus but does not evaluate vascular patency. Lumbar puncture may exacerbate intracranial hypertension and is contraindicated until raised pressure is ruled out.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI brain
– Incorrect because standard MRI sequences (T1/T2/FLAIR) without MRV do not reliably visualize venous sinuses. Common misconception: “Any MRI rules out CVT.”
C. EEG
– Incorrect as it assesses cortical electrical activity, not vascular pathology. Misconception: “Seizure → EEG first.”
D. Lumbar puncture
– Incorrect due to risk of herniation if intracranial pressure elevated from venous outflow obstruction. Misconception: “Normal CT → LP to rule out meningitis.”

• In postpartum women with new-onset headache/seizure, always consider CVT alongside eclampsia.
• A normal noncontrast CT does not exclude CVT; proceed with venous imaging.
• Initiate anticoagulation promptly once CVT is confirmed, even if hemorrhagic.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming MRI brain without MRV rules out CVT.
2. Performing lumbar puncture before excluding intracranial hypertension in suspected CVT.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2011 Guidelines on Cerebral Venous Thrombosis: “CT venography or MR venography is recommended to confirm CVT in suspected cases” (Class I, LOE B).
2. European Stroke Organization 2017 Update: “In cases where MRI is available, MRV is equivalent to CTV; choose modality based on local availability and patient factors” (Grade A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis most commonly affects the superior sagittal sinus and transverse sinuses, leading to impaired cortical venous drainage, raised intracranial pressure, and venous infarction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Postpartum hypercoagulability (elevated fibrinogen, decreased protein S) plus endothelial injury and stasis predispose to dural sinus thrombosis, causing venous congestion, blood–brain barrier disruption, and seizure.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage/infarct
2. If CT is normal or equivocal and CVT suspected → CTV or MRV
3. Confirm diagnosis → start low-molecular-weight heparin
4. Monitor and transition to oral anticoagulation

Neuroimaging Pearls

• “Empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CT: triangular filling defect in superior sagittal sinus.
• “Cord sign” on noncontrast CT: hyperdense thrombus in cortical vein.
• CTV rapidly demonstrates absent flow in affected sinus.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Acute CVT treatment: low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) even with hemorrhagic infarction, followed by warfarin for 3–12 months; emerging data support direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) in select patients.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Malignant middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction refers to large hemispheric strokes producing cytotoxic edema, raised intracranial pressure (ICP), and risk of transtentorial herniation. Key concepts:
1. MCA anatomy: supplies lateral frontal, temporal, parietal lobes; proximal occlusion → large territory infarct and severe edema.
2. Ischemic cascade: energy failure → ion pump dysfunction → intracellular water shift → malignant edema peaks 2–5 days post‐stroke.
3. ICP and herniation physiology: uncontrolled swelling leads to midline shift, Cushing’s triad, brainstem compression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 hours in malignant MCA infarction reduces mortality from ~80% to ~30–40% and increases survival with moderate disability (mRS ≤4). Three European RCTs (DECIMAL, DESTINY, HAMLET) and a pooled analysis (Vahedi et al., 2007) demonstrated significant mortality benefit (Level A evidence, Class I recommendation in AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines). Early surgery prevents ICP rise, halts herniation, and improves functional outcome.
Intravenous tPA is contraindicated after the hyperacute window or in massive established infarcts due to hemorrhagic risk. Hyperventilation transiently lowers ICP but may reduce cerebral perfusion. Stroke unit care alone cannot reverse advanced edema.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Stroke admission
• Incorrect because supportive care does not halt rapidly progressing edema or herniation.
• Misconception: routine stroke unit monitoring suffices in malignant edema.
• Differs from hemicraniectomy, which physically relieves mass effect.

C. Hyperventilation
• Temporizing measure only: lowers PaCO₂, induces cerebral vasoconstriction, but risks ischemia and rebound ICP rise.
• Common error: overestimating its duration of effect.
• Does not address underlying cytotoxic swelling.

D. Intravenous thrombolysis
• Time‐limited (≤4.5 h) and increases hemorrhage risk in large established infarcts.
• Misconception: tPA reduces mass effect in late-presenting MCA strokes.
• Does not reverse cytotoxic edema once infarct matured.

• Perform decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 h of symptom onset for maximal benefit.
• Ideal candidates: age ≤60, NIHSS ≥15, >50% MCA territory involvement.
• Post‐op: aggressive ICP control, early rehabilitation improves outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing hyperventilation alone prevents herniation; its benefit is short-lived and can worsen ischemia.
2. Administering tPA in large established infarcts due to misunderstanding of time window and hemorrhage risk.

• AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines 2018: Class I, Level A—decompressive hemicraniectomy recommended for malignant MCA infarction patients 18–60 yrs within 48 h.
• DESTINY II Trial (2015): extended benefit demonstrated in patients >60 yrs for mortality reduction, though survivors often have moderate–severe disability.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MCA supplies lateral neocortex and deep structures (internal capsule). Large proximal occlusions cause extensive cortical and subcortical infarction, leading to hemispheric edema that compresses basal cisterns and shifts midline structures.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemia prompts glutamate‐mediated excitotoxicity, sodium–potassium pump failure, intracellular water influx, and cytotoxic edema. Swollen hemisphere exerts mass effect, raising ICP and risking uncal herniation with brainstem compression.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT: hypodensity in >50% MCA territory, effacement of sulci, midline shift >5 mm. MRI DWI confirms infarct extent. Crescendoc edema peaks days 2–5.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Watershed (border-zone) infarctions occur at the junctions between major cerebral artery territories (e.g., ACA–MCA or MCA–PCA) and are most often due to systemic hypoperfusion or severe proximal arterial stenosis. Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) rapidly detects cytotoxic edema in acute ischemia. Once a watershed pattern is identified, the next step is to assess vascular anatomy for stenosis or occlusion that predisposes to hypoperfusion. CT angiography (CTA) provides noninvasive, high-resolution evaluation of extracranial and intracranial vessels, guiding management of hemodynamic stroke risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend prompt vascular imaging (CTA or MRA) in patients with infarcts at risk for recurrent events (Class I, Level B-R). CTA identifies symptomatic carotid or intracranial stenosis amenable to endarterectomy or stenting. A watershed pattern implies hemodynamic compromise rather than embolic occlusion alone; thus establishing large-vessel status is essential before instituting blood pressure targets or considering revascularization. Randomized trials (e.g., WASID) underscore that severe intracranial stenosis (>70%) confers high recurrence risk, warranting targeted intervention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Initiate intravenous thrombolysis
• Incorrect because thrombolysis is indicated within a time window (<4.5 h) for occlusive stroke, not for subacute watershed infarcts already visualized on DWI.
• Misconception: any DWI-confirmed stroke mandates tPA—time window and hemorrhage risk must be assessed first.

C. Perform lumbar puncture
• Incorrect: LP is unrelated; no suspicion of infection, hemorrhage ruled out by imaging, and LP may risk herniation in infarcted tissue.
• Misconception: LP is a routine next step in any neurologic deficit.

D. Start high-dose corticosteroids
• Incorrect: steroids have no role in ischemic stroke management and may worsen glycemic control and immunosuppression.
• Misconception: steroids benefit all acute neurologic lesions (confuses with demyelinating or vasculitic processes).

Clinical Pearls

- Border-zone infarcts are hallmark of hemodynamic stroke; always evaluate carotid and intracranial circulation.
• DWI is positive within minutes of ischemia; follow-up with CTA/MRA clarifies etiology and guides revascularization.
• Symptomatic ≥70% carotid stenosis in watershed infarction patients may benefit from endarterectomy (NASCET criteria).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all acute MRI-confirmed infarcts with automatic tPA eligibility, without regard to time window or hemorrhage risk.
2. Assuming lumbar puncture is necessary for first-line evaluation of any new focal neurologic deficit.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines: “Noninvasive vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) is recommended in all acute ischemic stroke patients to detect large-vessel occlusion or stenosis” (Class I, Level B-R).
• ESO 2021 Guidelines: “CTA-based identification of large-vessel stenosis in watershed infarcts guides selection for carotid interventions; severe symptomatic stenosis (>70%) should be referred for endarterectomy” (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Watershed zones lie between the distal territories of the ACA and MCA (anterior watershed) or MCA and PCA (posterior watershed). These zones receive the lowest perfusion pressure and are first affected in systemic hypotension or proximal stenosis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Border-zone infarcts result from sustained cerebral hypoperfusion when autoregulatory capacity is overwhelmed, often in the presence of high-grade carotid or intracranial arterial stenosis, leading to cytotoxic edema detectable on DWI.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. MRI with DWI to confirm acute ischemia.
3. CTA of head and neck to identify stenosis/occlusion.
4. Tailor blood pressure targets and consider revascularization if significant large-vessel disease identified.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI hyperintensity with corresponding ADC hypointensity confirms acute cytotoxic edema.
• CTA reveals vessel caliber, collateral status, and high-grade stenoses critical to management planning.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Visual signals travel: retina → optic nerves → chiasm → optic tracts → lateral geniculate nuclei → optic radiations → primary visual cortex.
• Lesions posterior to the optic chiasm cause contralateral visual field loss in both eyes (homonymous defects).
• Acute ischemic strokes frequently involve middle cerebral artery (MCA) or posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territories, affecting optic radiations or occipital cortex.
• Recognizing homonymous hemianopia localizes the lesion to retrochiasmal pathways, guiding emergent neuroimaging and reperfusion therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Homonymous hemianopia occurs in up to 15–20% of acute ischemic strokes, most often with PCA infarcts affecting the occipital cortex (Kalra et al., Stroke 2018). AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend bedside confrontation visual field testing as part of the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) (Class I, Level of Evidence B). MRI diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) confirms infarction in contralateral visual pathways. Restoration of perfusion via intravenous thrombolysis or endovascular thrombectomy can salvage peri-infarct tissue and improve visual outcomes when performed early (Albers et al., NEJM 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Bitemporal hemianopia
• Due to chiasmal compression (e.g., pituitary macroadenoma); spares homonymous fields.
B. Homonymous hemianopia (correct)
• Retrochiasmal lesion yields same‐side defect; common in stroke.
C. Central scotoma
• Loss of central vision; arises from macular or optic nerve pathology (optic neuritis, maculopathy), not cortical ischemia.
D. Quadrantanopia
• One‐quarter field defect from partial optic radiation lesions (Meyer’s loop or parietal branch). Less frequent than complete hemianopia in acute stroke.

Clinical Pearls

• Bedside confrontation testing quickly detects homonymous defects; confirm with automated perimetry.
• PCA infarcts may spare macular vision ("macular sparing") due to dual blood supply.
• Early reperfusion (≤4.5 h for tPA, ≤24 h for thrombectomy in select patients) can improve both motor and visual outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking bitemporal hemianopia for stroke—chiasmal lesions, not vascular events.
2. Overattributing any visual loss in stroke to cortical causes; central scotoma suggests optic nerve or retinal disease.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines: NIHSS visual field assessment required; Class I, LOE B.
• ESO 2021 (European Stroke Organisation): Endovascular thrombectomy improves visual field preservation when PCA involvement extends into occipital lobe; Level II evidence.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Atrial fibrillation (AF) causes stasis in the left atrium and left atrial appendage, promoting thrombus formation that can embolize to the cerebral circulation. Nonvalvular AF excludes mechanical valves or moderate-severe mitral stenosis. Secondary prevention of cardioembolic stroke relies on systemic anticoagulation to inhibit the coagulation cascade.
Key concepts:
• Thrombogenesis in AF involves activation of the intrinsic and common pathways culminating in factor Xa–mediated conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.
• Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) targeting factor Xa or thrombin provide predictable anticoagulation without routine monitoring.
• Antiplatelet agents (aspirin, clopidogrel) inadequately prevent cardioembolic stroke compared with anticoagulants.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban) directly inhibit factor Xa, preventing thrombin generation. The 2019 AHA/ASA secondary stroke prevention guidelines and the 2021 European Stroke Organisation guidelines both recommend DOACs over warfarin for nonvalvular AF (Class I, Level A). Large randomized trials—ROCKET-AF (rivaroxaban), ARISTOTLE (apixaban), and ENGAGE AF-TIMI 48 (edoxaban)—demonstrated noninferiority or superiority to warfarin in preventing stroke/systemic embolism, with significantly lower intracranial hemorrhage rates (ARISTOTLE: 0.33% vs. 0.80% ICH rate, p<0.001). In acute ischemic stroke from AF, anticoagulation is typically initiated 4–14 days after stroke onset based on infarct size and hemorrhagic risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin
• Why incorrect: Antiplatelets do not inhibit thrombin-mediated clot formation central to cardioembolism.
• Misconception: Confusing atherosclerotic versus cardioembolic stroke prevention.
• Differentiator: Aspirin reduces platelet aggregation, not coagulation factor activity.

B. Warfarin
• Why incorrect: Although effective, warfarin requires INR monitoring, has variable pharmacokinetics, and higher intracranial hemorrhage risk compared to DOACs.
• Misconception: Belief that warfarin remains first-line for all AF.
• Differentiator: DOACs have fewer dietary/drug interactions and reduced ICH.

D. Clopidogrel
• Why incorrect: Similar to aspirin, clopidogrel targets P2Y12 receptors on platelets, ineffective for preventing clot formation in high-flow stasis conditions of AF.
• Misconception: Using dual antiplatelet therapy for stroke prevention in AF.
• Differentiator: No direct effect on factor Xa or thrombin.

• Initiate anticoagulation 4–14 days post-stroke; delay longer for large infarcts.

1. Starting aspirin instead of anticoagulation in AF-related stroke.
2. Presuming warfarin is superior in all stroke patients with AF, ignoring DOAC benefits.

1. AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention (2019): Recommends DOACs over warfarin for nonvalvular AF (Class I, Level A).
2. European Stroke Organisation Guideline (2021): Endorses factor Xa inhibitors as first-line in nonvalvular AF to reduce stroke and ICH risk.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) management balances preventing secondary complications (hematoma expansion, edema) and avoiding treatment-related risks.
• VTE risk rises soon after ICH due to immobility and inflammation; early pharmacologic prophylaxis reduces DVT/PE without increasing hematoma growth once the bleed is stable.
• Surgical interventions (EVD, evacuation) are reserved for large hemorrhages, significant mass effect, hydrocephalus, or cerebellar locations.
• Blood pressure control is crucial if hypertensive; with normotension, aggressive lowering may compromise cerebral perfusion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Prophylactic low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) initiated 24–48 hours after ICH onset is supported by the 2022 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Class I, Level B-R). The landmark PREVENT trial and subsequent meta-analyses show no increase in hematoma expansion when heparin is started after CT stability is confirmed. In contrast, EVD is indicated only for intraventricular hemorrhage with hydrocephalus; surgical evacuation benefits superficial lobar bleeds >30 mL but not small deep hemorrhages; strict BP control applies only when systolic >180 mm Hg (ICH ATACH-II criteria).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. External ventricular drain (EVD) placement
– Incorrect: No intraventricular extension or hydrocephalus reported.
– Misconception: Belief that all thalamic bleeds cause hydrocephalus.
– Differentiator: EVD only for obstructive hydrocephalus.

C. Immediate surgical evacuation
– Incorrect: Small deep hemorrhages (<10 mL) in thalamus lack surgical benefit.
– Misconception: All ICH require evacuation.
– Differentiator: Evacuation reserved for superficial lobar bleeds >30 mL or deteriorating neurologic status.

D. Strict blood pressure control
– Incorrect: Patient is normotensive; aggressive lowering risks ischemia.
– Misconception: “Lower is always better” in ICH.
– Differentiator: Target SBP <140 mm Hg only if admission SBP >180 mm Hg per AHA/ASA.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Delaying all pharmacologic prophylaxis for >7 days due to fear of expansion—increases VTE risk.
2. Assuming any thalamic bleed causes hydrocephalus and warrants EVD—requires radiographic/intracranial pressure evidence.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2022 ICH Guideline: Recommend starting prophylactic LMWH 24–48 h after ICH onset once hematoma stability confirmed (Class I, Level B-R).
• European Stroke Organisation 2021: Supports combined mechanical and low-dose pharmacologic VTE prophylaxis in ICH patients at low bleeding risk (Level A).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Intracerebral hemorrhage causes direct parenchymal injury and secondary damage via hematoma expansion. Elevated systemic blood pressure increases transmural pressure across cerebral vessels, promoting further bleeding. According to the Monro–Kellie doctrine, intracranial volume is fixed; reducing arterial pressure limits hematoma growth while maintaining cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP = mean arterial pressure − intracranial pressure). In ICH, autoregulatory mechanisms are often impaired in perihematomal tissue, so cerebral blood flow becomes pressure‐dependent. The goal is a rapid, controlled reduction of systolic BP to about 140 mm Hg to minimize expansion without inducing ischemia in vulnerable areas.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The AHA/ASA 2015 Guidelines for Management of Spontaneous ICH (Class I, Level A) recommend lowering systolic BP to 140 mm Hg in patients presenting with initial SBP 150–220 mm Hg, based on INTERACT2 (N Engl J Med 2013) which showed a shift toward better functional outcomes. ATACH-II (N Engl J Med 2016) compared intensive (<140 mm Hg) versus standard (<180 mm Hg) SBP targets; intensive lowering did not increase adverse events significantly and remains the recommended target in international guidelines. Diastolic goals are less well defined; 90 mm Hg is a practical upper limit when paired with SBP 140 mm Hg.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. 160/90
– Too permissive: allows ongoing hematoma expansion.
– Reflects older acute stroke thresholds (SBP <160) but fails to optimize functional outcome in ICH.
– Does not align with Class I guideline recommendation for SBP 140 mm Hg.

C. 180/105
– Matches general ischemic stroke or hypertensive emergency protocols but is excessive in ICH.
– Associated with higher rates of hematoma growth and worse prognosis.
– Represents a misunderstanding of ICH-specific BP targets versus ischemic stroke.

D. 120/80
– Overly aggressive lowering risks cerebral hypoperfusion and ischemia, especially with impaired autoregulation.
– Below the lower limit of recommended SBP (130–150 mm Hg) range in trials.
– Misconception: “lower is always better” without regard to CPP.

1. Initiate IV nicardipine or labetalol infusion for rapid, titratable SBP control.
2. Monitor neurological status and CPP; avoid SBP fluctuations >20 mm Hg.
3. Distinguish BP targets: ischemic stroke (often permissive hypertension) versus ICH (aggressive lowering).

- Confusing BP goals in ischemic stroke (allow SBP ≤220 mm Hg) with ICH (target ≥140 mm Hg).
• Focusing on diastolic rather than systolic BP as the primary driver of hematoma expansion.
• Overzealously lowering SBP below 120 mm Hg, precipitating perihematomal ischemia.

• AHA/ASA Guidelines for ICH Management, 2015 (Class I, Level A): Rapid SBP lowering to 140 mm Hg in patients with admission SBP 150–220 mm Hg.
• INTERACT2 Trial, 2013 (Level I evidence): SBP target <140 mm Hg showed improved functional outcomes (ordinal analysis p=0.04).
• ATACH-II Trial, 2016 (Level I evidence): Intensive SBP lowering (<140 mm Hg) vs standard (<180 mm Hg) did not increase adverse events; supports guideline target.

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by transient, segmental narrowing of cerebral arteries leading to ischemic or hemorrhagic complications.
1. Pathophysiology: Dysregulated cerebrovascular tone—often endothelial dysfunction—provokes multifocal arterial constriction.
2. Triggers: Physical exertion, emotional stress, vasoactive substances, or minor trauma can precipitate RCVS, especially in migraineurs.
3. Clinical features: Thunderclap headaches are classic; focal deficits (e.g., visual field cuts) may appear hours to days later due to ischemia in posterior circulation territories (occipital lobes).

(Word count: 106)

Evidence-Based Analysis

RCVS is confirmed by angiographic “string‐of‐beads” appearance and reversibility within 12 weeks (Calabrese et al., Neurology 2007). In this patient:
• Trigger: Intense exertion (tennis) and minor trauma with transient hypertension.
• Delayed deficit: Hemianopia arises 2 hours after normal CT—typical of ischemic events secondary to vasoconstriction rather than immediate hemorrhage or dissection.
• Migraine history: Migraineurs have up to a 20% higher risk of RCVS (Singhal et al., Stroke 2016).
Current AHA guidelines (2021) recommend noninvasive vascular imaging (MRA) initially, reserving catheter angiography for equivocal cases (Class IIa, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Vertebral dissection
• Incorrect: Dissection often causes neck pain, immediate focal signs (e.g., lateral medullary syndrome), and visible vessel wall defect on CTA.
• Misconception: All trauma-related strokes stem from dissection.
• Differentiation: No cervical pain or hyperintense vessel wall on imaging; delayed isolated hemianopia is atypical.

C. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)
• Incorrect: PRES presents with headache, seizures, altered mental status, and bilateral parieto-occipital vasogenic edema on MRI/FLAIR.
• Misconception: Acute hypertension in trauma always equals PRES.
• Differentiation: CT was normal; PRES shows diffuse edema rather than focal arterial narrowing.

D. Internal carotid artery (ICA) stenosis
• Incorrect: Typically chronic atherosclerosis in older patients causing TIA or watershed infarcts, not acute hemianopia post-trauma.
• Misconception: Any visual field cut equals carotid pathology.
• Differentiation: No bruit, no ulcerated plaque on ultrasound; ICA stenosis rarely causes isolated homonymous hemianopia.

• Migraine history is a strong predisposing factor; differentiate from primary migraine aura by the severity and sudden onset.
• “String-of-beads” on angiography is pathognomonic; follow-up imaging at 6–12 weeks should show resolution.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any acute visual field defect post-trauma with carotid or vertebral dissection without angiography.
2. Misdiagnosing PRES when only focal deficits occur; PRES is a diffuse vasogenic edema syndrome with seizures or encephalopathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on RCVS (2021): Recommends early noninvasive vascular imaging (MRA/CTA) for suspected RCVS (Class IIa, Level B).
• International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): Classifies RCVS under headache disorders, emphasizing thunderclap onset and reversible angiographic changes.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Left homonymous hemianopia localizes to the right occipital cortex (PCA territory). RCVS‐induced vasoconstriction in the distal PCA leads to focal ischemia here.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Sympathetic overactivity or endothelial dysfunction → segmental cerebral arterial constriction → transient ischemia or hemorrhage. Exposure to triggers (e.g., exertion, trauma) precipitates acute vasospasm.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. MRI brain with DWI/FLAIR to detect early ischemia or edema.
3. MRA/CTA to identify multifocal cerebral vasoconstriction.
4. Consider digital subtraction angiography if noninvasive imaging is inconclusive.
5. Follow-up imaging at 6–12 weeks to confirm reversibility.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Early CT is often normal; use MRI/MRA to detect both parenchymal changes and vascular narrowing.
• DSA remains gold standard for detailing segmental vasoconstriction (“string-of-beads”).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First‐line: Oral nimodipine or verapamil to alleviate vasospasm (off‐label). Avoid sympathomimetics. Supportive blood pressure control without precipitous drops.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Warfarin inhibits vitamin K–dependent γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, leading to coagulopathy. In ICH, rapid INR normalization is critical to prevent hematoma expansion.
• Prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) provides immediate factor replacement (II, VII, IX, X).
• Intravenous vitamin K is required to sustain synthesis of functional clotting factors by the liver.
• CT imaging confirms hemorrhage; INR guides reversal strategy.
Understanding these principles underpins safe, effective management of warfarin-associated ICH. (≈100 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vitamin K is the only agent that restores endogenous synthesis of clotting factors, ensuring durable INR correction after PCC’s transient effect. The 2015 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines (Class I, LOE B) and 2016 Neurocritical Care Society guidelines (Grade 1B) recommend IV vitamin K (5–10 mg) concurrently with PCC for warfarin reversal. Sarode et al. (NEJM 2013) demonstrated faster INR normalization and fewer volume‐related complications with 4‐factor PCC + vitamin K versus FFP. Without vitamin K, PCC’s half‐life (8–24 hours) leads to rebound coagulopathy as factors are consumed.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP)
– Incorrect because PCC is superior: FFP requires large volumes, slower infusion, and carries risk of transfusion‐related acute lung injury.
– Misconception: FFP alone suffices for emergent reversal; in fact, it’s second‐line if PCC unavailable.

C. Platelet transfusion
– Incorrect: platelets address thrombocytopenia or antiplatelet therapy; warfarin impairs clotting factors, not platelet function.
– Misconception: any bleed mandates platelets—only indicated if platelet count <50×10^9/L or platelet dysfunction.

D. Desmopressin
– Incorrect: desmopressin raises vWF/Factor VIII, useful in von Willebrand disease or platelet dysfunction, not vitamin K antagonist reversal.
– Misconception: desmopressin reverses all coagulopathies—its role is limited to specific platelet/vWF defects.

1. Always administer IV vitamin K alongside PCC to prevent INR rebound after the exogenous factors degrade.
2. Use 4-factor PCC over FFP for faster, lower-volume warfarin reversal in ICH (Class I recommendation).
3. Avoid platelet transfusion or desmopressin in warfarin‐only coagulopathy; they address platelet/vWF defects.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Forgetting vitamin K after PCC leads to transient correction and risk of delayed hematoma expansion.
2. Choosing FFP over PCC due to hospital tradition delays reversal and increases fluid overload risk.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2015 ICH Guidelines (Class I, LOE B): Recommend 4-factor PCC + IV vitamin K for rapid warfarin reversal.
• Neurocritical Care Society 2016 (Grade 1B): Endorse IV vitamin K (5–10 mg) with PCC; FFP only if PCC unavailable.
• Sarode et al., NEJM 2013: 4-factor PCC achieved INR <1.4 in 70% within 30 min vs. 9% with FFP (p<0.001).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Warfarin’s inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase prevents γ-carboxylation of clotting factors, reducing their coagulant function. Elevated INR reflects decreased factor activity. PCC rapidly supplies functional factors, but without vitamin K, endogenous synthesis remains impaired, leading to factor depletion as PCC factors decay.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Vitamin K: 5–10 mg IV infusion over 30 min to avoid anaphylactoid reactions; recheck INR at 6 h.
• 4-factor PCC dosing based on INR and weight (e.g., 25–50 IU/kg).
• FFP: 10–20 mL/kg if PCC unavailable; slow infusion risks volume overload.
• Platelets and desmopressin have no role in isolated warfarin reversal.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Sneddon disease (syndrome) is a noninflammatory thrombotic vasculopathy affecting small‐ and medium‐sized arteries in skin and brain, classically presenting with livedo reticularis and recurrent ischemic strokes.
• Livedo reticularis: a lace‐like, violaceous skin mottling due to dermal arteriolar occlusion and capillary dilation.
• Cerebrovascular involvement: multiple cortical infarcts, often in watershed areas, with normal conventional angiography early on.
• Differential diagnosis hinges on distinguishing thrombotic noninflammatory arteriopathy (Sneddon) from systemic vasculitis (e.g., polyarteritis nodosa), autoimmune coagulopathies (APS, SLE), and embolic sources.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sneddon disease is defined by the coexistence of persistent livedo reticularis and ischemic strokes without evidence of systemic inflammatory vasculitis or cardioembolism. Histopathology reveals intimal hyperplasia, luminal thrombosis, and minimal inflammatory infiltrate in small/medium dermal and leptomeningeal vessels (Bourgeois et al., J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2020).
A systematic review (Caetano et al., Stroke 2022) showed that 80% of patients with livedo and stroke fulfilling Sneddon criteria had negative inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) and normal ANCA/ANA panels, distinguishing it from PAN or SLE. Advanced vessel wall MRI may demonstrate concentric wall thickening and enhancement without vessel wall edema (class IIa, LOE C; ESO 2021 guidelines on cryptogenic stroke).
Screening for antiphospholipid antibodies is recommended (Gianni et al., J Neurol 2022), but aPL positivity alone without the livedo–stroke syndrome fits primary APS, not Sneddon.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Polyarteritis nodosa
• Why incorrect: PAN is a necrotizing medium‐vessel vasculitis with systemic features (renal microaneurysms, mononeuritis multiplex), not isolated livedo reticularis with recurrent cortical strokes.
• Misconception: conflating livedo reticularis with vasculitis rather than thrombotic arteriopathy.
• Differentiator: PAN shows elevated ESR/CRP, tissue biopsy reveals fibrinoid necrosis and inflammatory infiltrate.

C. Antiphospholipid syndrome
• Why incorrect: APS causes hypercoagulability with stroke and can produce livedo, but livedo in APS is transient and serology (lupus anticoagulant, aCL, β2‐GP1) is persistently positive.
• Misconception: equating any livedo‐stroke association with APS rather than Sneddon’s distinctive noninflammatory arteriopathy.
• Differentiator: APS often has obstetric morbidity and venous thromboses; Sneddon lacks systemic coagulopathy criteria.

D. Systemic lupus erythematosus
• Why incorrect: SLE may have livedo and stroke, but it manifests with multi‐organ autoimmunity, hypocomplementemia, positive ANA/dsDNA, and immune complex vasculitis.
• Misconception: attributing livedo reticularis in any autoimmune disease to SLE.
• Differentiator: SLE shows broad serologic profile and inflammatory markers, unlike the noninflammatory histology of Sneddon.

Clinical Pearls

- Sneddon disease should be suspected in young/middle‐aged adults with livedo reticularis and “cryptogenic” strokes refractory to standard cardioembolic work‐up.
• Skin biopsy of livedo reticularis lesions with deep dermal sampling increases diagnostic yield (>80% sensitivity).
• Vessel wall MRI shows concentric concentric enhancement without edema in Sneddon vs. vasculitis‐associated edema in PAN/SLE.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking livedo reticularis in APS for Sneddon: always confirm aPL serology and obstetric/venous thrombosis history.
2. Assuming all livedo‐stroke syndromes are inflammatory: check ESR/CRP and biopsy for inflammatory infiltrates vs. thrombotic arteriopathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines on Cryptogenic Stroke: Recommend (Class IIa, LOE C) screening for nonatherosclerotic vasculopathies (e.g., Sneddon) with skin examination and high‐resolution vessel wall imaging when livedo reticularis is present.
• EULAR 2019 Recommendations for Antiphospholipid Syndrome: In stroke patients with persistent aPL positivity, lifelong anticoagulation with warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) is advised (Grade C), underscoring the need to differentiate APS from Sneddon’s non‐inflammatory arteriopathy.
• Gianni et al., J Neurol 2022 (n=48): Found 35% of Sneddon patients had transient aPL positivity but lacked obstetric/venous thrombotic events, reinforcing that isolated livedo–stroke without full APS criteria indicates Sneddon.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Sneddon disease arises from a primary arteriopathy of dermal and cerebral vessels characterized by endothelial dysfunction, intimal hyperplasia, and in situ thrombosis without significant inflammatory cell infiltration. The precise trigger is unknown; hypotheses include genetic predisposition (e.g., PTHR1 mutations) and endothelial prothrombotic activation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: Identify persistent livedo reticularis + unexplained ischemic strokes.
2. Labs: ESR/CRP, ANA/ANCA, aPL panel, complement levels.
3. Imaging: Brain MRI for multifocal infarcts; vessel wall MRI to distinguish thrombotic arteriopathy vs. vasculitis.
4. Biopsy: Deep skin biopsy of livedo lesions—look for intimal thickening and thrombosis without vasculitis.
5. Exclude: Cardioembolic sources, atherosclerosis, systemic vasculitis, APS/SLE.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI: Multiple small cortical/subcortical infarcts, often in watershed zones.
• Vessel wall MRI: Concentric wall thickening with homogeneous enhancement; lack of mural edema distinguishes from inflammatory vasculitis.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Acute ischemic stroke workup hinges on rapid imaging to differentiate hemorrhage from infarction and to identify large‐vessel occlusion (LVO).
• Neuroanatomy: The centrum semiovale is supplied by penetrating branches of the anterior cerebral and middle cerebral arteries; hypodensity there on noncontrast CT suggests early ischemia.
• Pathophysiology: Vessel occlusion creates a core infarct and surrounding penumbra; timely recanalization preserves at‐risk tissue.
• Imaging Strategy: Noncontrast CT excludes hemorrhage; CT angiography (CTA) of head/neck is the next step to detect LVO and guide thrombolysis or thrombectomy.
(105 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTA is the optimal emergent vascular study after noncontrast CT in suspected acute ischemic stroke. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level of Evidence B-R) recommend CTA or MRA of head/neck immediately after hemorrhage exclusion to identify LVO and select patients for endovascular therapy. Goyal et al.’s meta-analysis (Lancet 2016) demonstrated that CTA‐guided selection for mechanical thrombectomy yields a number needed to treat of 2.6 for functional independence. In late windows (6–24 h), the DAWN (N Engl J Med 2018) and DEFUSE 3 (N Engl J Med 2018) trials further underscore CTA plus perfusion imaging to expand thrombectomy candidacy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI brain
• Incorrect because DWI/MRA, while sensitive, delays time to reperfusion. MRI is used when CT findings are equivocal or for subacute stroke characterization.
• Misconception: Belief that MRI must confirm infarct before vessel imaging; in hyperacute stroke, speed supersedes marginal sensitivity gains.

C. Start antiplatelet therapy
• Premature: Antiplatelet agents (e.g., aspirin) are initiated after vascular imaging and consideration of IV thrombolysis; starting without LVO assessment risks mismanagement if thrombectomy or tPA is indicated.
• Misconception: “Aspirin immediately” overlooks the priority of reperfusion strategies in LVO.

D. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
• Limited to extracranial carotid bifurcation; cannot visualize intracranial arteries or circle of Willis.
• Slower and operator‐dependent; CTA offers comprehensive, rapid head‐to‐neck evaluation.

Clinical Pearls

- In acute stroke (<24 h), always obtain emergent CTA following noncontrast CT to assess for endovascular therapy candidacy.
• Perfusion imaging (CTP or MR perfusion) refines patient selection in extended windows (6–24 h) per DAWN/DEFUSE 3.
• Carotid ultrasound is indicated later in subacute stroke to evaluate extracranial stenosis but is not a substitute for CTA in the hyperacute setting.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating MRI with first‐line acute stroke imaging, causing critical delays.
2. Initiating antiplatelet therapy before vascular imaging, potentially missing a thrombectomy window.
3. Overreliance on carotid Doppler in lieu of comprehensive CTA, risking undetected intracranial occlusions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Class I recommendation for CTA or MRA immediately after noncontrast CT to detect LVO (Level B-R).
• DAWN Trial (N Engl J Med 2018): Demonstrated benefit of EVT up to 24 h in patients with mismatch profiles on CTA/perfusion (NIHSS 6–25, infarct core <70 mL).
• DEFUSE 3 (N Engl J Med 2018): Confirmed endovascular benefit in 6–16 h window using perfusion imaging selection (Class I, Level B).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] The cerebellum’s superior surface and deep nuclei are supplied by the superior cerebellar artery (SCA). Lesions here produce ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere signs—especially limb ataxia—due to involvement of the dentate nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle. By contrast, PICA infarction (lateral medullary) yields ipsilateral facial sensory loss and Horner’s syndrome; AICA infarction often causes ipsilateral hearing loss via labyrinthine artery involvement. Recognizing these distinct syndromes allows localization to specific posterior circulation territories.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Superior cerebellar artery infarcts account for ~7% of cerebellar strokes (Schmahmann & Pandya, Brain 2018). In SCA territory strokes, the most consistent exam finding is ipsilateral appendicular ataxia, dysmetria, and dysdiadochokinesia, reflecting dentate nucleus and cerebellar hemisphere dysfunction (Siepmann et al., Neurol Clin Pract 2018). There is no interruption of descending sympathetic fibers (located in lateral medulla) to cause Horner’s syndrome. Nor is the cochlear apparatus affected—hearing loss is characteristic of AICA (Hutchinson & Schmidek, Neurosurg Clin N Am 2019). Truncal hyperalgesia is not a recognized feature of SCA infarction. Current AHA/ASA guidelines (2019) emphasize bedside localization of posterior circulation stroke syndromes to guide urgent imaging and revascularization (Class I, Level B-R).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Ipsilateral truncal hyperalgesia
• Why incorrect: Hyperalgesia implies enhanced pain perception; SCA infarcts spare spinothalamic tracts.
• Misconception: Confusing pain/temperature loss in lateral medullary (PICA) with cerebellar lesions.
• Differentiator: PICA causes analgesia (not hyperalgesia) of ipsilateral face and contralateral body.

B. Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
• Why incorrect: Horner’s arises from disruption of sympathetic fibers in lateral brainstem/upper cervical cord (PICA/Wallenberg), not SCA.
• Misconception: Attributing all cerebellar infarcts to autonomic signs.
• Differentiator: Only lateral medullary (PICA) lesions interrupt hypothalamospinal tract causing ptosis, miosis.

C. Hearing loss
• Why incorrect: Cochlear structures are supplied by the internal auditory (labyrinthine) artery branching from AICA, not SCA.
• Misconception: Generalizing brainstem infarcts to include cranial nerve VIII involvement.
• Differentiator: AICA infarcts produce labyrinthine signs—vertigo, tinnitus, sensorineural hearing loss.

Clinical Pearls

- Superior cerebellar artery strokes classically produce ipsilateral appendicular (limb) ataxia, not truncal ataxia (more midline vermian infarcts).
• Horner’s syndrome localizes to lesions interrupting the descending sympathetic pathway in the lateral medulla (Wallenberg), not the cerebellum.
• Hearing loss in a cerebellar territory stroke strongly suggests AICA involvement—prompt audiometry may aid early differentiation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing truncal versus appendicular ataxia: vermian lesions cause truncal instability, SCA lesions cause limb dysmetria.
2. Believing all posterior circulation infarcts can produce Horner’s syndrome; only lateral medullary (PICA) disrupts sympathetic outflow.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends emergent neuroimaging within 20 minutes for posterior fossa syndromes (Class I, Level B-R).
• ESO 2021 Guidelines on Mechanical Thrombectomy in Posterior Circulation: Suggest benefit of endovascular therapy in basilar artery occlusion; data for branch occlusions (e.g., SCA) remain limited (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The SCA arises just caudal to the posterior cerebral artery from the basilar artery. It courses around the midbrain to supply the superior cerebellar hemisphere, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle. Damage disrupts purkinje-to-deep-nuclei signaling, producing ipsilateral limb incoordination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify acute cerebellar signs (ataxia, dysmetria).
2. Differentiate vermian (truncal) vs hemispheric (limb) ataxia.
3. Evaluate for cranial nerve involvement (hearing, facial sensation).
4. Obtain MRI brain with DWI to localize infarct.
5. Correlate vessel territory to clinical signs (SCA vs AICA vs PICA).

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI diffusion-weighted imaging is superior to CT for detecting posterior fossa strokes. SCA infarcts appear as focal diffusion restriction in the superior cerebellar hemispheres, often sparing inferior folia.
