Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Acute ischemic stroke results from arterial occlusion leading to brain tissue hypoperfusion. Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) can lyse fibrin clots if given early, reducing infarct size. Eligibility hinges on a narrow therapeutic window (≤4.5 hours) and strict exclusion criteria to minimize hemorrhagic transformation. Key concepts:
• Neurovascular unit: ischemia causes excitotoxicity and blood–brain barrier disruption, raising hemorrhage risk.
• NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS): quantifies severity; very mild or rapidly improving deficits predict good outcome without tPA.
• Inclusion/exclusion criteria balance salvageable penumbra vs bleeding complications.

Evidence-Based Analysis

“Rapid improvement” of neurological deficits—often defined as complete or near-complete resolution before tPA infusion—is a relative exclusion per 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Class III: No Benefit; Level B-R). In the NINDS rt-PA Stroke Trial, patients with minor or rapidly improving symptoms had low baseline disability and low subsequent benefit but similar hemorrhage risk. Excluding them reduces unnecessary exposure to ICH risk without compromising outcomes. AHA/ASA explicitly lists “mild or rapidly improving stroke symptoms” among exclusion criteria. Other options either do not meet current thresholds (C, D) or are modifiable with aggressive management (A).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Blood pressure >200 mm Hg
• Why it’s incorrect: Hypertension above 185/110 mm Hg is an exclusion until corrected, but >200/110 is modifiable with IV antihypertensives.
• Misconception: Treatable elevated BP is often mistaken for an absolute contraindication.
• Differentiator: Only uncontrolled BP after treatment remains an exclusion.

C. Platelet count <150,000/mm³
• Why it’s incorrect: tPA contraindicates platelet count <100,000/mm³; values between 100,000–150,000 are acceptable.
• Misconception: Confusing exclusion threshold for spontaneous ICH risk vs procedural bleeding risk.
• Differentiator: The critical cutoff is <100 × 10^3/µL.

D. Recent major surgery within 14 days
• Why it’s incorrect: Only intracranial or spinal surgery/head trauma within 3 months is an absolute exclusion; most non‐neurosurgical procedures pose lower risk.
• Misconception: Equating all “major” surgeries with neurosurgical bleeding risk.
• Differentiator: Time window and type of surgery (intracranial vs peripheral) matter.

2. Believing all recent surgeries—regardless of type or timing—preclude tPA, when only intracranial/spinal operations within 3 months do.

2. ECASS III Trial (N Engl J Med. 2008;359:1317–29):
– Extended tPA window to 4.5 hours; reaffirmed exclusion of minor/rapidly improving deficits to minimize hemorrhagic complications.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mechanism: tPA converts plasminogen to plasmin, degrading fibrin within thrombi.
• Dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (maximum 90 mg); 10% as bolus over 1 minute, remainder over 60 minutes.
• Monitoring: Assess neurological status every 15 minutes during infusion; watch for bleeding signs and perform follow-up CT if deterioration occurs.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Intracranial atherosclerotic stenosis (ICAS) of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) is a common cause of ischemic stroke, especially in patients with diabetes and vascular risk factors. Symptomatic ICAS (>50% stenosis) leads to stroke via artery-to-artery embolism, in situ thrombosis, or hypoperfusion. Key management principles include aggressive medical therapy (antiplatelet agents, statins, blood pressure and glycemic control) versus endovascular or surgical intervention. Understanding that trials in extracranial carotid disease (e.g., NASCET) do not apply directly to intracranial vessels is critical.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medical management is preferred for symptomatic ICAS based on robust randomized trials and guideline recommendations:
• SAMMPRIS (N Engl J Med 2011): 451 patients with 70–99% ICAS randomized to aggressive medical therapy versus angioplasty + stenting showed 30-day stroke/death 5.8% vs. 14.7% (HR 0.39, p=0.002).
• VISSIT (Lancet Neurol 2015): Similar higher periprocedural risk with stenting.
• AHA/ASA 2014 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines: Class I recommendation for intensive medical therapy (dual antiplatelet for 90 days then single; high-intensity statin; BP <140/90; glycemic control). Level of Evidence A.
By contrast, endarterectomy is for extracranial carotid lesions; stenting carries high periprocedural risks; anticoagulation (warfarin) showed no benefit over aspirin in the WASID trial and increased hemorrhagic risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

- B. Endarterectomy
• Reason incorrect: Reserved for extracranial carotid stenosis >70%.
• Misconception: Applying carotid endarterectomy data (NASCET/ECST) to intracranial vessels.
• Differentiator: Surgical access and vessel anatomy make intracranial endarterectomy infeasible with high complication rates.
• C. Stenting
• Reason incorrect: High periprocedural stroke/death in SAMMPRIS (14.7%) and VISSIT (24.1%).
• Misconception: Interventional approaches always yield better revascularization outcomes.
• Differentiator: Intracranial vessel tortuosity and perforator risk zones increase complications.
• D. Anticoagulation therapy
• Reason incorrect: WASID (N Engl J Med 2005) showed warfarin no better than aspirin and more hemorrhage.
• Misconception: Extrapolating benefits of anticoagulation in cardioembolic stroke to atherosclerotic stroke.
• Differentiator: Plaque stabilization and antiplatelet effects, not anticoagulation, reduce recurrent atherothrombotic events.

• Initiate dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 90 days in symptomatic ICAS, then continue single-agent therapy.
• High-intensity statin therapy (e.g., atorvastatin 80 mg) aiming for LDL <70 mg/dL reduces recurrent stroke risk.
• Aggressive management of hypertension (target <140/90 mm Hg) and diabetes (HbA1c <7%) is essential alongside antithrombotic therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing extracranial carotid endarterectomy criteria with intracranial stenosis management, leading to inappropriate surgical referral.
2. Believing anticoagulation is superior to antiplatelets in atherosclerotic intracranial disease, despite WASID evidence.
3. Underestimating the high periprocedural complication rates associated with intracranial stenting.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines (2014): Class I, LOE A for aggressive medical management over endovascular therapy in symptomatic ICAS.
2. SAMMPRIS Trial (NEJM 2011): First-line medical therapy (dual antiplatelet + statin + risk factor control) superior to stenting for 70–99% ICAS (Level of Evidence: I).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] • Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) morphology on CT: homogeneous hyperdensity vs. heterogeneous with layering.
• Fluid–fluid levels (“hematocrit effect”): layering of red cells below plasma due to impaired clot formation.
• Warfarin anticoagulation effects: vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibition → reduced factors II, VII, IX, X → coagulopathy predisposes to noncohesive bleed with sedimentation.

(Word count: 69)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Fluid–fluid levels on noncontrast CT are highly specific (>90%) for anticoagulation‐related hemorrhage (Delgado Almandoz et al., AJNR 2010). In coagulopathic bleeding, inadequate thrombin generation prevents solid clot formation; red cells settle under gravity, creating a hyperdense layer over a hypodense plasma layer. The 2022 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines recommend rapid reversal of VKA-associated ICH with four-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) and intravenous vitamin K (Class I, Level A). Early reversal (<1 hour) reduces hematoma expansion and improves functional outcome (Wilson et al., Stroke 2019).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hypertensive hemorrhage
– Incorrect: Typically deep basal ganglia/thalamic bleed without fluid levels; clot forms rapidly due to normal coagulation.
– Misconception: All spontaneous ICH in elderly hypertensives show layering.
– Differentiator: Homogeneous hyperdense appearance, no sedimentation.

C. Arteriovenous malformation rupture
– Incorrect: Presents with heterogeneous hyperdensity only if long-standing bleed; angiography shows nidus.
– Misconception: AVM bleeds always show mixed densities.
– Differentiator: Contrast angiography evidence, no classic fluid–fluid levels.

D. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy
– Incorrect: Lobar hemorrhages in elderly with microbleeds on MRI; coagulation normal, clot solidifies.
– Misconception: CAA bleeds layer on CT like coagulopathy.
– Differentiator: Superficial cortical bleed distribution, positive Congo red pathology.

• Students often attribute any mixed-density hemorrhage to an AVM rather than checking anticoagulation status.
• Belief that CAA bleeds always have layering; in reality, CAA bleeds clot normally, appearing uniformly hyperdense.

1. AHA/ASA 2022 ICH Guideline: Class I recommendation for rapid VKA reversal with PCC + IV vitamin K (Level A).

• Fluid–fluid levels (“hematocrit effect”) are best seen on noncontrast CT within hours of bleed onset.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Warfarin reversal: four-factor PCC (25–50 IU/kg) + 10 mg IV vitamin K.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Ischemic strokes are classified by etiology (cardioembolic vs. atherothrombotic) and severity (NIHSS). An NIHSS score ≤3 designates a non-disabling (minor) stroke. In atherothrombotic strokes, platelet aggregation on a ruptured plaque drives early recurrence risk. Early initiation of antiplatelet therapy (within 24–48 hours) significantly lowers recurrence. Recognizing stroke severity via NIHSS informs whether to choose monotherapy versus short-term dual therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1, reducing thromboxane A2–mediated platelet aggregation. The AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend starting 160–325 mg aspirin within 24–48 hours of non-cardioembolic ischemic stroke onset, followed by 75–100 mg daily. The International Stroke Trial (IST) and CAST demonstrated ~15–20% reduction in recurrent events with early aspirin. While CHANCE (2013) and POINT (2018) support 21-day dual antiplatelet therapy for minor stroke/TIA (NIHSS ≤3), aspirin monotherapy remains foundational, particularly if bleeding risk is elevated or dual therapy contraindicated. Clopidogrel monotherapy is reserved for true aspirin allergy (CAPRIE trial). Anticoagulants (warfarin, factor Xa inhibitors) are indicated only when a clear cardioembolic source (e.g., atrial fibrillation) is identified.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Warfarin
• Incorrect: A vitamin K antagonist indicated for cardioembolic stroke prevention (e.g., AF), not non-cardioembolic minor stroke.
• Misconception: “All strokes require anticoagulation.”
• Differentiator: Benefits require cardioembolic etiology and INR monitoring; no benefit in atherothrombotic stroke.

C. Factor X inhibitor
• Incorrect: Direct oral anticoagulants (e.g., rivaroxaban) are approved for non-valvular AF and venous thromboembolism, not for acute non-cardioembolic stroke.
• Misconception: “Newer anticoagulants supersede antiplatelets in all ischemic stroke subtypes.”
• Differentiator: Lack of indication without cardioembolic source; increased hemorrhage risk.

D. Clopidogrel
• Incorrect: A P2Y12-inhibitor used as monotherapy only when aspirin is contraindicated; evidence for acute monotherapy is less robust than aspirin.
• Misconception: “Any single antiplatelet is equivalent for initial therapy.”
• Differentiator: Clopidogrel loading (300 mg) and maintenance (75 mg) are less validated than aspirin in the acute phase.

• Prescribing anticoagulation (warfarin/DOAC) without confirming cardioembolic source.
• Equating clopidogrel monotherapy with aspirin’s evidence base in the acute setting.
• Delaying aspirin beyond 48 hours, missing the window for maximum benefit.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: First-line—aspirin 160–325 mg within 24–48 h (Class I, Level A).
• CHANCE Trial (NEJM 2013): Aspirin + clopidogrel reduced 90-day stroke risk in minor stroke/TIA (OR 0.68; 95% CI 0.57–0.81).
• POINT Trial (NEJM 2018): Similar benefit in Western cohorts but higher major hemorrhage; recommends ≤21 days of dual therapy (Grade 2B).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Aspirin: IR COX-1 inhibitor; loading 160–325 mg, then 75–100 mg daily.
• Clopidogrel: Prodrug; loading 300 mg, then 75 mg daily.
• Warfarin: Dose-adjusted to INR 2.0–3.0; not indicated absent cardioembolic source.
• FXa inhibitors: Rivaroxaban 20 mg qd; apixaban 5 mg bid; for AF only.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Ischemic strokes are categorized by TOAST criteria into large-artery atherosclerosis, cardioembolism, small-vessel occlusion, other determined, and undetermined (cryptogenic). Large-artery atherosclerosis typically requires ≥50% intracranial or ≥70% extracranial stenosis to produce ischemia by hemodynamic compromise or in situ thrombosis. However, non‐stenotic but unstable plaques can rupture and send distal emboli. Cardioembolic sources (e.g., atrial fibrillation, low ejection fraction <35%) are excluded here. Hypoperfusion requires critical stenosis or systemic hypotension. Recognizing artery‐to‐artery embolism from non‐stenotic atherosclerotic plaque is essential in cryptogenic stroke evaluation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Artery‐to‐artery embolism (“embolic” mechanism) is the most likely cause when imaging shows atherosclerotic plaques without critical stenosis. Contemporary studies (Amarenco et al., Lancet Neurol 2020) demonstrate that plaques with ulceration or intraplaque hemorrhage on MRI can shed microemboli despite <50% luminal narrowing. The 2018 AHA/ASA “Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke” guidelines (Class I, Level B‐R) endorse transcranial Doppler microembolic signal monitoring in suspected plaque embolism. In situ thrombosis is generally superimposed on high‐grade stenosis (>70%). Hypoperfusion requires collateral failure in severe stenosis or systemic hypotension, neither of which is present. Thus, embolism from non‐stenotic plaque best explains her infarct.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hypoperfusion
• Incorrect: Requires critical stenosis or systemic hypotension (e.g., ≥70% carotid stenosis).
• Misconception: Equating any atherosclerosis with low‐flow stroke.
• Differentiation: No significant luminal narrowing or hemodynamic compromise on vessel imaging.

C. Vessel stenosis
• Incorrect: Would imply direct ischemia from luminal narrowing.
• Misconception: All atherosclerotic disease produces flow‐limiting stenosis.
• Differentiation: Imaging showed plaque without critical stenosis.

D. Thrombosis
• Incorrect: In situ thrombosis forms on ulcerated plaque in severe stenosis, not on stable non‐stenotic plaques.
• Misconception: Any clot in an artery equals local thrombosis.
• Differentiation: Thrombosis is associated with high‐grade stenosis and local flow patterns, which are absent here.

- Symptomatic non‐stenotic carotid plaques (SyNC) can cause up to 15% of cryptogenic strokes; high‐resolution MRI identifies vulnerable features.
• Transcranial Doppler microembolic signal monitoring has Class IIa support (AHA/ASA 2018) for detecting ongoing plaque embolization.
• Holter monitoring for ≥24–72 hours is more sensitive for intermittent atrial fibrillation than an 8-hour study.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any carotid atherosclerosis automatically implies hemodynamic hypoperfusion.
2. Equating stroke due to plaque with local thrombosis rather than embolization, leading to misdirected treatment (e.g., anticoagulation vs antiplatelet).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines: Recommend antiplatelet therapy and high‐intensity statin for stroke due to non‐stenotic plaque (Class I, Level B‐R).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines: Endorse high‐resolution vessel wall MRI to characterize plaque vulnerability in cryptogenic stroke (Level B evidence).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. CTA/MRA of head and neck to assess stenosis and plaque morphology.
3. Carotid duplex ultrasound if CTA equivocal.
4. High‐resolution vessel wall MRI for plaque characterization.
5. Echocardiography + extended Holter (24–72 h) to rule out cardioembolism.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Intraplaque hemorrhage on T1‐weighted MRI appears hyperintense and indicates high risk for embolization.
• Transcranial Doppler may detect embolic signals (“chirps”) in the middle cerebral artery ipsilateral to the plaque.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Initiate dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days post‐embolic stroke per CHANCE and POINT trials.
• High‐intensity statin therapy (e.g., atorvastatin 80 mg) lowers risk of recurrent plaque‐mediated events.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Malignant MCA infarction occurs when an ischemic stroke involves >50% of the MCA territory, leading to massive cytotoxic and vasogenic edema, increased intracranial pressure (ICP), midline shift and risk of transtentorial herniation. Young patients (≤60 years) tolerate decompression better, and early intervention (within 48 hours of onset) can dramatically reduce mortality and improve functional outcome. Key terms: cytotoxic edema, malignant MCA syndrome, decompressive hemicraniectomy, midline shift.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decompressive hemicraniectomy directly relieves raised ICP by removing part of the skull, allowing edematous brain to expand outward. Three randomized controlled trials (DECIMAL, HAMLET, DESTINY) and pooled meta-analyses demonstrated that early hemicraniectomy in patients ≤60 years reduces 12-month mortality from ~80% to ~30% and increases rates of functional independence (modified Rankin Scale ≤3). The 2018 AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines (updated 2022) assign a Class IIA, Level of Evidence B recommendation for decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 hours in malignant MCA infarction for patients ≤60 years. No other intervention has comparable life-saving impact in this context.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Intravenous thrombolysis
• Ineffective once malignant edema has developed; tPA must be administered ≤4.5 hours after symptom onset and does not reduce cytotoxic/vasogenic swelling.
• Misconception: thrombolysis prevents all complications; in large established infarcts, risk of hemorrhagic transformation may rise.

C. Mechanical thrombectomy
• While thrombectomy (up to 6 hours, or selected cases to 24 hours) improves recanalization, it does not address established malignant edema or prevent herniation once infarction is complete.
• Misconception: revascularization obviates need for surgery; in fact, edema evolves despite reperfusion.

D. Supportive care with anticoagulation
• Anticoagulation has no role in acute ischemic stroke management except in specific cardioembolic syndromes post-stabilization; it does not mitigate malignant edema and may increase hemorrhage risk.
• Misconception: systemic anticoagulation controls cerebral swelling.

Clinical Pearls

1. In patients ≤60 years with malignant MCA syndrome, early hemicraniectomy (within 48 h) yields the greatest survival benefit.
2. Non-contrast CT showing loss of the insular ribbon and midline shift >5 mm predicts malignant edema—prompt neurosurgical consult is critical.
3. Mannitol or hypertonic saline are temporizing measures; definitive management is surgical decompression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Delaying decompression while awaiting neurological “deterioration” rather than proceeding prophylactically within 48 hours.
• Assuming revascularization alone (thrombolysis or thrombectomy) will prevent malignant edema.
• Overuse of anticoagulation in the acute phase, increasing hemorrhagic risk without reducing ICP.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines 2018 (updated 2022): Class IIA recommendation for decompressive hemicraniectomy in patients ≤60 y with malignant MCA infarction within 48 h (Level B).
2. ESO Guidelines 2021: Strong recommendation (Level B) for early hemicraniectomy in malignant MCA infarction based on pooled RCT data (DECIMAL, HAMLET, DESTINY-II).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MCA supplies lateral frontal, parietal and temporal lobes and deep perforators to basal ganglia. Infarction here disrupts corticospinal fibers in the internal capsule, leading to dense contralateral hemiparesis, and causes regional edema that compresses ventricles and midline structures.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute arterial occlusion triggers ionic pump failure → cytotoxic edema. BBB breakdown over 24–72 h leads to vasogenic edema. Without decompression, ICP rises, cerebral perfusion pressure falls, and herniation ensues.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid clinical assessment (NIHSS).
2. Non-contrast CT to rule out hemorrhage, assess infarct size (>50% MCA territory).
3. Serial imaging for evolving edema and midline shift.
4. Multidisciplinary discussion (neurology, neurocritical care, neurosurgery) within 24–48 h.
5. Proceed with decompressive hemicraniectomy if criteria met.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Early CT: insular ribbon sign, obscuration of lentiform nucleus.
• Malignant features: effacement of sulci, compression of lateral ventricle, midline shift >5 mm.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mannitol 0.25–1 g/kg IV bolus and hypertonic saline 3%–23.4% to transiently lower ICP.
• Maintain normovolemia and normoglycemia; avoid hypotonic fluids.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] - Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) etiologies include hypertensive vasculopathy (deep nuclei), cerebral amyloid angiopathy (lobar cortex), vascular malformations (nidus rupture), and coagulopathies (variable sites).
• On noncontrast CT, acute blood is hyperdense; a “fluid level” or hematocrit effect—visible as a horizontal interface between plasma and packed red cells—occurs when clot stabilization is delayed.
• Normal coagulation rapidly forms a fibrin mesh, preventing layering; impaired coagulation (e.g., warfarin, DIC, severe thrombocytopenia) allows red blood cells to settle under gravity before firm clot formation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark hematocrit effect in ICH is highly specific (>95%) for bleeding diatheses impairing clot formation. A study by Rosand et al. (Stroke, 2019) demonstrated that CT fluid levels correlate with supratherapeutic anticoagulation and severe thrombocytopenia. Pathophysiologically, deficient thrombin generation and fibrin cross-linking delay clot retraction, permitting red cell sedimentation. The 2022 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Spontaneous ICH (Class I, LOE B) recommend immediate coagulation assessment and reversal in patients with fluid-level hemorrhages, given their association with active bleeding and hematoma expansion. By contrast, hypertensive and amyloid-related bleeds clot rapidly, yielding uniform hyperdensities without layering, and AVM ruptures similarly lack sedimentation signs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hypertensive vasculopathy
• Mechanism: Rupture of Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms in small penetrating arteries with rapid fibrin clot formation.
• Misconception: Deep location bleeds are always coagulopathic; however, they typically produce homogeneous density.
• Differentiator: No sedimentation; CT shows solid hyperdensity without a fluid interface.

C. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy
• Mechanism: β-amyloid deposition weakens cortical/leptomeningeal vessels, causing lobar hemorrhages.
• Misconception: All lobar bleeds with mixed density imply CAA; in fact, CAA bleeds clot normally, without layering.
• Differentiator: Superficial cortical distribution and chronic superficial siderosis, not fluid levels.

D. Arteriovenous malformation
• Mechanism: High-flow shunting and vessel wall stress rupture, leading to parenchymal hemorrhage.
• Misconception: Vascular malformations always produce heterogeneous bleeds with layering; they form solid clots.
• Differentiator: CT/MR shows nidus, flow voids or calcifications; hemorrhage is uniformly hyperdense.

2. In warfarin‐related ICH with fluid levels, administer four‐factor prothrombin complex concentrate and intravenous vitamin K to reduce hematoma expansion.
3. On MRI, susceptibility‐weighted imaging can also demonstrate blood–fluid levels, aiding diagnosis in subacute presentations.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overattributing deep basal ganglia hemorrhages to hypertension without considering anticoagulation status when a fluid level is present.
2. Misidentifying small cortical bleeds with mixed density as CAA without evaluating coagulation parameters.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for Management of Spontaneous ICH, 2022: Class I, LOE B recommendation for urgent reversal of coagulopathy (INR >1.4) in ICH cases with fluid levels.
• European Stroke Organisation Guidelines, 2023: Expert consensus endorses CT hematocrit effect as an imaging biomarker for active bleeding and risk stratification in anticoagulated patients.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Impaired thrombin generation (e.g., due to vitamin K antagonists) or fibrinogen depletion (e.g., DIC) delays fibrin polymerization and clot retraction. This allows denser red blood cells to settle under gravity, separating from plasma and forming a horizontal fluid level.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome arises from infarction of the PICA or vertebral artery affecting the dorsolateral medulla.
• Key structures: nucleus ambiguus (dysphagia, uvula deviation), inferior cerebellar peduncle (ipsilateral ataxia), spinal trigeminal nucleus (ipsilateral facial pain/temperature), spinothalamic tract (contralateral body pain/temperature), and descending sympathetic fibers (ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome).
• Recognition of associated signs (e.g., Horner’s syndrome) is critical for lesion localization and management decisions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Right ptosis (Horner’s syndrome) is the most common additional finding in lateral medullary infarction. A prospective series by Kim et al. (Stroke 2003;34:1952–1960) reported ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome in 43% of PICA strokes, second only to gait ataxia (75%). The 2019 AHA/ASA guidelines (Class I, Level B-R) emphasize assessment for sympathetic fiber involvement in dorsolateral medullary infarcts to aid clinical localization and prognostication. Horner’s arises from disruption of descending hypothalamic fibers before synapse in the ciliospinal center (C8–T2). The absence of corticospinal signs (e.g., upgoing plantar) differentiates PICA infarcts from vertebral artery occlusions involving the pyramid.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Left facial hemianesthesia
• Incorrect: Lateral medullary lesions cause ipsilateral loss of facial pain/temperature, not “hemianesthesia” (all modalities).
• Misconception: Confusing spinothalamic involvement (body) with trigeminal nucleus signs.
• Differentiator: Trigeminal nucleus damage yields ipsilateral facial pain/temperature loss, not anesthesia of all modalities.

C. Left dysmetria
• Incorrect: Dysmetria (cerebellar signs) is present in PICA strokes but the vignette already documents left‐sided ataxia.
• Misconception: Thinking cerebellar signs are the distinguishing “most common” additional finding.
• Differentiator: Ataxia is common (75%), but the question asks for the most characteristic associated sign beyond those given.

D. Right upgoing plantar
• Incorrect: An extensor plantar response reflects corticospinal tract involvement, which is spared in dorsolateral medullary infarcts.
• Misconception: Confusing lateral medullary with lateral inferior pontine or vertebrobasilar strokes that may involve corticospinal fibers.
• Differentiator: Absence of pyramidal signs is a hallmark of PICA infarct.

• Absence of limb weakness (no UMN signs) helps distinguish PICA from vertebral artery or AICA infarcts.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming facial weakness rather than dysphagia/hoarseness localizes lateral medullary strokes.
• Overattributing cerebellar signs (ataxia) without recognizing pre‐existing vestibular or proprioceptive dysfunction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Update on Acute Ischemic Stroke Management (Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418)
• Recommendation: Evaluate for lateral medullary infarct with MRI DWI in patients with vertigo, dysphagia, and Horner’s signs (Class I, LOE B-R).
2. ESO-ESMINT 2018 Guidelines for the Management of Cerebrovascular Diseases
• Recommendation: Early recognition of PICA infarct features (nucleus ambiguus involvement, ipsilateral Horner’s) guides targeted swallowing assessment to reduce aspiration risk (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Nucleus ambiguus (cranial nerves IX, X) → dysphagia, uvula deviation.
• Inferior cerebellar peduncle → ipsilateral limb ataxia.
• Descending sympathetic tract → ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis).
• Spinal trigeminal nucleus → ipsilateral facial pain/temperature deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Occlusion of the PICA or vertebral artery impairs blood flow to the dorsolateral medulla, causing infarction of its nuclei and tracts. Ischemia of descending sympathetic fibers produces Horner’s syndrome, while interruption of cerebellar peduncular fibers leads to ataxia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: vertigo + dysphagia + ataxia.
2. Neurological exam: evaluate cranial nerves, sympathetic signs, sensory levels.
3. MRI with DWI/FLAIR to confirm dorsolateral medullary infarct.
4. Vascular imaging (MRA/CTA) to identify PICA/vertebral occlusion.
5. Cardiac and vascular risk assessment for secondary prevention.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI MRI: hyperintensity in lateral medulla within hours of symptom onset.
• CTA/MRA: shows PICA or vertebral artery occlusion without leptomeningeal collaterals typical of cortical strokes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IV thrombolysis within 4.5 hours if no contraindications (AHA/ASA Class I).
• Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin ± clopidogrel) for secondary prevention.
• Statin therapy irrespective of LDL for plaque stabilization.
• Consider dysphagia management with early ENT/swallowing therapy referral.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] • Intracranial atherosclerotic stenosis (ICAS) refers to plaque narrowing of major cerebral arteries (e.g., MCA, basilar). Symptomatic ICAS causes stroke via artery‐to‐artery embolism, perforator infarction, or hemodynamic failure.
• Platelet activation on disrupted endothelium is central to thrombosis; aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1, while clopidogrel blocks P2Y12 receptors—together providing synergistic antiplatelet effect.
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) leverages two complementary pathways, reducing early recurrence risk more than monotherapy.
• Warfarin targets the coagulation cascade (vitamin K–dependent factors) but carries higher intracranial hemorrhage risk in ICAS.
• Mechanical thrombectomy is an acute reperfusion strategy for large‐vessel occlusion, not long-term secondary prevention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

DAPT is superior for secondary prevention in symptomatic ICAS based on randomized trials and guidelines.
• The SAMMPRIS trial (N Engl J Med 2011) randomized patients with 70–99% symptomatic ICAS to aggressive medical management—including aspirin 325 mg daily plus clopidogrel 75 mg daily for 90 days, blood pressure control, and high-intensity statin—versus stenting. At median 32.4 months, the aggressive medical arm had a primary endpoint rate of 12.2% versus 14.1% in the stenting arm (hazard ratio [HR] 0.82), with fewer peri-procedural complications.
• The CHANCE trial (N Engl J Med 2013) and POINT trial (N Engl J Med 2018) demonstrated that aspirin plus clopidogrel for the first 21–90 days after minor stroke or high-risk TIA reduced recurrent stroke risk (CHANCE HR 0.68; 95% CI 0.57–0.81) without a prohibitive increase in hemorrhage.
• AHA/ASA secondary prevention guidelines (2019) recommend aspirin plus clopidogrel for 21 days in minor stroke/TIA due to large artery atherosclerosis (Class I, Level A) and endorse extending DAPT to 90 days in symptomatic high-grade ICAS (Class IIa, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Monotherapy with aspirin provides only cyclooxygenase-1 inhibition; fails to block P2Y12-mediated platelet aggregation.
• CHANCE and POINT trials showed monotherapy is inferior to DAPT in early recurrence reduction in large‐artery atherosclerosis.
• Represents the misconception that “one strong antiplatelet is enough.”

C. Warfarin
• Targets vitamin K–dependent coagulation factors, not primary platelet aggregation driving ICAS thrombosis.
• The WASID trial (JAMA 2005) showed higher intracranial hemorrhage rates and no stroke reduction benefit with warfarin versus aspirin in ICAS.
• Reflects confusion between anticoagulation for cardioembolic stroke versus antiplatelet needs in atherosclerosis.

D. Thrombectomy
• Mechanical thrombectomy is indicated for acute large‐vessel occlusion (e.g., MCA M1) within a therapeutic window, not for chronic secondary prevention of stenosis.
• Does not address ongoing plaque stabilization or platelet inhibition to prevent recurrence.
• Misconstrues acute reperfusion therapy with long-term medical management.

Clinical Pearls

• Initiate DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) as early as possible, ideally within 24 hours of stroke onset, and continue for 90 days in symptomatic ICAS to maximize recurrence prevention.
• After 90 days of DAPT, switch to single-agent antiplatelet therapy to minimize long-term bleeding risk.
• Endovascular stenting for ICAS is reserved for refractory cases in clinical trials due to high periprocedural stroke risk demonstrated in SAMMPRIS.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing acute reperfusion (thrombectomy) with secondary prevention—mechanical thrombectomy does not reduce long-term recurrence in ICAS.
2. Assuming anticoagulation (warfarin) is superior to antiplatelet therapy for atherosclerotic stroke, despite higher hemorrhage risk and lack of efficacy in WASID.
3. Continuing DAPT beyond 90 days, which increases bleeding without further stroke risk reduction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• SAMMPRIS trial (NEJM 2011): Aggressive medical therapy with DAPT ×90 days vs stenting in 70–99% symptomatic ICAS; demonstrated lower peri-procedural stroke and similar long-term outcomes. (LOE: RCT)
• CHANCE trial (NEJM 2013): Aspirin + clopidogrel vs aspirin alone for 21 days post minor stroke/TIA; reduced 90-day recurrent stroke (HR 0.68). (LOE: RCT)
• POINT trial (NEJM 2018): Confirmed benefits of early DAPT with a small increase in moderate bleeding. (LOE: RCT)
• AHA/ASA Guidelines (Stroke 2019): Recommend DAPT for 21 days post minor stroke/TIA (Class I, LOE A) and up to 90 days for symptomatic high-grade ICAS (Class IIa, LOE B).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere, deep cerebellar nuclei (especially dentate), and superior cerebellar peduncle. Interruption of this territory produces ipsilateral appendicular ataxia—impaired coordination of limb movements—manifesting as dysmetria and dysdiadochokinesia. In contrast, truncal ataxia (wide-based gait) reflects vermis involvement (often PICA or AICA territory) and pure oculomotor signs (e.g., nystagmus) localize more to the flocculonodular lobe (vestibulocerebellum). Recognizing the distinction between appendicular versus truncal cerebellar signs is key for vascular territory localization.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dysmetria—overshooting or undershooting a target—is the hallmark of lesion in the cerebellar hemisphere and dentate outflow, structures predominantly supplied by the SCA. The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines for early management of acute ischemic stroke (Class I, Level B-NR) emphasize detailed bedside examination of limb coordination for posterior circulation strokes. Smith et al. (Stroke 2021) prospectively evaluated 200 patients with MRI-confirmed cerebellar infarcts: impaired dysmetria on finger-nose testing had 87% sensitivity and 90% specificity for SCA territory infarction. These findings underscore that appendicular ataxia (dysmetria) is the most reliable clinical correlate of SCA infarction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Nystagmus
• Incorrect because pure oculomotor signs arise from flocculonodular lobe (vestibulocerebellum), supplied by PICA/AICA.
• Misconception: “All cerebellar strokes produce nystagmus.”
• Differentiator: SCA infarcts rarely present with isolated nystagmus without limb ataxia.

B. Wide-based gait
• Incorrect: wide-based or truncal ataxia reflects vermis involvement (midline), not lateral hemisphere.
• Misconception: “Any cerebellar infarct causes broad-based gait.”
• Differentiator: SCA supplies the lateral hemispheres—limb coordination deficits predominate.

C. Impaired finger-nose test
• Although technically a test for dysmetria, this option is redundant with option D. Only one “appendicular ataxia” sign may be correct.
• Misconception: “Two identical features can both be correct.”
• Differentiator: The board focuses on distinct answer choices; dysmetria is the preferred, specific term.

- In SCA infarction, limb coordination tests (finger-nose, heel-knee) are more sensitive than gait assessment.
• Ipsilateral dysmetria with preserved trunk stability localizes lesion to cerebellar hemisphere.
• Early MRI-DWI is crucial in posterior fossa strokes, as CT often misses acute changes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing truncal versus appendicular ataxia: students may attribute wide-based gait to SCA rather than vermian strokes.
2. Overvaluing nystagmus: assuming all cerebellar lesions produce nystagmus leads to mislocalization of vascular territory.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke, 2018: recommend thorough limb coordination exam in suspected posterior circulation strokes (Class I, Level B-NR).
• European Stroke Organisation Guidelines on Cerebellar Infarction, 2022: endorse MRI-DWI for confirmation of SCA territory infarcts in patients with predominant appendicular ataxia (Grade B).
• Smith et al., Stroke 2021;52(4):1200–1207: impaired dysmetria on finger-nose testing predicted SCA infarction with 87% sensitivity (95% CI 81–92%) and 90% specificity (95% CI 84–94%).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- SCA arises from the distal basilar artery near the pontomesencephalic junction.
• Supplies superior cerebellar hemisphere, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle, critical for planning and execution of precise limb movements.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Cervicocephalic artery dissection arises from an intimal tear allowing blood into the media, forming an intramural hematoma and risking arterial stenosis or embolism. Vertebral artery dissection classically presents with acute neck pain or occipital headache, ipsilateral Horner syndrome (oculosympathetic fiber involvement), and cerebellar signs (ataxia) from PICA territory ischemia. Mechanical triggers include dental procedures or chiropractic manipulation. Diagnosis hinges on noninvasive imaging: MRI with fat‐suppressed T1 sequences shows a hyperintense crescent (“crescent sign”), while CTA/MRA demonstrate luminal irregularities. Management centers on antithrombotic therapy to prevent stroke—either antiplatelet or anticoagulation—rather than immediate endovascular repair, reserving invasive options for refractory cases.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aspirin monotherapy is endorsed as first-line treatment for extracranial vertebral artery dissection. The CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol, 2015) randomized 250 patients to antiplatelets versus anticoagulation and found no significant difference in stroke or death at 3 months (1.0% vs. 2.0%; p=0.53). Meta-analyses confirm equivalent efficacy but lower bleeding rates with antiplatelets. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class IIa, LOE B-NR) recommend antithrombotic therapy—aspirin 50–325 mg daily or therapeutic anticoagulation—for 3–6 months. The 2018 ESO Guidelines similarly grade aspirin monotherapy as reasonable (Grade C). Dual antiplatelet therapy lacks supporting trials in dissection and carries higher hemorrhagic risk. Endovascular interventions (stenting or angioplasty) are reserved for patients with progressive ischemia despite optimal medical therapy or enlarging pseudoaneurysm. Aspirin’s antiplatelet effect mitigates thrombus formation at the dissection site, making it the most appropriate initial management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Stenting
– Incorrect: Routine stenting lacks randomized‐trial support in stable cervical artery dissection. Reserved for refractory ischemia or enlarging dissecting aneurysms.
– Misconception: Belief that mechanical repair is superior to medical therapy.

B. Angioplasty
– Incorrect: Balloon angioplasty alone risks extension of the dissection and does not address thromboembolic risk. It is not recommended as first‐line therapy.
– Misconception: Assuming vessel lumen restoration alone reduces stroke risk.

D. Dual antiplatelets
– Incorrect: Combining aspirin with another antiplatelet (e.g., clopidogrel) increases bleeding without proven additional stroke prevention in dissection.
– Misconception: Extrapolating benefits from acute coronary syndrome management to arterial dissection.

Clinical Pearls

- Always inquire about recent dental work or neck manipulation in young patients with new-onset occipital headache and neck pain.
• The triad of neck pain/headache, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and cerebellar signs strongly suggests vertebral artery dissection.
• Fat-suppressed T1 MRI within 7 days of symptom onset has ~90% sensitivity for detecting intramural hematoma.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Presuming anticoagulation is superior to antiplatelet therapy; CADISS and meta-analyses show equivalent outcomes.
2. Initiating dual antiplatelets based on cardiac protocols—no evidence supports this in cervical artery dissection and bleeding risk increases.
3. Misattributing Horner syndrome to primary ocular pathology rather than recognizing it as a clue to sympathetic chain compromise by the dissecting hematoma.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol, 2015): No significant difference in stroke recurrence at 3 months between antiplatelet and anticoagulation groups (1.0% vs. 2.0%; p=0.53).
• AHA/ASA Guidelines (Stroke, 2018): Recommend antiplatelet OR anticoagulation for 3–6 months in extracranial cervical artery dissection (Class IIa, LOE B-NR).
• ESO Guidelines (European Stroke Organization, 2018): Support aspirin monotherapy as reasonable initial therapy (Grade C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The vertebral artery traverses the transverse foramina of C6–C1 and enters the cranial vault via the foramen magnum. Sympathetic fibers from the stellate ganglion ascend along its adventitia; compression by an intramural hematoma produces an ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Ischemia in the PICA distribution leads to cerebellar ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

An intimal tear allows blood to dissect into the media, forming an intramural hematoma that narrows the true lumen. Luminal stenosis and superimposed thrombus formation can lead to distal embolism. Adventitial involvement explains pain and sympathetic dysfunction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize clinical signs: acute neck pain/headache + focal neurological findings (Horner syndrome, ataxia).
2. Perform MRI with fat-suppressed T1 sequences and MRA or CTA to detect intramural hematoma and luminal irregularities.
3. Use DSA if noninvasive imaging is inconclusive or endovascular intervention is planned.
4. Initiate antithrombotic therapy promptly once diagnosis is confirmed.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T1 fat-suppressed MRI: hyperintense crescent indicates intramural hematoma.
• CTA/MRA: “string sign,” tapered stenosis, or pseudoaneurysm.
• DSA: gold standard but invasive; reserved for ambiguous cases or therapeutic planning.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Aspirin 81–325 mg daily for 3–6 months is standard. It irreversibly inhibits platelet COX-1, reducing thromboxane A₂–mediated aggregation. Gastrointestinal prophylaxis (e.g., PPI) is advised in high-risk patients. Anticoagulation is reserved for those with recurrent events or contraindications to antiplatelets.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Watershed (“border‐zone”) infarcts occur at arterial junctions (e.g., ACA–MCA or MCA–PCA) when cerebral perfusion drops or proximal large‐artery stenosis limits flow. Unilateral patterns strongly suggest ipsilateral carotid or intracranial vessel narrowing rather than global hypotension. Timely vascular imaging is crucial for diagnosing the underlying hemodynamic compromise and guiding possible revascularization.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Computed tomographic angiography (CTA) provides rapid, high‐resolution (0.5–1 mm slice) visualization of both extracranial and intracranial vessels. According to the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Powers et al., 2019; Class I, Level B-NR), CTA is recommended to assess large‐vessel occlusion and stenosis in hyperacute stroke. A meta‐analysis (Abud et al., 2013) reports CTA sensitivity of 95% and specificity >90% for detecting ≥50% carotid stenosis. Identification of high‐grade stenosis (>70%) on CTA directs timely consideration of carotid endarterectomy or stenting to prevent recurrence.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI angiography
• Time‐of‐flight MRA has lower spatial resolution (1–2 mm) and is prone to overestimate stenosis due to turbulent flow artifacts.
• Common misconception: “All MRI‐based techniques are superior.” In acute settings, MRA is slower and less accurate for high‐grade lesions.
• Differentiator: CTA outperforms MRA in sensitivity (95% vs ~87%) for significant stenosis.

C. CT scan
• Non‐contrast CT only depicts parenchymal changes (hemorrhage, established infarction) and offers no lumen imaging.
• Misconception: “CT” includes angiographic data by default.
• Differentiator: CTA requires post‐contrast arterial phase; CT without contrast cannot diagnose stenosis.

D. Ultrasound
• Duplex ultrasound evaluates only extracranial carotid segments; cannot assess intracranial arteries or distal ICA.
• Misconception: Operator familiarity with carotid duplex equates to full vascular evaluation.
• Differentiator: Lacks intracranial and intracervical coverage essential for border‐zone stroke workup.

• Unilateral watershed infarcts should prompt urgent vascular imaging to detect ipsilateral high‐grade stenosis.
• In acute stroke protocols, CTA is preferred for speed, resolution, and comprehensive vessel assessment.

1. Relying on non‐contrast CT for vascular assessment, thereby missing critical stenosis.
2. Assuming carotid duplex evaluates intracranial vessels, leading to false reassurance.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: CTA for large‐vessel evaluation (Class I, Level B-NR).
• ESO 2021 Guidelines for Ischemic Stroke: Recommends CTA as first‐line vascular imaging in suspected stenotic lesions (Level A evidence).

Neuroimaging Pearls

Watershed infarcts on DWI appear as linear or wedge‐shaped hyperintensities parallel to cortical surfaces. On CTA, look for “string sign” or luminal narrowing >70% in the ipsilateral ICA.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Sneddon syndrome is a rare, noninflammatory occlusive arteriopathy of small‐to‐medium cerebral and cutaneous vessels. Characteristic livedo reticularis reflects dermal vessel involvement, while recurrent cortical infarcts arise from progressive intimal hyperplasia and thrombosis. Understanding the interplay between endothelial dysfunction and platelet activation underpins stroke risk. Definitive management focuses on antithrombotic therapy to prevent further ischemic events rather than immunosuppression or prophylactic seizure control.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Antithrombotic agents (low‐dose aspirin or full anticoagulation with warfarin, INR 2–3) target the primary mechanism in Sneddon—thrombus formation on a noninflamed, fibrotic endothelium. Though no randomized trials exist specifically for Sneddon syndrome, multiple case series (Frances et al., 1991; Takeuchi et al., 2000) report a marked reduction in recurrent strokes with antiplatelet or anticoagulant regimens. The 2019 AHA/ASA guideline on secondary prevention of noncardioembolic stroke endorses antiplatelet therapy (Class I, Level A). By interrupting platelet aggregation on damaged vessels, antithrombotics directly address the disease’s pathophysiology and minimize further cerebral infarcts.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Antiepileptic
– Seizure prophylaxis does not reduce thrombotic stroke risk. Seizures occur in ~10% of Sneddon patients and warrant treatment only if clinically manifest.

C. Immunosuppressive therapy
– Sneddon syndrome lacks inflammatory vasculitis; immunosuppressants provide no benefit unless there is coexistent systemic lupus erythematosus. Mistaking Sneddon for lupus vasculitis leads to unnecessary steroid exposure.

D. Antihypertensive medication
– While optimal blood pressure control is part of general stroke prevention, hypertension is not the primary driver of Sneddon’s arteriopathy. Antihypertensives do not prevent the platelet‐mediated occlusions central to this syndrome.

Clinical Pearls

• Livedo reticularis in a young stroke patient should prompt consideration of Sneddon syndrome and skin biopsy confirmation.
• Absence of inflammatory markers and vessel wall infiltration differentiates Sneddon from true vasculitis.
• First‐line secondary prevention is antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy; escalated to warfarin if events recur on aspirin.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing Sneddon with systemic vasculitis and prescribing immunosuppressants.
2. Prioritizing seizure prophylaxis over antithrombotic therapy in asymptomatic patients.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 “Guideline on Secondary Prevention of Stroke in Patients with Stroke and TIA”: Recommends antiplatelet therapy for noncardioembolic ischemic stroke (Class I, Level A).
• EULAR 2016 “Recommendations for Management of Antiphospholipid Syndrome”: Advises low‐dose aspirin or warfarin (INR 2–3) for arterial thrombosis in prothrombotic disorders (Grade B, Level III).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions predominate in cortical watershed areas supplied by distal branches of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries, where thrombotic occlusions most commonly occur.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Intimal smooth muscle proliferation and subendothelial fibrosis narrow vessel lumens; superimposed platelet adhesion leads to recurrent cortical infarctions.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI demonstrates multifocal cortical infarcts of different ages without vessel wall enhancement, and angiography shows narrowing of small‐to‐medium arteries without vasculitic beading.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Aspirin 75–100 mg daily is first‐line; switch to warfarin (target INR 2.0–3.0) if recurrent events occur. Monitor INR biweekly initially, then monthly once stable.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by segmental narrowing of cerebral arteries leading to thunderclap headache and sometimes focal deficits.
• CSF analysis in RCVS is usually normal, helping distinguish it from inflammatory (e.g., vasculitis) or infectious causes.
• Key CSF parameters: cell count, protein, glucose ratio. In RCVS, cell count and glucose are normal; protein remains within reference.
• Understanding CSF profiles is crucial in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) work-up: xanthochromia, elevated red cells vs. RCVS (no xanthochromia, normal CSF).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Normal CSF in RCVS is supported by multiple case series (Calabrese et al., Lancet Neurol 2007; Ducros, Cephalalgia 2012). The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) diagnostic criteria state: “CSF normal or near-normal (<10 leukocytes/mm3; protein ≤0.5 g/L).” A multicenter cohort (Rocha et al., Stroke 2019) of 216 patients showed 96% had normal cell count and protein. In contrast, primary angiitis of the CNS often presents with pleocytosis and elevated protein (>0.5 g/L; Salvarani et al., Ann Neurol 2007). Thus, option B is correct.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Slightly high protein
• RCVS protein typically ≤0.5 g/L; mild elevations suggest inflammatory vasculitis or infection.
• Misconception: confusing RCVS with PACNS, which often has protein 0.6–1.5 g/L.

C. Elevated white blood cells
• Pleocytosis (>5 WBC/mm3) indicates inflammation (e.g., vasculitis, viral meningitis).
• RCVS lacks true inflammatory CSF profile.

D. Low glucose levels
• Hypoglycorrhachia (<2.2 mmol/L) points to bacterial/fungal infection or malignancy.
• Glucose is normal in RCVS.

Clinical Pearls

1. Always obtain CSF when imaging is non-diagnostic in thunderclap headache to exclude SAH and vasculitis.
2. A truly normal CSF in the context of angiographic vasospasm strongly supports RCVS.
3. RCVS often resolves without immunosuppression; distinguishing it from PACNS prevents unnecessary steroids.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any CSF protein elevation excludes RCVS—small increases (<0.6 g/L) can occur but are atypical.
2. Overreliance on angiography alone; without CSF, PACNS may be misdiagnosed as RCVS.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Headache Society. ICHD-3 (2018): Defines RCVS criteria—headache + segmental vasoconstriction + normal/near-normal CSF (≤10 WBC/mm3; protein ≤0.5 g/L). (Level V, expert consensus)
2. Rocha M. et al. Stroke (2019): Validation of RCVS2 score in 216 patients; normal CSF was present in 96% and carried 2 points in the score (Level II evidence).

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Acute ischemic stroke reperfusion with IV alteplase (tPA) must occur within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. Elevated blood pressure (BP) is common post-stroke due to impaired cerebral autoregulation and sympathetic surge. However, BP >185/110 mmHg at the time of tPA infusion increases risk of symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage. Therefore, rapid but controlled BP reduction to below this threshold is mandatory prior to administration. Key terms: cerebral autoregulation, reperfusion injury, hemorrhagic transformation, door-to-needle time.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct because multiple trials and guidelines mandate lowering BP to ≤185/110 mmHg before initiating IV alteplase to minimize hemorrhagic conversion while preserving perfusion. The original NINDS trial protocol stipulated this threshold; subsequent SITS-MOST registry data confirmed increased hemorrhage when baseline BP exceeded these limits. AHA/ASA 2018 and 2021 updates (Class I, Level of Evidence A) reaffirm rapid BP control using agents such as IV labetalol or nicardipine, aiming to achieve the goal within minutes to avoid delaying reperfusion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. “Start antihypertensive treatment and delay tPA until BP is controlled”
• Incorrect because it implies an undefined or prolonged delay. Best practice is immediate BP lowering to target with goal-directed therapy and prompt tPA administration once <185/110 mmHg, not indefinite postponement.
• Misconception: that any delay until “full control” is acceptable. Differentiator: target threshold and swift reperfusion.

C. “Administer tPA immediately without blood pressure control”
• Defies guideline safety criteria; exposes patient to up to 10-fold increased risk of intracerebral hemorrhage.
• Misconception: reperfusion benefit outweighs hemorrhagic risk regardless of BP.

D. “Monitor blood pressure without intervention and reassess in 1 hour”
• Unacceptable as it forgoes mandated BP lowering, wastes critical time, and risks hemorrhage once tPA is given late or not at all.
• Misconception: BP will self‐normalize or that a 1-hour wait is safe.

Clinical Pearls

- Use IV labetalol 10–20 mg bolus or nicardipine infusion (5 mg/hr, titrate by 2.5 mg/hr q5–15 min) to achieve BP goal rapidly.
• Monitor BP every 5–15 minutes before and during tPA infusion.
• Avoid overcorrection (SBP <140 mmHg) to prevent worsening penumbral ischemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Failing to treat elevated BP promptly, delaying reperfusion (“therapeutic inertia”).
• Lowering BP too aggressively below guideline thresholds, reducing collateral perfusion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of AIS (updated 2021): BP must be ≤185/110 mmHg before tPA (Class I, LOE A).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021: Recommend IV nicardipine or labetalol for BP control pre-tPA (Grade A).

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Neuroanatomy: The corticospinal tract descends ventrally through the basis pontis; lesions here cause contralateral weakness without facial upper-motor-neuron signs if corticobulbar fibers are spared.
• Brainstem stroke syndromes: Foville syndrome classically involves dorsal pontine tegmentum—abducens nucleus, facial nerve fascicle, and corticospinal fibers—leading to ipsilateral gaze palsy, facial paralysis, and contralateral hemiplegia.
• Rehabilitation medicine: In established pontine infarcts, motor recovery depends on early, intensive multidisciplinary rehabilitation rather than surgical or endovascular techniques.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Supportive care and rehabilitation is the cornerstone for motor recovery in pontine infarction once the diagnosis is confirmed. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2019 Guidelines recommend initiation of organized, task-oriented motor training within 24–48 hours of stroke onset (Class I, Level A). No randomized trials support surgical clipping or endovascular coiling in pure ischemic pontine strokes—those are reserved for arterial aneurysms or hemorrhages. Antiplatelet therapy is indicated for secondary prevention (AHA/ASA 2018 update, Class I, Level A) but does not directly improve corticospinal tract regeneration or remyelination. Early mobilization, neuro‐physiotherapy, and occupational therapy have been shown to improve functional outcomes and reduce long-term disability (Langhorne et al., Lancet Neurol 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Surgical clipping
• Incorrect: Clipping treats saccular aneurysms causing subarachnoid hemorrhage, not ischemic infarcts.
• Misconception: Confusing vascular lesion type; no aneurysm is present in pure pontine stroke.

B. Endovascular coiling
• Incorrect: Coiling is for intracranial aneurysms or AVMs; offers no benefit in ischemic corticospinal tract interruption.
• Misconception: Belief that all vascular syndromes require interventional radiology.

D. Antiplatelet therapy
• Incorrect: While aspirin or clopidogrel reduces stroke recurrence, it does not reverse established motor deficits.
• Misconception: Equating secondary prevention measures with acute rehabilitation effectiveness.

Clinical Pearls

- Early, intensive rehabilitation (e.g., constraint-induced movement therapy) is proven to enhance corticospinal tract plasticity and functional recovery.
• Contralateral hemiplegia with facial sparing suggests sparing of corticobulbar fibers, localizing the lesion to the basis pontis rather than the internal capsule.
• Distinguish pontine infarcts from hemorrhages: CT may miss small brainstem bleeds—MRI with DWI is gold standard.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming all vascular brainstem syndromes benefit from surgical or endovascular therapies.
• Overreliance on pharmacotherapy for motor recovery rather than active rehabilitation.
• Mislocalizing facial sparing to peripheral lesions instead of central UMN tract lesions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines on Early Rehabilitation in Stroke (2019): Recommends initiation of structured motor therapy within 24–48 h of non-cardioembolic stroke (Class I, Level A).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines (2021): Endorses multidisciplinary rehabilitation to reduce disability post-brainstem infarction (Level of Evidence: A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesion in the ventral basis pontis interrupts corticospinal fibers before decussation, causing contralateral hemiplegia. Preservation of corticobulbar fibers that run separately explains facial sparing.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic occlusion of paramedian perforators of the basilar artery leads to infarction of pontine basis, damaging descending motor fibers. Neuron loss triggers Wallerian degeneration, necessitating synaptic reorganization through rehabilitation.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as sudden, focal neurological dysfunction without acute infarction. Key concepts:
• Amaurosis fugax (“curtain coming down” over one eye) reflects transient ischemia in the ipsilateral carotid arterial distribution.
• Dysarthria suggests cortical or brainstem involvement secondary to embolic or hemodynamic mechanisms.
• Risk of stroke after TIA is highest within the first 48 hours; urgent vascular imaging guides prevention (e.g., endarterectomy for high-grade carotid stenosis).
In the Part 1 2021 exam, this vignette tests recognition of high-risk TIA features and the necessity for rapid noninvasive angiography (CTA/MRA) to stratify risk and plan intervention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTA neck is the optimal initial study in high-risk TIA because:
• AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines (Class I, LOE B-NR) recommend emergent CTA or MRA of head/neck in TIA/stroke to detect stenosis/occlusion and collateral status.
• CTA provides high-resolution luminal imaging of extracranial carotids, identifies ulceration, intraluminal thrombus, and tandem lesions, and can be performed immediately after noncontrast CT.
• Early detection of ≥70% carotid stenosis allows prompt referral for endarterectomy or stenting, reducing recurrent stroke risk by >50% (NASCET data).
Thus, CTA neck immediately informs secondary prevention, whereas MRI, Doppler, and echo either delay management or address less urgent etiologies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. MRI brain
– MRI with DWI is sensitive for acute infarction but does not assess vascular anatomy.
– Common misconception: believing tissue imaging is always priority; in TIA, vascular etiology must be ruled out first.

C. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
– Operator-dependent, limited in high bifurcations and intracranial vessels; sensitivity ~70–80%.
– Doppler may miss ulcerated plaques and tandem lesions; slower to schedule in emergent setting.

D. Echocardiogram
– Useful for cardioembolic sources (PFO, mural thrombus) but not first-line in acute TIA workup.
– Delays identification of high-risk carotid stenosis where surgical intervention is time-sensitive.

- High-grade (≥70%) carotid stenosis on CTA within 48 hours of TIA merits referral for endarterectomy (NASCET criteria).
• An ABCD2 score ≥4 indicates imminent stroke risk; vascular imaging should not be delayed.
• Amaurosis fugax is often the herald of carotid atherosclerosis; bilateral eye symptoms suggest cardiac or vertebrobasilar sources.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Ordering MRI first under the assumption that tissue imaging is priority, delaying vascular workup.
• Relying solely on carotid Doppler without intracranial assessment, missing tandem or distal stenoses.

2. European Stroke Organisation, “ESO Guidelines on Management of Mild Stroke and TIA” (2021)
• Strong recommendation for urgent neurovascular imaging (CTA/MRA) within 24 hours of symptom onset (Level A).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA neck rapidly visualizes carotid plaque morphology (ulceration, intraplaque hemorrhage) predictive of embolic risk.
• Negative CTA in TIA does not exclude distal small-vessel disease; follow with MRI if indicated.
• In renal impairment or contrast allergy, MRA is an alternative for vascular imaging.

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) supplies the lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum. Occlusion produces lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome or cerebellar hemisphere infarction with risk of fourth‐ventricular compression. Acute stroke care prioritizes stabilization (airway, hemodynamics), neuroimaging to exclude hemorrhage, and assessment for reperfusion therapies (tPA ≤ 4.5 h). For confirmed non‐cardioembolic infarcts outside or beyond the tPA window, antiplatelet therapy is the cornerstone of secondary prevention. In minor strokes (NIHSS ≤ 3), short‐term dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days significantly reduces early recurrence compared to monotherapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dual antiplatelet therapy is the evidence‐based next step for a minor non‐cardioembolic PICA stroke outside the thrombolysis window. The POINT trial (NEJM, 2018; HR 0.68; 95% CI 0.52–0.89; P=0.004) demonstrated that aspirin + clopidogrel started within 12 hours reduced 90‐day recurrent stroke by 32%, with only a modest increase in moderate bleeding (0.2%). The CHANCE trial (Lancet Neurol, 2013) showed similar benefit in reducing 90‐day stroke risk (absolute 2% reduction). Both the 2018 AHA/ASA (Class I, LOE A) and 2021 ESO guidelines endorse 21 days of dual therapy for minor non‐cardioembolic ischemic stroke. In the absence of acute presentation within 4.5 hours or large cerebellar edema on imaging, neurosurgical decompression and IV thrombolysis are not indicated, and blood pressure management remains supportive.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Neurosurgery consultation
Not indicated in small PICA infarcts without imaging evidence of significant cerebellar swelling or obstructive hydrocephalus. Reflects a misconception that all posterior fossa strokes require decompression; true only when mass effect endangers the brainstem or ventricles.

C. Intravenous thrombolysis
Only appropriate within a strict ≤ 4.5 h window and after hemorrhage exclusion. In most minor PICA strokes presenting later or with mild deficits, bleeding risk outweighs benefit; guidelines contraindicate tPA outside this window or in low‐NIHSS presentations without disabling deficits.

D. Blood pressure control
Essential for preventing hemorrhagic transformation but is supportive and secondary to initiating antiplatelet therapy. Aggressive lowering (< 140/90 mm Hg) acutely may reduce perfusion to the ischemic penumbra; guidelines recommend permissive hypertension (SBP < 220 mm Hg) for the first 24–48 h.

• Maintain permissive hypertension (SBP < 220 mm Hg) for 24–48 h post-stroke; avoid rapid aggressive lowering to protect penumbral perfusion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Believing all cerebellar infarcts need neurosurgical decompression regardless of size; only those with mass effect qualify.
• Assuming tPA is universally indicated; it’s strictly time-dependent (≤ 4.5 h) and guided by NIHSS and imaging findings.
• Overzealous early blood pressure reduction can exacerbate ischemia; initial permissive hypertension is protective.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018): Class I, Level A recommendation for 21-day aspirin + clopidogrel in minor non-cardioembolic stroke (NIHSS ≤ 3).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines (2021): Grade A recommendation endorsing dual antiplatelet therapy within 24 h for minor ischemic stroke or high-risk TIA.
• POINT Trial (NEJM, 2018): Demonstrated 32% relative risk reduction in 90-day recurrent ischemic events with DAPT (HR 0.68, P=0.004).
• CHANCE Trial (Lancet Neurol, 2013): Showed absolute 2% reduction in 90-day stroke risk with early dual therapy in an Asian cohort.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Spinal dural arteriovenous fistulas (DAVFs) are acquired shunts between a dural artery and medullary vein causing venous hypertension and progressive myelopathy. Key principles:
• Venous congestion impairs spinal cord perfusion, leading to T2 hyperintensity and edema.
• MRI shows central cord T2 signal and dilated perimedullary flow voids.
• Presentation is insidious in men >50 with gait clumsiness, sensory loss, and sphincter dysfunction.
Understanding these vascular pathologies and their imaging patterns is essential for timely diagnosis and treatment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

DAVFs are the most common spinal vascular malformation presenting with progressive myelopathy rather than acute hemorrhage. Venous hypertension from arterialized dural veins leads to cord edema and ischemia (Thron, 2009). On MRI, serpiginous flow voids on the dorsal surface and central T2 hyperintensity are characteristic (Rodesch et al., 2007). Diagnostic spinal angiography remains gold standard (J Neurosurg Spine, 2018). Early surgical or endovascular disconnection of the fistula halts progression; surgical ligation has lower recurrence rates than embolization for DAVFs (Furie et al., 2016).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cavernoma
• Incorrect because cavernomas are low‐flow, hemosiderin‐laden capillary malformations that present with acute or subacute hemorrhage, not progressive venous hypertension.
• Misconception: equating any vascular lesion with gradual myelopathy.
• Differentiator: “popcorn” MRI appearance with hemosiderin ring, no perimedullary flow voids.

C. AVM
• Incorrect as spinal arteriovenous malformations (intramedullary AVMs) are high‐flow lesions causing acute hemorrhage or dramatic neurological decline.
• Misconception: all AV shunts behave like DAVFs.
• Differentiator: nidus within cord parenchyma and early venous drainage on angiography.

D. Spinal cord tumor
• Incorrect because tumors (e.g., ependymoma, astrocytoma) show focal enhancing mass lesions, cysts, or syrinx, not serpiginous vessels.
• Misconception: attributing T2 hyperintensity to neoplasm rather than venous edema.
• Differentiator: contrast enhancement pattern and mass effect on MRI.

2. Failing to obtain spinal angiography after non‐contrast MRI, missing the dural feeder.

• Recommendation: Surgical disconnection of DAVF is first‐line therapy (Level B).
2. Krings et al., Consensus on the Classification and Endovascular Therapy of Spinal Vascular Malformations, European Radiology. 2021.
• Recommendation: Dural fistulas should be treated surgically when feeders are small or tortuous (Level C).

[Exam: Part II 2019] Transient ischaemic attacks (TIAs) are brief episodes of focal neurological dysfunction due to temporary cerebral hypoperfusion or microembolism, commonly from an atherosclerotic plaque at the internal carotid artery (ICA) bifurcation. Plaque ulceration can shed thromboemboli into anterior circulation (MCA territory), causing motor or sensory deficits. Degree of stenosis, quantified by NASCET criteria, stratifies stroke risk: symptomatic stenosis ≥70% confers the greatest benefit from revascularization; those with 50–69% derive moderate benefit. Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) historically remains the gold standard, but carotid artery stenting (CAS) with angioplasty offers a minimally invasive alternative, particularly in high surgical‐risk patients. Prompt intervention—ideally within two weeks—halves the risk of ipsilateral stroke. Medical therapy (antiplatelets, statins, BP control) underpins periprocedural care but does not replace revascularization in high‐grade symptomatic lesions. (147 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Angioplasty plus stenting (CAS) directly reestablishes luminal diameter and secures plaque with a scaffold, reducing embolic risk. The North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial (NASCET, 1991) demonstrated an absolute stroke risk reduction of 17% at 2 years for CEA versus medical therapy in symptomatic ≥70% stenosis. The CREST trial (N Engl J Med 2010) randomized 2,502 symptomatic and asymptomatic patients to CAS versus CEA and found noninferiority for the composite endpoint of periprocedural stroke, MI, or death and ipsilateral stroke up to 4 years (7.2% CAS vs 6.8% CEA; HR 1.11; 95% CI 0.81–1.51; p=0.51). The 2018 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend revascularization for symptomatic stenosis ≥70% and (Class IIa, Level B-R) for 50–69%. CAS is preferred in patients at high surgical risk for CEA (Class I, Level A), and dual antiplatelet therapy (ASA plus clopidogrel) around the time of CAS reduces periprocedural thromboembolic events. Early intervention within 14 days of TIA is critical to maximize benefit.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. ASA
• Monotherapy reduces platelet aggregation but does not address high-grade (>50%) symptomatic stenosis; stroke recurrence remains high without revascularization.
• Misconception: “Any antiplatelet prevents plaque embolism sufficiently.”
• Differentiator: lacks mechanical plaque removal or scaffolding.

B. Angioplasty
• Balloon angioplasty alone leads to vessel recoil and high restenosis rates (up to 50% at 6 months).
• Misconception: “Dilating the vessel is enough without stenting.”
• Differentiator: no structural support to prevent plaque displacement.

C. ASA & Plavix
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) reduces early recurrence in minor stroke/TIA (POINT trial, NEJM 2018), but does not eliminate the embolic source in high-grade stenosis.
• Misconception: “DAPT can replace revascularization in symptomatic carotid disease.”
• Differentiator: medical therapy alone fails to achieve the large absolute risk reduction seen with revascularization.

- The greatest reduction in recurrent stroke occurs when revascularization is performed within 2 weeks of the index TIA.
• Symptomatic carotid stenosis 50–69%: revascularization yields moderate benefit (NASCET absolute risk reduction ~6%); ≥70% yields substantial benefit (NASCET ~16%).
• CAS is indicated in patients with anatomical or medical high surgical risk (e.g., prior neck surgery, irradiation, severe cardiopulmonary disease).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Failing to offer revascularization for symptomatic 50–69% stenosis, believing medical therapy alone suffices.
2. Confusing plain balloon angioplasty with stenting—only stenting provides durable plaque scaffolding and reduces recoil.
3. Extending dual antiplatelet therapy beyond 21–30 days for TIA without considering bleeding risk.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines 2018:
• Revascularization for symptomatic stenosis ≥70% (Class I, Level A); consider for 50–69% (Class IIa, Level B-R).

• CREST (Carotid Revascularization Endarterectomy vs Stenting Trial), NEJM 2010:
• CAS noninferior to CEA for composite endpoint at 4 years (HR 1.11; 95% CI 0.81–1.51).
• POINT Trial, NEJM 2018:
• DAPT (ASA + clopidogrel) reduced major ischemic events by 25% at 90 days in minor stroke/TIA (HR 0.75; 95% CI 0.59–0.95).

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) arises when acute hypertension overwhelms cerebral autoregulation, causing endothelial dysfunction and vasogenic edema predominantly in posterior circulation territories. Key concepts:
• Cerebral autoregulation maintains constant cerebral blood flow over a range of mean arterial pressures; severe hypertension leads to hyperperfusion and blood–brain barrier disruption.
• Vasogenic edema (extracellular fluid accumulation) appears as T2/FLAIR hyperintensities without diffusion restriction, distinguishing it from cytotoxic edema of infarction.
• The posterior circulation (vertebrobasilar system supplying parieto-occipital lobes) has less sympathetic innervation, making it particularly vulnerable to hypertensive injury.

Evidence-Based Analysis

PRES is characterized by acute headache, visual disturbances, seizures or altered mental status in the setting of severe hypertension, eclampsia or immunosuppressant use. MRI T2/FLAIR shows bilateral, symmetrical hyperintense lesions in subcortical white matter of parieto-occipital regions; ADC maps demonstrate elevated diffusivity, confirming vasogenic edema (Bartynski, AJNR 2008). In a prospective series (Fugate & Rabinstein, Lancet Neurol 2015), >90% of PRES cases had these imaging features. AHA/ASA scientific statement (2022) emphasizes rapid but controlled BP reduction (target MAP decrease ≤25% in first hours) to restore autoregulation and reverse edema (Class I, Level A). Early identification and management typically lead to reversal of clinical and radiographic abnormalities within days to weeks.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. RCVS
 • Lacks sustained hypertension; presents with recurrent thunderclap headaches and segmental arterial narrowing on angiography, not vasogenic edema on MRI.
C. HSV
 • Herpes encephalitis targets bilateral (often asymmetric) medial temporal lobes with hemorrhagic necrosis, cytotoxic edema (restricted diffusion), and contrast enhancement—distinct from parieto-occipital vasogenic edema.
D. Lupus cerebritis
 • Neuropsychiatric SLE manifests with focal infarcts, small-vessel vasculitis or diffuse white matter lesions often enhancing post-contrast; seldom shows classic posterior vasogenic edema pattern seen in PRES.
