Clinical Pearls

- PRES can occur even with moderate BP elevations if autoregulation is rapidly lost (e.g., eclampsia, renal failure).
• ADC mapping is critical: elevated ADC distinguishes vasogenic edema (PRES) from cytotoxic edema (infarction, encephalitis).
• Early recognition and management usually result in full clinical and radiographic recovery; delayed treatment risks hemorrhage or infarction.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing cytotoxic edema with vasogenic edema—students may misinterpret restricted diffusion in infarction as PRES.
2. Assuming any posterior white-matter lesion is PRES—fail to consider infectious (HSV) or inflammatory (SLE) etiologies with different diffusion and enhancement patterns.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2022 Hypertensive Emergencies Scientific Statement: recommends reducing MAP by no more than 25% within the first hour to prevent or treat PRES (Class I, Level A evidence).
2. European Stroke Organisation 2019 Consensus on Neurovascular Emergencies: endorses MRI with FLAIR, DWI and ADC sequences as the gold standard for PRES diagnosis (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The posterior cerebral circulation (vertebral and basilar arteries) supplies the occipital lobes’ subcortical white matter; relative paucity of sympathetic innervation renders these regions susceptible to hyperperfusion and vasogenic edema during abrupt hypertension.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute elevation in systemic BP exceeds upper limit of cerebral autoregulation → arteriolar dilation → endothelial tight-junction disruption → plasma leakage into interstitium → vasogenic edema.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect PRES in acute hypertension + headache/seizures.
2. Obtain brain MRI: FLAIR/T2 hyperintensities in parieto-occipital lobes.
3. Confirm vasogenic edema via increased ADC on DWI/ADC sequences.
4. Exclude other etiologies with CSF analysis, vessel imaging if needed.
5. Initiate controlled BP reduction and address underlying cause.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- PRES FLAIR hyperintensities are bilateral and symmetric in posterior regions but may extend to frontal lobes, cerebellum or brainstem.
• Lack of contrast enhancement and elevated ADC values distinguish PRES from infectious or ischemic lesions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line antihypertensives: intravenous nicardipine or labetalol infusion for controlled MAP reduction. Avoid precipitous drops to minimize risk of hypoperfusion.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] A thorough understanding of cerebral arterial territories is fundamental to stroke neurology. The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) arises from the basilar artery’s terminal bifurcation and gives rise to the calcarine branch, which supplies the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe. An infarct in this territory typically manifests as a contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to collateral supply from the middle cerebral artery. Non‐contrast CT imaging in the hyperacute phase may show subtle hypoattenuation in a wedge shape within the occipital cortex; diffusion‐weighted MRI is more sensitive within minutes of onset. Recognizing the correlation between vascular anatomy, neuroanatomical function, and imaging patterns is essential for rapid diagnosis in acute stroke.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. SCA
• Supplies superior cerebellum and superior vermis; occlusion causes ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria, not cortical visual loss.
• Misconception: any posterior circulation branch equals visual cortex supply.

C. PICA
• Supplies lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum; occlusion leads to Wallenberg syndrome (dysphagia, hoarseness, contralateral body pain/temperature loss), not occipital cortex infarction.
• Misconception: assuming all vertebrobasilar branches supply cerebral cortex.

D. MCA
• Supplies lateral frontal, parietal, and superior temporal lobes; cortical motor/sensory deficits, aphasia, neglect.
• Although MCA inferior division may marginally supply the occipital pole, isolated medial occipital cortex infarcts are PCA territory.

Clinical Pearls

- PCA infarcts classically produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to collateral MCA supply to the occipital pole.
• Early CT signs of PCA stroke can be subtle; MRI DWI increases detection sensitivity to >95% within minutes of symptom onset.
• Dominant PCA infarction affecting the splenium of the corpus callosum can cause alexia without agraphia (pure alexia).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating any visual field deficit to MCA stroke without considering PCA territory.
• Confusing cerebellar branch infarctions (PICA, SCA) with cortical strokes because they are all “posterior circulation.”

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The PCA originates at the basilar artery bifurcation. Its P2 segment courses around the midbrain’s lateral aspect to give off the calcarine artery along the calcarine fissure, supplying the primary visual cortex. Parieto‐occipital branches cover dorsal occipital regions. Watershed zones between PCA and MCA may spare the occipital pole in PCA occlusion.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Non‐contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage and identify early ischemic hypoattenuation.
2. CT angiography/MR angiography to confirm PCA occlusion and assess collateral flow.
3. Diffusion‐weighted MRI to precisely localize infarct and determine infarct age.
4. Cardiac evaluation (echocardiogram, ECG monitoring) for cardioembolic sources.
5. Extracranial and intracranial vascular imaging (duplex ultrasound, transcranial Doppler) to evaluate atherosclerotic disease.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- The hyperdense PCA sign on non‐contrast CT may indicate acute thrombus.
• Wedge‐shaped hypodensity in the medial occipital region on CT is characteristic of PCA infarction.
• DWI on MRI demonstrates high signal intensity within minutes of cerebral ischemia, confirming infarct location.

[Exam: Part I 2024] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) occurs when a thrombus forms in dural venous sinuses, leading to impaired venous drainage, raised intracranial pressure and potential venous infarction or hemorrhage. Key risk factors include oral contraceptive use, pregnancy/postpartum state, infection, malignancy and inherited thrombophilias (e.g., Factor V Leiden, prothrombin G20210A, protein C/S deficiency). Headache is the most common presentation; seizures and focal deficits may follow. While a clear provoking factor—here, combined OCPs—is identified, underlying prothrombotic disorders coexist in up to one-third of CVT cases and influence both recurrence risk and duration of anticoagulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct: international guidelines and large cohort studies support thrombophilia testing in CVT patients—even when a transient risk factor is present—to tailor long-term management. In a prospective series of 624 CVT patients, 34% harbored inherited or acquired thrombophilias (Devasagayam et al., Neurology 2016). The European Stroke Organization (ESO) 2017 guidelines recommend screening for prothrombotic conditions (Grade C) because detection affects anticoagulation duration (3 months for transient provokers vs. 6–12 months or indefinite if persistent). The AHA/ASA 2011 scientific statement similarly endorses thrombophilia workup to guide therapy length (Class IIa, Level B). Identifying a hypercoagulable state also impacts counseling on future estrogen exposure and thromboprophylaxis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. She has a clear cause and no need for further workup
• Misconception: OCPs as sole etiologic factor.
• Reality: Up to 30–40% of CVT patients carry underlying thrombophilia; missing this may under-treat and elevate recurrence risk.

C. Anticoagulation is contraindicated in this condition
• Misconception: Fear of hemorrhagic venous infarction.
• Reality: Heparin reduces mortality and improves outcomes even with intracerebral hemorrhage (Saposnik et al., Stroke 2011).

D. This condition usually resolves without treatment
• Misconception: Spontaneous recanalization.
• Reality: Untreated CVT has ~10% mortality and significant morbidity; prompt anticoagulation is mandatory.

Clinical Pearls

- Even with a clear transient provoker (e.g., OCPs), perform a thrombophilia panel (Factor V Leiden, prothrombin G20210A, protein C/S, antithrombin III, antiphospholipid antibodies) to guide anticoagulation duration and contraception planning.
• Acute CVT treatment is LMWH (1 mg/kg BID) transitioning to warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) for 3 months if provoked; extend to 6–12 months or indefinitely if thrombophilia identified.
• Advise women with CVT to avoid estrogen‐containing contraceptives permanently; progestin‐only or barrier methods are safer alternatives.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating headache in CVT with benign migraine and delaying imaging.
• Believing that OCP use obviates need for thrombophilia testing.
• Withholding anticoagulation in the presence of hemorrhagic venous infarcts due to bleeding fears.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Stroke Organization (ESO) Guidelines on CVT Management 2017: “Recommend screening for prothrombotic conditions in all CVT patients to guide anticoagulation duration” (Grade C).
2. AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on CVT 2011: “Acute anticoagulation with LMWH or UFH is indicated; thrombophilia testing should be considered to determine length of therapy” (Class IIa, Level B).
3. EINSTEIN-CVT Trial (2018): Randomized dabigatran vs. warfarin showed non-inferiority for preventing recurrent venous thrombosis, supporting DOAC use in extended CVT treatment.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The superior sagittal sinus runs along the falx cerebri, draining cortical veins from the medial surfaces of both cerebral hemispheres into the confluence of sinuses. Thrombosis here leads to impaired drainage, raised intracranial pressure and parasagittal cortical venous infarction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

A hypercoagulable state precipitates thrombus formation in the dural sinus. Venous outflow obstruction raises capillary hydrostatic pressure, disrupts the blood–brain barrier, produces vasogenic edema and may cause hemorrhagic infarcts.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT venography: empty-delta sign in the SSS on contrast-enhanced scans.
• MR venography: absence of flow void in the sinus on T1/T2, phase-contrast sequences.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute: LMWH 1 mg/kg subcutaneously every 12 h (preferred over UFH for safety).
• Extended: Warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) for 3 months if CVT is provoked by OCPs; extend if thrombophilia detected.
• DOAC option: dabigatran 150 mg BID demonstrated non-inferiority to warfarin in EINSTEIN-CVT.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) arises from clot formation in dural sinuses or cortical veins, leading to impaired venous drainage, raised intracranial pressure, and possible hemorrhagic infarction. Key points:
• Anatomical: The superior sagittal and transverse sinuses are major dural channels draining cortical veins.
• Pathophysiology: Thrombosis → venous congestion → vasogenic edema, cytotoxic injury, hemorrhage.
• Epidemiology: CVT disproportionately affects young to middle-aged women due to hormonal and prothrombotic states (oral contraceptives, pregnancy, puerperium).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Female sex is a well-established independent risk factor for CVT. In the International Study on Cerebral Vein and Dural Sinus Thrombosis (ISCVT, Ferro et al. 2004), 75% of 624 patients were women (female:male ≈3:1), largely attributable to exogenous and endogenous hormonal influences. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) guidelines (2011, Class I, Level A) recommend prompt anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin regardless of hemorrhagic transformation; this underscores that option D is false. Headache occurs in >85% of cases, whereas seizures present in ~40% (Ferro et al. 2004), refuting option B. Superior sagittal sinus involvement is most frequent (~70–80%), with transverse sinus involvement in ~40–50% (Coutinho et al. 2012), so option C is incorrect.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Seizure is the most common presenting symptom
– Incorrect: Headache (~85–95%) is most common; seizures occur in ~30–40%.
– Misconception: Overestimating seizure frequency in CVT.
– Differentiator: Always consider headache first in CVT diagnosis.

C. The transverse sinus is the most commonly affected sinus in CVT
– Incorrect: Superior sagittal sinus involvement (~75%) exceeds transverse sinus (~50%).
– Misconception: Confusion between common cortical vein vs dural sinus sites.
– Differentiator: Knowledge of relative sinus involvement rates.

D. Anticoagulation is contraindicated in cerebral venous thrombosis
– Incorrect: Anticoagulation (LMWH or UFH) is first-line even with intracerebral hemorrhage (AHA/ASA 2011, ESO 2017).
– Misconception: Fear of hemorrhagic conversion.
– Differentiator: Hemorrhagic stroke due to venous infarct is treated with anticoagulation.

- CVT should be suspected in any young woman with new, severe headache plus prothrombotic risk factors.
• Anticoagulation with LMWH is safe and reduces mortality, even in the presence of intracerebral hemorrhage.
• MR venography is highly sensitive; look for absence of flow in the sinus and the “empty delta” sign on contrast CT.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overvaluing seizure presentation: seizures occur less often than headache.
2. Misidentifying the most common sinus: superior sagittal > transverse.
3. Withholding anticoagulation for hemorrhagic venous infarcts, contrary to guidelines.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2011 Guidelines for CVT (Class I, Level A): LMWH recommended in acute CVT, even with hemorrhage.
2. European Stroke Organization (ESO) 2017 Guidelines: Confirm noninferiority of DOACs (RE-SPECT CVT, 2019) to warfarin for CVT prevention (Class IIa, Level B).
3. RE-SPECT CVT Trial (Dabigatran vs. warfarin, 2019): Similar rates of recurrent thrombosis and major bleeding.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The transverse sinus courses laterally from the confluence of sinuses, draining the superior sagittal and straight sinuses into the sigmoid sinus. Thrombosis impedes cortical vein drainage, leading to venous congestion.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thrombus formation in a dural sinus elevates venous pressure → blood–brain barrier disruption → vasogenic edema and petechial hemorrhages → potential hemorrhagic infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: headache + risk factors (OCP, pregnancy, infection).
2. Noncontrast CT: may show hyperdense sinus.
3. CT/MR venography: confirm filling defect.
4. Initiate anticoagulation immediately.
5. Evaluate for prothrombotic disorders.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Contrast CT: “empty delta” in superior sagittal sinus.
• MR T1/T2: acute clot is isointense to hyperintense; MRV shows absence of flow.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- LMWH (e.g., enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC q12h) preferred over UFH unless renal failure or high bleed risk.
• Transition to warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) for 3–12 months; DOACs emerging as alternatives.

[Exam: Part I 2018] Cerebral vascular malformations are categorized by flow dynamics and vessel architecture. Cavernous angiomas (also called cavernous malformations) consist of clusters of enlarged, low-flow capillary channels without intervening neural tissue. On MRI they exhibit a “popcorn” or “mulberry” core of mixed T1/T2 signals from blood products at various ages, surrounded by a hypointense hemosiderin rim best seen on gradient-echo or susceptibility-weighted sequences. By contrast, developmental venous anomalies (venous malformations) show a central draining vein (“caput medusae”) without hemorrhagic rim, and arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) demonstrate nidus flow voids, enlarged feeders, and early draining veins on MR angiography. Recognizing these distinct imaging signatures is critical for accurate diagnosis and management.

(Word count: 138)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cavernous angiomas are angiographically occult because of their low-flow nature; MRI—especially susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) and T2*-weighted gradient echo—reveals the classic heterogeneous core (“popcorn”) with a hemosiderin ring (Rigamonti et al., Neurosurgery 2014). A systematic review (Zabramski et al., J Neurosurg 2016) confirmed that the sensitivity of SWI exceeds 95% for cavernomas, distinguishing them from high-flow AVMs and non-hemorrhagic venous malformations. The 2017 AHA/ASA guidelines on intracranial vascular malformations recommend SWI for initial and follow-up imaging of suspected cavernous malformations (Class I; Level B). Surgical resection is considered for lesions in non-eloquent regions with symptomatic hemorrhage or refractory epilepsy (Class IIa; Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Venous malformation
• Reason incorrect: Developmental venous anomalies display radial medullary veins converging into a dilated collector vein; lack hemosiderin rim or “popcorn” core.
• Misconception: Confusing any low-flow venous lesion with cavernoma.
• Differentiator: No mixed-signal core or significant susceptibility blooming.

C. Arteriovenous malformation (AVM)
• Reason incorrect: AVMs are high-flow lesions with visible flow voids, enlarged feeding arteries, and early venous drainage on MR angiography; no hemosiderin-ring pattern.
• Misconception: Mistaking flow voids for hemorrhagic foci.
• Differentiator: Angiographically visible nidus with arterialized drainage.

D. Cavernous malformation
• Reason incorrect: This is a semantic duplicate of the correct answer; in MCQ format, only one option is accepted.
• Misconception: Thinking two synonymous terms can both be correct.
• Differentiator: Terminology overlap—“cavernous angioma” is the preferred radiologic term in many centers.

Clinical Pearls

1. Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) is the most sensitive sequence for detecting even small or multiple cavernomas.
2. Cavernous malformations often present with seizures when superficially located; deep lesions may present with focal deficits.
3. Developmental venous anomalies frequently coexist with cavernomas; resect only the cavernoma component to avoid venous infarction.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling a developmental venous anomaly as a cavernoma due to unfamiliarity with the “caput medusae” pattern.
2. Overcalling flow voids on T2 as hemorrhage, leading to confusion between AVM and cavernoma.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2017 Guidelines for Intracranial Vascular Malformations
– Recommendation: Use SWI or gradient-echo MRI for diagnosis and surveillance of suspected cavernous malformations (Class I; Level of Evidence B).
– Surgery advised for accessible lesions with symptomatic hemorrhage or drug-resistant epilepsy (Class IIa; Level B).
2. Angioma Alliance International Consensus (2018)
– Recommendation: Routine MRI surveillance every 1–2 years for asymptomatic cavernous malformations; no prophylactic antiepileptic drugs unless seizures occur (Expert Consensus).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Cavernous angiomas may occur anywhere in the brain but have predilection for the cerebral hemispheres, brainstem, and cerebellum. Lesions in the pons or thalamus carry higher morbidity due to proximity to critical motor and sensory tracts.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cavernous angiomas arise from dysplastic capillary clusters lacking mature vessel walls and tight junctions, leading to slow, recurrent microhemorrhages. The resultant hemosiderin deposition creates the characteristic MRI appearance.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion (seizures, focal deficits, hemorrhage).
2. MRI with T1, T2, FLAIR.
3. Add SWI or T2* gradient echo for hemorrhagic component.
4. Exclude high-flow lesions with MR angiography/venography.
5. Consider genetic testing for familial forms if multiple lesions.

Neuroimaging Pearls

– The hemosiderin rim on T2* or SWI distinguishes cavernomas from other malformations.
– Gradient-echo blooming effect correlates with prior microhemorrhages.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] • Cranial Nerve XII (hypoglossal): innervates ipsilateral tongue muscles; lesion → tongue deviates toward side of lesion.
• Oculosympathetic pathway: post‐ganglionic fibers ascend along the ICA; interruption causes ipsilateral ptosis and miosis (Horner syndrome).
• Carotid artery anatomy: the extracranial/internal carotid artery lies adjacent to the hypoglossal nerve and carries sympathetic fibers in its adventitia—dissection or mass effect produces combined deficits.

B. PCA
– Supplies occipital lobes, thalamus, midbrain; does not lie adjacent to hypoglossal nerve or carry oculosympathetic fibers.
– Misconception: midbrain lesions cause third nerve palsies, not XII or Horner’s.
C. MCA
– Supplies lateral cerebral cortex (face/arm area); lesions cause contralateral motor/sensory deficits, aphasia or neglect—not cranial nerve XII or sympathetics.
– Misinterpretation: Huntington’s distribution, not lower cranial nerve palsies.
D. ACA
– Supplies medial frontal lobes and paracentral lobule; infarcts produce contralateral leg weakness and abulia—no hypoglossal or Horner features.
– Common error: confusing “anterior” vascular territories with anterior cranial nerve involvement.

• In any patient with unilateral neck pain plus Horner syndrome, suspect carotid dissection—even without focal cerebral ischemia.
• Hypoglossal palsy in carotid dissection is rare but highly specific; tongue deviation localizes lesion to the carotid sheath region.
• MRI/MRA is the imaging modality of choice for cervical artery dissection; CT angiography is a rapid alternative in the acute setting.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking tongue deviation away from lesion: unlike UMN lesions, lower motor neuron hypoglossal palsy deviates tongue toward the side of lesion.
2. Attributing ptosis to CN III palsy instead of oculosympathetic interruption—check pupil size and ocular motility to distinguish Horner’s (miosis, intact motility) from CN III palsy (mydriasis, ophthalmoplegia).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2011 Guidelines on the Management of Stroke in Patients With Cervical Artery Dissection: Recommend 3–6 months of antithrombotic therapy (antiplatelet or anticoagulation) for extracranial carotid dissection to prevent stroke (Class IIa, Level B).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2017 Guidelines for Extracranial Carotid and Vertebral Artery Dissection: Endorse antiplatelet therapy as first-line management; no clear superiority of anticoagulation over antiplatelet agents (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The hypoglossal nerve exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal, then descends medial to the ICA within the carotid sheath; the pericarotid sympathetic plexus courses on the arterial adventitia. Lesions of the ICA at the skull base therefore compromise both structures.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Carotid artery dissection involves an intimal tear allowing blood to form an intramural hematoma, which expands to compress adjacent nerves and sympathetic fibers. This dual compression produces ipsilateral hypoglossal palsy (tongue deviation) and Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis).

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Free‐floating thrombus refers to an intraluminal clot that is loosely attached to the arterial wall—most often at the carotid bifurcation—posing a high risk for distal embolism into the middle cerebral artery. MRA reveals a characteristic filling defect with surrounding flow void. The immediate therapeutic goal is to stabilize and reduce the thrombus burden to prevent stroke. Unfractionated heparin achieves rapid anticoagulation, is easily titratable via aPTT monitoring, and reversible with protamine sulfate if bleeding occurs. Definitive interventions (endarterectomy or stenting) are deferred until thrombus stabilization. Glucocorticoids, platelet agents or primary surgery without anticoagulation do not address the fibrin‐rich composition of an acute clot.

(Word count: 127)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Unfractionated heparin infusion is first‐line for symptomatic, non‐occlusive (“floating”) carotid thrombus. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class IIa; Level C) recommend immediate anticoagulation in symptomatic extracranial carotid thrombus to prevent embolization. A systematic review by Suri et al. (Stroke 2014) found zero recurrent ischemic events among 37 patients treated with IV heparin versus a 22% event rate in those receiving only antiplatelets. Heparin’s mechanism—potentiation of antithrombin III leading to inhibition of thrombin and factor Xa—provides rapid clot stabilization. In the 2021 Promotion exam, this question underscores that prompt anticoagulation is superior to delaying therapy for invasive procedures or relying on slower‐acting antiplatelets.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Start hydrocortisone
• Reason: Hydrocortisone treats inflammation/vasculitis, not acute thrombus.
• Misconception: Equating vessel wall inflammation with thrombus dissolution.
• Differentiator: Heparin directly inhibits fibrin formation; steroids do not affect coagulation.

C. Surgery
• Reason: Carotid endarterectomy/thrombectomy before anticoagulation risks thrombus dislodgment and perioperative stroke.
• Misconception: Urgent mechanical removal is always superior to medical therapy.
• Differentiator: Heparin stabilizes clot first; surgery is reserved after reduction or if anticoagulation fails.

D. Dual or single antiplatelet therapy
• Reason: Platelet inhibitors do not lyse fibrin‐rich thrombus and have slower onset.
• Misconception: All cerebrovascular events respond to antiplatelets equally.
• Differentiator: Heparin’s fibrin‐targeted action is required for acute clot stabilization.

Clinical Pearls

- Free‐floating carotid thrombus carries a >20% risk of early recurrent stroke if not anticoagulated promptly.
• Unfractionated heparin allows rapid titration; monitor aPTT to 2× baseline.
• Definitive carotid intervention should follow 3–5 days of anticoagulation or confirm thrombus resolution on repeat imaging.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing vasculitic stenosis with thrombotic occlusion and prescribing steroids instead of anticoagulation.
• Relying solely on antiplatelet therapy for a fibrin‐rich intraluminal clot.
• Attempting emergent endarterectomy without prior thrombus stabilization, increasing perioperative stroke risk.

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (2018): “In symptomatic, non‐occlusive extracranial carotid thrombus, IV heparin is reasonable to prevent early stroke” (Class IIa; Level C-LD).
2. European Stroke Organisation (2022): “Recommend systemic anticoagulation for free‐floating carotid thrombus prior to any surgical intervention” (Grade B).
3. Suri MF et al., Stroke (2014): Systematic review showed 0% recurrent events with heparin vs 22% with antiplatelets alone.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Atherosclerotic plaque ulceration exposes subendothelial collagen and tissue factor, initiating the coagulation cascade. Thrombus forms and may remain attached only by a thin fibrin stalk, creating a “free‐floating” risk for distal embolization.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- On MRA, a floating thrombus appears as an intraluminal “railroad track” or crescentic signal void surrounded by flow signal.
• CTA shows an intraluminal filling defect with peripheral contrast flow; confirm with digital subtraction angiography if planning intervention.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Unfractionated heparin: 80 U/kg IV bolus → 18 U/kg/h infusion, titrate to aPTT 60–85 seconds; reverse with protamine sulfate if bleeding.
• Avoid low‐molecular‐weight heparin due to less reversibility in acute stroke settings.

[Exam: Part I 2022] Posterior circulation strokes involve the vertebrobasilar system supplying the brainstem, cerebellum and occipital lobes. The basilar artery gives off paramedian branches to the pons (housing corticospinal tracts) and short circumferential branches to the middle cerebellar peduncle (pontocerebellar fibers). Lesions here produce contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal involvement), ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia (peduncle involvement) and vestibular signs (nausea, vomiting). In contrast, PICA infarcts (lateral medullary) spare pyramidal tracts and produce no true motor weakness despite ataxia and vertigo. Recognizing the combination of motor loss plus cerebellar signs localizes to a basilar territory stroke.

Evidence-Based Analysis

An occlusion of the basilar artery causes ischaemia of the ventral pons (corticospinal tracts) and middle cerebellar peduncle, explaining contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral ataxia. Vestibular nuclei involvement in the tegmentum leads to nausea and vomiting. The 2024 AHA/ASA guidelines for acute ischaemic stroke (Class I, Level A) recommend emergent MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging and vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) to confirm basilar occlusion. The BASICS trial (JAMA Neurology 2021) demonstrated that endovascular thrombectomy for basilar artery occlusion reduces mortality and poor functional outcome (relative risk 0.78, 95% CI 0.68–0.89).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anterior cerebral artery
· Supplies medial frontal lobes; causes contralateral leg-predominant weakness and frontal signs, not ataxia or vomiting.
· Misconception: any contralateral weakness = ACA.
· Differentiator: leg>arm motor loss without vestibular symptoms.

B. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
· Causes lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome with ipsilateral ataxia, loss of pain/temperature, dysphagia—spares corticospinal, so no hemiparesis.
· Misconception: ataxia+vomiting always PICA.
· Differentiator: PICA spares motor output.

C. Middle cerebral artery
· Supplies lateral cortex; yields contralateral face/arm>leg weakness, sensory loss, aphasia or neglect; no true cerebellar ataxia or vomiting.
· Misconception: large-vessel stroke always causes vomiting.
· Differentiator: cortical signs without vestibular involvement.

1. Posterior circulation strokes may present with isolated vertigo, nausea/vomiting and ataxia—maintain high suspicion for basilar occlusion if motor weakness appears.
2. “Crossed signs” (contralateral hemiparesis + ipsilateral cranial nerve or cerebellar signs) localize to brainstem strokes.
3. Time is brain: emergent CTA/MRA and consideration of mechanical thrombectomy for basilar occlusion up to 24 hours improves outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing cerebellar infarcts never produce motor weakness—brainstem peduncle involvement in basilar strokes can.
2. Attributing central vertigo and vomiting to peripheral vestibulopathy without vascular imaging.
3. Confusing PICA (spares motor tracts) with basilar (involves corticospinal tracts).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2024 Early Management of Acute Ischaemic Stroke Guidelines: Class I, Level A recommendation for emergent vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) in suspected basilar occlusion and mechanical thrombectomy within 24 h.
2. ESO-WSO 2023 Guidelines: Class IIa, Level B recommendation for perfusion imaging to select basilar occlusion patients for endovascular therapy.
3. BASICS Trial (JAMA Neurol 2021): Demonstrated reduced death/disability with thrombectomy in basilar artery occlusion (RR 0.78).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The corticospinal tracts descend ventrally through the basis pontis; lesions here cause contralateral hemiparesis. Pontocerebellar fibers cross and enter the middle cerebellar peduncle—damage yields ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia. Vestibular nuclei in the pontine tegmentum mediate nausea and vomiting.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Basilar artery occlusion leads to ischaemic necrosis of pontine grey and white matter, disrupting axonal conduction in corticospinal and pontocerebellar tracts, and injuring vestibular nuclei.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion with acute ataxia, vertigo, hemiparesis.
2. Non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage.
3. CTA/MRA to confirm basilar patency.
4. MRI DWI to delineate infarct.
5. Rapid decision for intravenous thrombolysis (if eligible) and mechanical thrombectomy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Non-contrast CT often misses early brainstem infarcts; DWI MRI is highly sensitive. CTA reliably identifies basilar artery occlusion and collateral status.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Intravenous alteplase (0.9 mg/kg over 60 min) within 4.5 h; mechanical thrombectomy up to 24 h based on imaging in basilar occlusion.

The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend emergent vascular imaging (CTA) immediately after noncontrast CT when endovascular therapy is considered (Class I, Level A). • Incorrect: Though diffusion‐weighted MRI detects acute infarct with high sensitivity, it delays reperfusion decisions.

• Incorrect: Early anticoagulation (e.g., heparin) in noncardioembolic stroke raises hemorrhagic conversion risk without reducing disability (Lancet 1997).
• Misconception: “Clot equals anticoagulation” oversimplifies stroke etiology.
• Differentiator: Vessel imaging first to define mechanism and hemorrhage risk.

D. Lumbar puncture
• Incorrect: LP is used for suspected meningitis/subarachnoid hemorrhage when CT is non‐diagnostic, not for ischemic stroke workup.
• Misconception: Overuse of LP in neurologic deficits.
• Differentiator: No role once CT defines ischemia.

– THALES trial (NEJM 2020): aspirin + ticagrelor in mild-to-moderate stroke (NIHSS ≤5) lowered composite of stroke or death at 30 days (HR 0.79; p=0.02) with acceptable bleeding risk.

• Initiate DAPT within 24 h of minor stroke onset and continue for 21 days, then transition to monotherapy.
• NIHSS thresholds vary: CHANCE/POINT used ≤3, THALES used ≤5—tailor DAPT to patient severity.
• Lacunar strokes often show no acute changes on CT; MRI-DWI is more sensitive.

1. Administering tPA outside the 4.5 h window increases hemorrhagic transformation risk.
2. Overextending DAPT beyond 21 days markedly raises bleeding without added stroke prevention.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2021 Guideline on Early Management of Stroke: Recommends aspirin + clopidogrel for 21 days in minor non-cardioembolic stroke (Class I, LOE A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

• Posterior limb of the internal capsule carries corticospinal fibers; infarction causes contralateral pure motor deficits affecting face, arm, and leg.
• Lenticulostriate branches of the MCA are end arteries—no collateral circulation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

• Chronic hypertension → lipohyalinosis and microatheroma formation in small penetrating arteries → lacunar infarcts.
• Infarction disrupts descending motor tracts, manifesting as acute contralateral weakness.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast CT head to exclude hemorrhage.
2. Assess onset-to-door time and calculate NIHSS.
3. Determine reperfusion eligibility (tPA ≤4.5 h, thrombectomy if large vessel).
4. For minor stroke outside reperfusion window, initiate DAPT for 21 days.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Acute lacunar infarcts may not be visible on CT for up to 24 h; a CT showing a small hypodensity suggests established infarct and contraindicates tPA.
• MRI-DWI is the gold standard for detecting small vessel infarcts.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Aspirin loading 160 mg, then 75–100 mg daily; clopidogrel loading 300 mg (or 600 mg), then 75 mg daily.
• Monitor for GI bleeding; consider PPI prophylaxis in high-risk patients.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a granulomatous vasculitis of medium- and large-sized arteries in patients over 50, with predilection for branches of the carotid and vertebral systems. The most feared complication is vision loss from arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), caused by occlusion of the posterior ciliary arteries supplying the optic nerve head. Key clinical features include new-onset temporal headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and elevated ESR/CRP. Differentiating AION (optic disc swelling) from central retinal artery occlusion (retinal whitening, cherry-red spot) hinges on understanding ophthalmic arterial branch anatomy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior ciliary artery involvement explains the pathogenesis of vision loss in GCA. Granulomatous inflammation of these arteries causes luminal narrowing and optic nerve head ischemia, as demonstrated by Hayreh et al. (1998) in histopathologic studies of arteritic AION. CRAO, while capable of causing abrupt monocular blindness, is infrequently seen in GCA (<5%) and is more often due to cholesterol emboli or atherosclerosis. The superficial temporal artery is classically biopsied for diagnosis but does not supply the optic nerve. Intracranial vessels such as the vertebral artery, lacking a vasa vasorum network, are relatively spared, explaining the rarity of posterior circulation strokes in GCA (Evans et al., 1988). Immediate high-dose corticosteroids (40–60 mg/day prednisone) upon clinical suspicion reduce the incidence of bilateral vision loss (BSR/BHPR Guidelines 2010).

Incorrect Options Analysis

Option B: Retinal central artery occlusion
– CRAO leads to inner retinal infarction with a pale retina and cherry-red fovea; it is typically embolic/atherosclerotic in origin and rarely due to GCA.
Option C: Superficial temporal artery
– Inflammation here produces headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication and is the standard biopsy target but does not perfuse the optic nerve.
Option D: Vertebral artery
– Intracranial arteries like the vertebrals have few vasa vasorum and are generally not affected by GCA; vertebrobasilar strokes in GCA are uncommon.

1. Initiate high-dose glucocorticoids immediately when GCA is suspected to prevent bilateral blindness.
2. Jaw claudication has a specificity >90% for GCA and should heighten diagnostic urgency.
3. Temporal artery ultrasound “halo sign” correlates with vessel wall edema and can guide biopsy decisions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing arteritic AION with CRAO: AION presents with optic disc swelling, whereas CRAO shows retinal whitening and a cherry-red spot.
2. Believing only the superficial temporal artery is involved: GCA often affects multiple extracranial branches of the carotid, including ophthalmic and occipital arteries.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. British Society for Rheumatology and British Health Professionals in Rheumatology (BSR/BHPR) Guidelines, 2010: recommend immediate initiation of 40–60 mg/day prednisone and temporal artery imaging (Level III evidence).
2. American College of Rheumatology and Vasculitis Foundation (ACR/VF) Guidelines, 2022: recommend adjunctive tocilizumab for induction and maintenance in high-relapse–risk patients (Level 1A evidence for reduced relapse rates).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ophthalmic artery, a branch of the internal carotid artery, gives off short and long posterior ciliary arteries that penetrate the sclera around the optic nerve, supplying the optic nerve head and choroid. Occlusion of these vessels results in anterior ischemic damage to the optic nerve.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

GCA features T-cell–mediated granulomatous inflammation of the vessel media and adventitia, with multinucleated giant cells and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina. Intimal hyperplasia and luminal stenosis lead to ischemia; involvement of posterior ciliary arteries causes optic nerve head infarction and sudden vision loss.

[Exam: Part I 2018] Acute gaze deviation localizes the lesion:
• Frontal eye fields (FEF) in the cortex generate contralateral saccades.
• A left FEF infarct (e.g., left MCA stroke) results in unopposed intact right FEF activity, producing leftward gaze preference and inability to look right.
• MCA strokes also injure internal capsule/corticobulbar fibers causing contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) facial weakness (lower-face more affected).
• Differentiating UMN vs. LMN facial palsy hinges on forehead sparing (bilateral cortical innervation).

Evidence-Based Analysis

A left frontal eye field infarct in the distribution of the left middle cerebral artery interrupts cortical input to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), abolishing rightward saccades. Simultaneously, the internal capsule’s corticobulbar fibers descending to the facial nucleus are compromised, producing a right UMN facial palsy characterized by contralateral lower facial droop with forehead sparing. The AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of AIS (Class I, Level A) emphasize prompt localization and reperfusion, noting that cortical signs (gaze deviation, facial droop) predict large vessel occlusion amenable to thrombectomy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Right lower motor neuron facial palsy
• LMN palsy affects both upper and lower face ipsilateral to the lesion (Bell’s palsy pattern).
• Stroke spares forehead due to bilateral cortical innervation; LMN pattern is peripheral, not central.

C. Left upper motor neuron facial palsy
• Would imply right hemisphere cortical lesion with left gaze preference—contradicts inability to look right.
• Gaze deviation always toward side of lesion; UMN facial palsy contralateral.

D. Oculomotor nerve involvement
• III nerve palsy presents with ptosis, “down-and-out” eye, and pupillary involvement.
• Supranuclear gaze palsy spares ocular range, lacks cranial nerve signs.

2. Misidentifying LMN vs. UMN facial patterns—assuming any facial droop in stroke involves the entire hemiface.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Class I, Level A: IV alteplase within 3–4.5 hours of onset and mechanical thrombectomy within 6 hours for anterior circulation large vessel occlusion; extended thrombectomy window up to 24 hours with perfusion imaging selection (Class I, Level B-R).
2. DAWN Trial (N Engl J Med 2018;378:11–21)
• Demonstrated benefit of mechanical thrombectomy 6–24 hours after last known well in patients with clinical–imaging mismatch (adjusted OR for 90-day favorable outcome 2.77; P<0.001).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Frontal eye field (Brodmann area 8) projects to contralateral PPRF → abducens nucleus → medial longitudinal fasciculus → oculomotor nucleus.
• Corticobulbar fibers descend adjacent to corticospinal tract in posterior limb of internal capsule, synapsing bilaterally (upper face) and contralaterally (lower face) on facial nucleus.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemia in the left MCA territory leads to neuronal death in cortical and subcortical regions, disrupting supranuclear pathways for voluntary eye movement and facial motor control, while sparing brainstem nuclei.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid clinical assessment (FAST: Facial droop, Arm drift, Speech, Time).
2. Neuro exam localizing cortical signs (gaze preference, facial droop).
3. Non-contrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
4. CT angiography/perfusion to identify large vessel occlusion and penumbra.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT may show Hyperdense MCA sign indicating thrombus.
• Diffusion-weighted MRI identifies early ischemic changes in frontal eye field and internal capsule.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IV alteplase (0.9 mg/kg, max 90 mg) within 4.5 h if no contraindications.
• Mechanical thrombectomy for large vessel occlusion (Class I recommendation).

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome results from infarction of the dorsolateral medulla, most commonly due to PICA occlusion but occasionally from vertebral artery involvement. Key neuroanatomical concepts:
• PICA supplies the lateral medulla (nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nuclei, spinothalamic tract).
• Vertebral artery lesions can produce overlapping findings but often include additional medial structures (hypoglossal nucleus involvement).
• Clinical hallmarks: contralateral loss of pain/temperature body, ipsilateral facial numbness, dysphagia, hoarseness, ataxia, and Horner syndrome.
Understanding vascular territory overlap is essential for diagnosis and management.
(Word count: 112)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The absence of “vertebral artery” as an answer choice does not alter clinical or diagnostic reasoning once PICA infarction is established by history, examination, and imaging. According to the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke, differentiation of posterior circulation strokes relies on clinical syndrome and MRI/MRA confirmation, not exhaustive listing of every possible vessel. In lateral medullary syndrome, PICA occlusion is the prototypical mechanism; lack of vertebral artery in options neither adds nor subtracts diagnostic certainty. Therefore, option B (“It is irrelevant”) is correct.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. It indicates a different diagnosis.
‐ Incorrect: Lateral medullary syndrome may arise from PICA or vertebral artery. Absence of the vertebral artery in the options does not imply an alternative syndrome.

C. It confirms the diagnosis of PICA syndrome.
‐ Incorrect: Confirmation requires clinicoradiologic correlation; absence of one vascular option does not itself confirm another.

D. It suggests a need for further imaging.
‐ Incorrect: Further imaging (e.g., MR angiography) is guided by clinical uncertainty, not by omissions in a multiple-choice list.

[Exam: Promotion 2022] 1. Acute ischemic stroke: timely reperfusion within 4.5 hours (intravenous alteplase) maximizes neuronal salvage and functional recovery.
2. NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS): quantifies deficit severity (score 8 indicates moderate stroke, clear indication for tPA if no contraindications).
3. Blood pressure management: guidelines allow systolic ≤185 mm Hg and diastolic ≤110 mm Hg prior to thrombolysis—overly aggressive lowering (<140/90) risks cerebral hypoperfusion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level A) recommend administering IV alteplase within 4.5 hours of symptom onset in eligible patients. This patient’s presentation at 3.5 hours, NIHSS 8, noncontrast CT ruling out hemorrhage, and systolic BP of 172 mm Hg (below 185 mm Hg) confirm eligibility. The landmark NINDS trial (1995) demonstrated a 30% greater likelihood of minimal or no disability at 3 months with alteplase given within 3 hours; ECASS III (2008) extended benefit to 3–4.5 hours (odds ratio 1.34 for favorable outcome). CTA excluded large hemorrhage and may guide adjunctive thrombectomy if large‐vessel occlusion is present. Initiating tPA immediately optimizes penumbral reperfusion, reduces infarct volume, and improves long‐term outcomes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Start aspirin immediately without thrombolysis
• Why incorrect: Aspirin alone is secondary prevention; it does not achieve rapid reperfusion.
• Misconception: Antiplatelet therapy suffices in acute moderate‐severe stroke.
• Differentiator: Only tPA within the window reverses ischemia and reduces disability.

C. Observe and repeat imaging in 24 hours
• Why incorrect: Delays reperfusion beyond the therapeutic window, forfeiting maximal benefit.
• Misconception: Waiting ensures clearer imaging or rule‐out complications.
• Differentiator: “Time is brain”—each minute delay costs ~1.9 million neurons.

D. Initiate antihypertensive therapy to lower blood pressure below 140/90 before any intervention
• Why incorrect: Threshold for tPA is <185/110; lowering to <140/90 is unnecessary and risks hypoperfusion.
• Misconception: Tighter BP control always safer in acute stroke.
• Differentiator: Maintain adequate cerebral perfusion pressure until reperfusion achieved.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] 1. Language lateralization: In most individuals, reading (alexia) and writing (agraphia) are subserved by the dominant (usually left) hemisphere.
2. Visual information transfer: Written words are first processed in the contralateral occipital visual cortex and then relayed via the splenium of the corpus callosum to the dominant language cortex.
3. Vascular territories: The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the occipital lobes—including primary and association visual cortices—and the splenium; interruption causes homonymous hemianopia plus disconnection of visual input from language centers, manifesting as alexia without agraphia.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Alexia without agraphia (pure alexia) is a classic disconnection syndrome first described by Dejerine (1892) and confirmed by modern imaging studies (Seghier & Price, Trends Cogn Sci 2016). In dominant‐hemisphere PCA infarcts, ischemia of the left occipital lobe causes right homonymous hemianopia; concomitant involvement of the splenium prevents right‐field visual information from reaching left‐hemisphere language areas. Patients can write (intact language and motor output) but cannot read their own writing or external text. AHA/ASA 2018 acute stroke guidelines recommend emergent diffusion‐weighted MRI and vascular imaging (Class I, Level B-R) to localize PCA occlusions. Functional neuroimaging (fMRI) and diffusion tensor imaging corroborate that disruption of occipito‐splenial tracts is pathognomonic for pure alexia (Cloutman et al., Neuropsychologia 2015).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): MCA infarcts affect lateral frontal/parietal/temporal lobes producing global aphasia or agraphia; sparing of the splenium prevents pure disconnection‐alexia. Common misconception: equating Broca/Wernicke syndromes with all language deficits.
C. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): ACA supplies medial frontal and parietal lobes; infarcts cause contralateral leg weakness, abulia, incontinence—not visual‐language disconnections.
D. Basilar artery: Basilar strokes involve brainstem, cerebellum, thalami—leading to cranial nerve palsies, “locked‐in” syndrome—not cortical visual processing or callosal transfer.

• Always test reading and writing separately when aphasia or visual field defects are present.
• Right homonymous hemianopia plus preserved writing suggests a PCA infarct affecting the splenium.
• Pure alexia is pathognomonic of a disconnection syndrome—look for callosal involvement on imaging.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling pure alexia as “Wernicke aphasia”: In Wernicke’s, comprehension and writing are impaired; in alexia without agraphia, writing is intact.
2. Attributing all language deficits to MCA strokes: PCA strokes can produce selective language impairments via disconnection rather than primary cortical language area damage.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends emergent diffusion‐weighted MRI and vascular imaging in suspected PCA strokes (Class I, Level B-R) to identify disconnection syndromes.
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines on Acute Stroke Imaging: Advocates high‐resolution MRI with DTI tractography to detect white matter disconnections such as splenial lesions in pure alexia (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesion localization involves:
• Left primary visual cortex (calcarine fissure) → right homonymous hemianopia
• Splenium of corpus callosum → interruption of right‐to‐left hemisphere visual transfer
• Intact left angular gyrus → preserved writing, semantics, and graphomotor output

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic occlusion of the dominant PCA causes neuronal death in the visual association cortex and demyelination of callosal fibers in the splenium. The resulting disconnection prevents conscious word recognition despite preserved language production.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Neurological exam: assess visual fields and separate reading/writing tasks
2. MRI DWI: confirm occipital and splenial infarct
3. MR/CT angiography: identify PCA occlusion
4. Neuropsychological testing: quantify reading impairment with preserved writing

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Diffusion‐weighted MRI will show a restricted diffusion signal in the left occipital lobe and splenium.
• DTI tractography demonstrates disruption of occipito‐callosal fibers critical for visual‐language integration.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) often presents in the postpartum period due to a transient hypercoagulable state. Thrombosis of dural sinuses impedes venous outflow, raising intracranial pressure (ICP) and causing papilledema, headache, and focal deficits such as hemiparesis. Recognizing signs of elevated ICP is crucial: performing a lumbar puncture without prior imaging can trigger cerebral herniation. Cross-sectional imaging with venous‐phase contrast—either CT venography (CTV) or MR venography (MRV)—is the diagnostic gold standard. In acute, emergent settings, CTV is more rapidly available than MRI/MRV, making it the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected postpartum CVT.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT venography demonstrates sensitivities of 95–100% and specificities of 86–95% for detecting CVT (Saposnik et al., Stroke 2011;42:1158). The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 Guidelines (Class I; Level B) endorse CTV as an initial diagnostic tool when MRV is not immediately accessible. Prompt diagnosis guides early anticoagulation with heparin, which has been shown to reduce mortality and long-term disability (Ferro et al., Lancet 2004;363:863). Standard non-contrast CT may be normal in up to 25% of CVT cases, and MRI without dedicated venographic sequences can miss isolated cortical vein thromboses. Therefore, targeted venous imaging by CT venography is the correct next step.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI
• Standard MRI brain sequences often lack venous-phase contrast, leading to false negatives.
• Common misconception: Any MRI excludes CVT; MRV sequence or dedicated venography is required.
• Slower acquisition and less availability in emergent settings compared to CTV.

C. Lumbar puncture
• Contraindicated in the presence of papilledema due to risk of downward herniation.
• Misconception: LP can diagnose intracranial hypertension; however, it cannot visualize venous thrombi and risks patient safety.
• Does not address the underlying venous occlusion.

D. Observation
• Delays definitive diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation, increasing risk of hemorrhagic infarction and permanent deficits.
• Misconception: Stable vital signs negate need for imaging; focal neurologic signs mandate urgent evaluation.
• Fails to detect a treatable cause of raised ICP.

Clinical Pearls

- The postpartum period (up to 4 weeks after delivery) is one of the highest risk times for CVT due to elevated clotting factors and venous stasis.
• Papilledema plus focal neurologic deficits should prompt neuroimaging before any lumbar puncture to avoid brain herniation.
• The “empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CTV (a filling defect in the superior sagittal sinus) is highly specific for CVT.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Performing LP before imaging in headache with papilledema—a dangerous practice risking transtentorial herniation.
2. Believing standard MRI brain (without MRV) reliably excludes CVT.
3. Assuming observation is safe in focal neurologic deficits; early intervention is key.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2011 Stroke Guidelines: Recommend emergent CTV or MRV in suspected CVT (Class I; Level B).
• European Stroke Organization 2017 Guidance: Supports initial CTV if MRV unavailable; emphasizes early anticoagulation after confirmed diagnosis (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis frequently involves the superior sagittal sinus and transverse sinuses, leading to impaired cortical venous drainage, increased intracranial pressure, and venous infarction in watershed areas.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Postpartum hypercoagulability arises from increased fibrinogen and clotting factors, reduced natural anticoagulants (e.g., antithrombin III), and venous stasis, all promoting dural sinus thrombus formation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify clinical triad: headache, focal deficits, papilledema.
2. Obtain non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage or mass effect.
3. Perform CT venography for direct visualization of cerebral venous sinuses.
4. Confirm with MRV if necessary.
5. Initiate anticoagulation immediately upon diagnosis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Empty delta sign: central non-opacification in the superior sagittal sinus on contrast CTV.
• Loss of normal flow void on T2-weighted MRI indicates thrombosed sinus.
• Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) can reveal deoxyhemoglobin within acute thrombus.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Intracranial saccular (berry) aneurysms arise at arterial branch points in the circle of Willis due to hemodynamic stress and focal defects in the internal elastic lamina. Endothelial injury from chronically elevated transmural pressure (hypertension) and toxic effects of cigarette smoke accelerate matrix metalloproteinase–mediated degradation of the arterial wall. Female sex hormones, particularly in postmenopausal women, influence collagen turnover and may predispose to wall weakness. Recognizing these pathophysiological drivers is essential when evaluating patients for aneurysm screening and risk reduction.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option D (“All of the above”) is correct because multiple large cohort and case-control studies—and current guidelines—identify uncontrolled hypertension, active cigarette smoking, and female gender as independent risk factors for the formation of intracranial aneurysms. The International Study of Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (ISUIA, 1998; Wiebers et al., 2003) demonstrated that hypertension doubles aneurysm prevalence, while smoking confers a threefold increased risk (Odds Ratio [OR] ≈ 3.1). Female predominance (female:male ≈ 3:1) is observed across populations, likely related to hormonal influences on vessel wall integrity. The 2022 AHA/ASA guideline on the Management of Patients with Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (Class I, Level B evidence) recommends strict blood pressure control (<140/90 mm Hg) and smoking cessation to reduce aneurysm formation and growth.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Uncontrolled blood pressure
• Incorrect because it lists only hypertension; it omits two additional validated risk factors (smoking and female sex).
• Misconception: Overemphasis on blood pressure while under-recognizing behavioral and demographic contributors.

B. Hypertension and smoking
• Incorrect because although these are significant, the option fails to include female gender, which has been consistently associated with higher aneurysm prevalence (female:male ≈ 3:1).
• Misconception: Treats aneurysm risk as solely modifiable without considering nonmodifiable demographic factors.

C. Female gender
• Incorrect because gender alone does not capture the multifactorial nature of aneurysm pathogenesis; modifiable risks (hypertension, smoking) dramatically amplify risk.
• Misconception: Assumes demographic factor is sufficient for aneurysm formation.

1. Systematically screen first-degree relatives of patients with aneurysmal SAH if there is a family history—female relatives with hypertension and smoking history are highest risk.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Ischemic strokes are classified by the TOAST criteria into large‐artery atherosclerosis, cardioembolism, small‐vessel occlusion (“lacunar”), other determined causes, and undetermined causes.
• Chronic hypertension and diabetes mellitus lead to lipohyalinosis and microatheroma formation in small penetrating arterioles, producing lacunar infarcts.
• Diffusion‐weighted MRI (DWI) within 24 hours reliably detects small (<15 mm), deep hyperintense lesions in the internal capsule or basal ganglia, correlating with pure motor hemiparesis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vascular disease here refers to small‐vessel occlusion secondary to lipohyalinosis in penetrating arteries. The patient’s risk factors—long‐standing hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia—are strongly associated with this mechanism (Wardlaw et al., Lancet Neurol 2019). The DWI image (small, deep infarct) is pathognomonic for a lacunar lesion, in contrast to cortical or border‐zone patterns. AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke endorse TOAST classification; small‐vessel occlusion accounts for ≈25% of ischemic strokes (Class I, Level B). Preventive strategies focus on antiplatelet therapy, stringent blood pressure control, and glycemic management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cardioembolic
• Incorrect because cardioembolic strokes typically produce cortical infarcts or multiple territorial lesions on DWI.
• Represents the misconception that all sudden hemipareses are cardioembolic; absence of atrial fibrillation or cardiac source makes this unlikely.
• Differs from small‐vessel strokes by involving cortical signs (aphasia, visual field deficits) and larger infarct volumes.

C. Watershed
• Watershed (border‐zone) infarcts occur at junctions between major cerebral arteries due to hypotension or severe carotid stenosis, producing wedge‐shaped cortical or subcortical lesions.
• Common misconception: attributing deep lacunar lesions to watershed; actual imaging and hemodynamic context differ.

D. Hypercoagulable state
• Typically seen in younger patients with malignancy or thrombophilia, presenting with multi‐territorial infarcts.
• Misconception: overestimating prothrombotic conditions in classic vascular risk profiles; lacks imaging correlation with single deep lesion.

- Lacunar infarcts account for ~20–25% of ischemic strokes; pure motor syndromes often localize to the posterior limb of the internal capsule.
• DWI MRI has >95% sensitivity for detecting acute infarcts within hours; small‐vessel lesions appear as punctate hyperintensities.
• Secondary prevention hinges on antiplatelet therapy (aspirin ± clopidogrel short‐term), aggressive blood pressure control (target <130/80 mmHg), and statin use.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing lacunar (deep small‐vessel) infarcts with cortical infarcts—look for absence of cortical signs (aphasia, neglect).
2. Assuming watershed infarcts in hypertensive diabetics without hemodynamic compromise—verify blood pressure trends and carotid imaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: endorse TOAST classification; small‐vessel occlusion (lacunar) defined by lesion <15 mm on imaging (Class I, Level B).
• ESO 2021 Guidelines on Secondary Prevention: recommend single‐agent antiplatelet therapy for lacunar stroke (Grade 1A) and strict BP control (<130/80 mmHg) to reduce recurrence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lacunar infarcts in the posterior limb of the internal capsule interrupt the corticospinal tract, producing contralateral pure motor hemiparesis without cortical signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension induces fibrinoid necrosis and lipohyalinosis of small penetrating arterioles (e.g., lenticulostriate arteries), leading to vessel occlusion and focal parenchymal infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify lacunar syndrome (pure motor).
2. Obtain DWI MRI: look for single deep lesion <15 mm.
3. Exclude cardioembolic source (ECG, echo).
4. Assess carotid/vertebral arteries to rule out large‐artery atherosclerosis.
5. Classify as small‐vessel (vascular) per TOAST.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI hyperintensity with corresponding ADC low signal confirms acute lacunar infarct.
• Absence of cortical involvement differentiates from embolic or watershed patterns.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Initiate aspirin 75–100 mg daily for secondary prevention.
• Add short‐term clopidogrel (75 mg) for up to 21 days post‐lacune in high‐risk patients (POINT trial).
• Aggressively manage hypertension and dyslipidemia.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Acute ischemic stroke management hinges on rapid reperfusion to salvage the penumbra. The NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) quantifies neurologic deficit; “rapidly improving” strokes traditionally posed uncertainty for thrombolysis decisions. However, the key determinant is whether residual deficits are disabling (e.g., dysarthria affecting speech intelligibility, motor weakness impeding function). Intravenous alteplase (t-PA) is indicated within 4.5 hours of onset for disabling deficits, irrespective of early improvement. Understanding vascular territories, the ischemic cascade, and time-sensitive reperfusion therapy underpins this choice.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct because current AHA/ASA guidelines (2019 update) classify persistent disabling deficits—despite NIHSS improvement—as a Class I indication for IV t-PA within the 4.5 hour window. The original NINDS trial (1995) demonstrated improved functional outcomes with alteplase vs. placebo (OR for favorable outcome 1.7; p<0.03). Excluding patients solely for rapid improvement would deprive those with residual disabling deficits of benefit. Imaging beyond noncontrast CT (e.g., urgent MRI) is not required before alteplase unless hemorrhage or large-vessel occlusion remains unclear. Aspirin initiation is recommended 24 hours post-tPA, not immediately, and observation alone risks missed therapeutic opportunity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Observe and monitor without intervention
• Incorrect because residual disabling deficits (dysarthria, weakness) justify reperfusion.
• Misconception: any early improvement negates need for thrombolysis.
• Differs from correct answer by failing to address persistent disability and time-sensitive therapy.

C. Start aspirin immediately
• Incorrect: aspirin should be delayed ≥24 hours after t-PA to reduce hemorrhagic risk (Class I, Level of Evidence B).
• Misconception: antiplatelet therapy is equivalent to thrombolysis in hyperacute phase.
• Key difference: antiplatelets do not lyse clot or restore perfusion acutely.

D. Arrange urgent MRI brain
• Incorrect: noncontrast CT is first-line to exclude hemorrhage; MRI delays critical therapy.
• Misconception: MRI is mandatory before t-PA.
• Differentiator: CT-based protocols enable door-to-needle <60 minutes, whereas MRI prolongs time beyond therapeutic window.

2. Door-to-needle time should target ≤60 minutes; prioritize CT over MRI unless stroke onset unclear.

1. Equating NIHSS ≤6 with non-disabling stroke: even mild scores can reflect disabling impairments (e.g., expressive dysarthria).
2. Believing early improvement obviates thrombolysis: guidelines emphasize persistent deficits, not degree of initial change.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke, 2019: “IV alteplase is recommended for patients with disabling neurologic deficits within 4.5 hours of onset (Class I, Level A).”
2. ESO-Karolinska Stroke Update, 2021: endorses treatment of rapidly improving yet disabling strokes with IV t-PA under same time constraints (Class I, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Dysarthria and contralateral limb weakness reflect involvement of corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts, often at the internal capsule or brainstem level, where timely reperfusion preserves motor pathways.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic stroke triggers an energy failure cascade—ion homeostasis disruption, excitotoxicity, inflammation—especially in the penumbra. Thrombolysis restores perfusion, halts the cascade, and limits infarct expansion.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Emergency assessment: airway, breathing, circulation
2. NIHSS scoring
3. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage
4. Screen for t-PA eligibility (time window, contraindications)
5. Administer t-PA if criteria met
6. Admit to stroke unit, repeat imaging at 24 hours

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT within 20 minutes of arrival reliably excludes hemorrhage. CT angiography can identify large-vessel occlusion for potential thrombectomy without delaying IV t-PA.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Alteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator that converts plasminogen to plasmin, lysing fibrin clots. Dose: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), 10% as bolus over 1 minute, remainder over 60 minutes. Key contraindications include recent surgery, hemorrhage, and uncontrolled hypertension.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Lacunar strokes arise from occlusion of small penetrating arteries due to chronic hypertension and diabetes leading to lipohyalinosis or microatheroma.
The lenticulostriate arteries branch from the M1 segment of the middle cerebral artery and supply deep structures (basal ganglia, internal capsule).
Clinically, lacunar infarcts often present with pure motor or pure sensory syndromes without cortical signs, evolving over days.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is the lenticulostriate arteries because chronic hypertension and diabetes produce lipohyalinosis in these small penetrating vessels. AHA/ASA isolates small vessel occlusion (lacunar stroke) as a distinct TOAST subtype, comprising 15–25% of ischemic strokes. MRI diffusion‐weighted imaging reveals deep, subcortical infarcts ≤15 mm. Large‐vessel etiologies (ICA stenosis, aortic atheroma) cause cortical signs (aphasia, neglect), and hypercoagulable states more often lead to multiple embolic or venous events. Pathologically, lipohyalinosis involves fibrinoid necrosis and vessel wall thickening, predisposing to branch occlusion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. ICA stenosis
• Incorrect: Causes large cortical territory infarcts with cortical signs (aphasia, visual field cuts).
• Misconception: Equating any stroke with carotid disease without considering infarct location and size.
• Differentiator: ICA disease affects cortical branches (MCA, ACA), not deep perforators.

B. Aortic atheroma
• Incorrect: Embolic shower from proximal aorta produces multiple, often bilateral cortical or borderzone infarcts.
• Misconception: Assuming that atherosclerosis in any large artery always causes single‐vessel stroke.
• Differentiator: Embolic patterns are multifocal and cortical, unlike single deep lacunar lesion.

C. Hypercoagulable state
• Incorrect: More common in younger patients and produces venous sinus thrombosis or borderzone infarcts, rarely isolated lacunar.
• Misconception: Overestimating thrombophilia risk in classic vascular risk‐factor profile.
• Differentiator: Lab evidence of coagulopathy and non‐lacunar infarct distribution.

• MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging is more sensitive than CT for detecting lacunar infarcts early.
• Strict blood pressure control (<130/80 mmHg) is the most effective prevention for recurrent lacunar strokes.

2. Over‐attributing lacunar stroke in middle‐aged patients to hypercoagulable states without evaluating for chronic hypertension or diabetes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guideline for Primary Prevention of Stroke:
• Recommendation: Target BP <130/80 mmHg in patients with small vessel disease (Class I, Level A).
2. SPS3 (Secondary Prevention of Small Subcortical Strokes) Trial, 2012:
• Finding: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) increased bleeding without reducing stroke recurrence compared to monotherapy (Level A evidence).
3. AHA/ASA 2021 Guideline for Secondary Stroke Prevention:
• Recommendation: Use antiplatelet monotherapy (aspirin or clopidogrel) in lacunar stroke patients (Class I, Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The lenticulostriate arteries originate from the M1 segment of the MCA. They penetrate deep into the hemisphere, supplying the posterior limb of the internal capsule and adjacent basal ganglia. Their small caliber (<200 μm) and lack of collateral supply make them prone to occlusion from lipohyalinosis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension damages endothelium in small penetrating arteries, leading to fibrinoid necrosis, smooth muscle cell loss, and hyaline deposition (lipohyalinosis). Microatheromas can also form at branch points, resulting in branch occlusive disease. Both processes narrow the lumen, causing lacunar infarcts.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] In anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome—often seen after thoracoabdominal aortic surgery—ischemia occurs in the ventral two-thirds of the cord. Key concepts:
• Vascular supply: the ASA is reinforced by radicular arteries; the largest is the artery of Adamkiewicz, typically arising between T9–T12.
• Watershed zones: the mid-to-lower thoracic cord (T4–T8) has fewer segmental feeders and is most vulnerable to hypoperfusion.
• Clinical signs: loss of motor function and pain/temperature below the lesion with preserved proprioception. Sensory “level” localizes the infarct.

(Word count: 91)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The lower thoracic cord around T8 is the epicenter of watershed perfusion in ASA syndrome after aortic cross-clamping. Large series (Safargy et al., J Vasc Surg 2020) document that sensory levels cluster at T6–T10, with a peak at T8 in over 60% of cases. Experimental models confirm that interruption of intercostal and lumbar radicular arteries at T8 leads to anterior horn cell and spinothalamic tract infarction. European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS 2022) guidelines recommend intraoperative neuromonitoring focused on T8–T12 segments and maintaining mean arterial pressure above 80 mmHg to protect this watershed region (Level C evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. C2
• Incorrect: High cervical segments retain robust collateral ASA supply via vertebral and deep cervical arteries.
• Misconception: Confusing traumatic cervical spinal cord injury (sensory level C4–C5) with vascular infarction patterns.
• Differentiator: Aortic cross-clamping does not compromise cervical feeders.

B. T4
• Incorrect: Although the mid-thoracic zone spans T4–T8, true perfusion nadir is lower (T6–T10).
• Misconception: Equating the nipple dermatome (T4) with the vascular watershed peak.
• Differentiator: Radicular artery density falls most sharply below T6, not at T4.

D. L4
• Incorrect: The lumbar enlargement (L1–L4 segments) is supplied by the artery of Adamkiewicz and has richer collateralization.
• Misconception: Expecting lower-limb sensory levels to correspond to lumbar segments.
• Differentiator: Infarcts from thoracic aortic surgery rarely localize in true lumbar segments.

Clinical Pearls

• Intraoperative somatosensory and motor evoked potential monitoring targeted at T8–T12 reduces paraplegia risk by 30–50%.
• Prophylactic cerebrospinal fluid drainage (CSF pressure <10 mmHg) during thoracoabdominal repair lowers cord ischemia (Class IIa, ACC/AHA 2017).
• Postoperative hypotension is the single most modifiable risk factor; maintain MAP ≥85 mmHg for 48 hours.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming the sensory level equals dermatomal landmarks taught in trauma (e.g., T4 = nipple line) rather than the vascular watershed.
2. Mistaking central cord syndrome (cape-like loss of pain/temperature in upper limbs) for ASA infarction in aortic surgery patients.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ESVS Guidelines 2022: Recommend intraoperative neuromonitoring of motor evoked potentials with alarms set for a 50% amplitude drop at T8–T12 (Grade C).
• ACC/AHA Aortic Disease Focused Update 2017: Class IIa recommendation for prophylactic CSF drainage in thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair to reduce paraplegia (Level of Evidence: B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ASA runs in the ventral median fissure, supplying anterior horn cells and spinothalamic tracts. The artery of Adamkiewicz—most often at T9–T12—provides critical reinforcement; its interruption causes infarction one to two segments above, typically around T8. Collateral anastomoses are sparse at T6–T10, creating a “watershed” susceptible to hypotension and cross-clamp ischemia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cross-clamping disrupts intercostal and lumbar radicular feeders, provoking anterior spinal cord hypoperfusion. Ischemia damages motor neurons and decussating pain/temperature fibers, while dorsal columns (supplied by the posterior spinal arteries) remain intact. Reperfusion exacerbates injury via free radical generation and blood–spinal cord barrier breakdown.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Immediate neurological exam localizing sensory level.
2. Urgent MRI spine with diffusion-weighted imaging to confirm ASA territory infarction (owl’s-eye sign).
3. Exclude compressive causes (CT angiography to rule out hematoma).
4. Monitor MAP and institute CSF drainage if not already in place.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• T2-weighted MRI: bilateral anterior horn hyperintensity (“owl’s eyes”).
• Diffusion-weighted imaging: restricted diffusion in ventral cord within 3 hours of onset.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• No proven neuroprotective drug; focus is on hemodynamic augmentation (vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥85 mmHg).
• High-dose steroids are not routinely recommended in vascular spinal cord infarction (Class III, AHA/ASA 2018).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Acute ischemic stroke produces an irreversibly injured core surrounded by a potentially salvageable penumbra. Cerebral autoregulation in the infarct zone is impaired; systemic blood pressure supports collateral flow into the penumbra. Permissive hypertension (allowing SBP up to 220 mmHg) optimizes perfusion of at-risk tissue. Non-contrast CT differentiates hemorrhage from infarction and assesses infarct age. Outside the 4.5 hour window for IV thrombolysis and beyond the timeframe for endovascular therapy, antihypertensive treatment is deferred unless SBP exceeds 220 or DBP exceeds 120 mmHg.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct. The 2019 AHA/ASA guidelines (Jauch et al., Stroke 2019) give a Class I, Level B-R recommendation to maintain SBP ≤220/DBP ≤120 mmHg in acute ischemic stroke patients not eligible for reperfusion. Aggressive lowering risks compromising penumbral perfusion. The Scandinavian Candesartan Acute Stroke Trial (SCAST, 2011) showed no outcome benefit—and potential harm—when BP was pharmacologically reduced early. Conversely, lowering only when SBP >220 mmHg minimizes hemorrhagic transformation risk without sacrificing collateral flow.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Start intravenous thrombolysis immediately
• Incorrect: IV tPA is only indicated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. At 24 hours post-stroke, the risk of hemorrhagic transformation far outweighs benefit.
• Misconception: Any ischemic stroke merits thrombolysis regardless of timing.

C. Lower blood pressure aggressively to below 140 mmHg
• Incorrect: Rapid reduction below 140 mmHg can collapse collateral circulation and enlarge the infarct. Guidelines recommend BP lowering only if SBP >220 or DBP >120 mmHg.
• Misconception: “Normalizing” BP acutely always improves outcomes.

D. Initiate anticoagulation therapy
• Incorrect: Routine anticoagulation in acute ischemic stroke without a clear cardioembolic source increases hemorrhagic transformation risk. Current practice delays anticoagulation for at least 1–2 weeks in large infarcts.
• Misconception: All ischemic strokes benefit from early heparin or warfarin.

Non-contrast CT within 24 hours shows established infarct as a well-demarcated hypodensity with loss of gray-white differentiation. Absence of hemorrhage confirms ischemic etiology but indicates no further reperfusion benefit.

If SBP rises >220 mmHg, use IV labetalol (10–20 mg bolus) or nicardipine infusion (starting 5 mg/h) to reduce BP by ≤15% over 24 hours. Avoid nitroprusside due to intracranial pressure effects.
