Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] - Acute ischemic stroke results from arterial occlusion causing neuronal ischemia; rapid reperfusion salvages penumbral tissue.
• The NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) quantifies stroke severity (0–42); scores <5 designate “mild” strokes but do not preclude disabling deficits.
• Intravenous alteplase (tPA) must be administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset to maximize benefit (NINDS, ECASS III).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intravenous tPA is the standard of care for eligible acute ischemic stroke patients within 4.5 hours, regardless of NIHSS if deficits are potentially disabling. The NINDS trial (1995) demonstrated a 30% relative improvement in functional outcome at 90 days (Class I, Level A). ECASS III extended the window to 4.5 hours with maintained efficacy (Aug 2008). AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines state: “IV alteplase is recommended for patients with mild but disabling symptoms” (Class I, LOE A). Although “minor, non-disabling” strokes may be excluded, this NIHSS 3 patient is presumed to have clinically relevant deficits warranting reperfusion.

A. DAPT
• Reason incorrect: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) benefits minor stroke/TIA not treated with thrombolysis (POINT, CHANCE trials), but it is not first‐line when tPA is indicated and within the window.
• Misconception: Equating antiplatelets with reperfusion therapy.

C. Thrombectomy
• Reason incorrect: Mechanical thrombectomy is reserved for large vessel occlusions (ICA/M1) and typically NIHSS ≥6; low NIHSS makes LVO unlikely. CT angiography must document a proximal occlusion before thrombectomy consideration.
• Misconception: All strokes are endovascular candidates.

D. Supportive care and monitoring
• Reason incorrect: Withholding reperfusion in a patient within the tPA window risks infarct expansion and poorer long‐term outcome.
• Misconception: Mild score implies benign course without intervention.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Posterior circulation strokes involve the vertebrobasilar arterial system. Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome results from occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), producing infarction in the dorsolateral medulla. Key neuroanatomical structures affected include the vestibular nuclei (vertigo, nystagmus), spinal trigeminal nucleus (ipsilateral facial pain/temperature loss), spinothalamic tract (contralateral body pain/temperature loss), nucleus ambiguus (dysphagia, hoarseness), and descending sympathetics (ipsilateral Horner syndrome). Clinically, patients present with acute vertigo, dysphagia, ipsilateral facial analgesia, contralateral body analgesia, and ataxia. Differentiation from medial medullary, lateral pontine, and midbrain syndromes hinges on the pattern of cranial nerve involvement and motor vs sensory deficits.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Wallenberg syndrome accurately describes a PICA infarct in the dorsolateral medulla. According to the 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level A), posterior circulation strokes require MRI with DWI for definitive diagnosis; MRA can identify PICA occlusion. Kim et al. (Neurology 2010) analyzed over 100 PICA infarcts, showing that nucleus ambiguus involvement (dysphagia, hoarseness) and dissociated sensory loss (ipsilateral facial, contralateral body) are pathognomonic. Preservation of motor strength differentiates it from medial medullary or basilar pontine lesions. The “don’t pick a PICA horse that can’t eat” mnemonic underscores the unique bulbar signs. Thus, clinical localization and imaging findings converge to confirm Wallenberg syndrome.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Locked-in syndrome
– Incorrect because it stems from ventral pontine (basilar artery) infarction affecting corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts. Patients exhibit quadriplegia and anarthria with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements; sensory function and bulbar signs of PICA lesions are absent.

C. Weber syndrome
– A midbrain ventral lesion (posterior cerebral artery) damaging oculomotor fascicles and cerebral peduncle. Presents with ipsilateral oculomotor palsy (ptosis, “down and out” gaze) and contralateral hemiparesis, without dysphagia, sensory dissociation, or cerebellar signs.

D. Medial medullary syndrome
– Due to vertebral or anterior spinal artery infarct affecting the pyramid (contralateral hemiparesis), medial lemniscus (contralateral proprioception loss), and hypoglossal nucleus (ipsilateral tongue deviation). Lacks nucleus ambiguus signs (dysphagia/hoarseness) and facial pain/temperature deficits.

• The nucleus ambiguus signs (dysphagia, hoarseness) distinguish PICA from AICA strokes (“PICA = palate”).
• Ipsilateral facial pain/temperature loss with contralateral body loss localizes to the lateral medulla.
• MRI DWI is superior to CT for detecting posterior fossa infarcts within the first 24 hours.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing lateral with medial medullary syndrome and expecting motor weakness in Wallenberg syndrome.
2. Attributing facial paralysis to lateral medullary infarct—facial nucleus (VII) lies outside PICA territory.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of AIS: MRI with DWI recommended for posterior circulation strokes; IV alteplase within 4.5 hours applies equally to PICA infarcts (Class I, Level A).
2. BASICS trial (Lancet Neurol 2021): Demonstrated benefit of timely endovascular therapy for basilar artery occlusion, underscoring aggressive reperfusion in posterior circulation strokes (Level II).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The PICA supplies the dorsolateral medulla, including the inferior cerebellar peduncle. Lesion of the spinal trigeminal nucleus disrupts ipsilateral facial pain/temperature, while involvement of the spinothalamic tract causes contralateral body analgesia. Nucleus ambiguus damage leads to dysphagia and loss of the gag reflex.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PICA occlusion—often from vertebral artery dissection or atherothrombotic embolism—causes ischemia in the lateral medulla. Excitotoxic neuronal death in affected nuclei and tracts yields the classic Wallenberg presentation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize acute-onset vertigo, nystagmus, dysphagia, facial sensory loss
2. Perform targeted cranial nerve and sensory exam
3. Obtain MRI brain with DWI and MRA of vertebrobasilar system
4. Confirm PICA territory infarction
5. Assess for IV thrombolysis or endovascular therapy eligibility

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI DWI reveals hyperintense lesion in lateral medulla within hours; CT has low sensitivity for posterior fossa strokes—thin-slice protocols may help but often miss early changes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Acute: IV alteplase if within 4.5-hour window (AHA/ASA 2018).
• Secondary prevention: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days in minor stroke/TIA (CHANCE trial, 2013), high-intensity statin, BP control.

[Exam: Part I 2018] Acute ischemic stroke management revolves around rapid reperfusion to salvage the penumbra and minimize infarct core expansion. Key concepts:
1. Time‐dependent benefit of intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), ideally within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.
2. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage or established large infarction before tPA.
3. NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS)–driven decision: significant deficits (e.g., dense hemiparesis, aphasia) justify tPA even if mild improvement occurs en route.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intravenous tPA remains the only FDA‐approved pharmacologic reperfusion therapy for eligible acute ischemic stroke patients within 4.5 hours of onset. The pivotal NINDS (1995) trial demonstrated a 30% greater favorable outcome at 3 months (Level A evidence). ECASS III (2008) extended the window to 4.5 hours with a similar safety profile (Class I, Level B). AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines recommend administration of IV tPA in patients with mild to moderate neurologic deficits (NIHSS > 4) as long as no contraindications exist, regardless of slight spontaneous improvement. Delaying tPA to obtain a CT angiogram is discouraged if it exceeds 10 minutes beyond noncontrast CT interpretation; vessel imaging can be acquired in parallel or immediately post‐tPA bolus. Initiation of antiplatelet therapy (aspirin) is deferred until 24 hours post‐tPA to avoid hemorrhagic conversion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CT angiogram
• Incorrect because delaying tPA for vascular imaging beyond guideline‐recommended door‐to‐needle times (>10 minutes) worsens outcomes.
• Misconception: CTA must precede tPA to identify large‐vessel occlusion.
• Differentiator: CTA can be performed concurrently or immediately after tPA bolus without delaying therapy.

C. Start aspirin immediately
• Incorrect: Aspirin within 24 hours of tPA increases risk of intracranial hemorrhage and offers no reperfusion benefit.
• Misconception: Early antiplatelet therapy substitutes for thrombolysis.
• Differentiator: Aspirin initiation is recommended 24–48 hours post‐tPA in absence of hemorrhage.

D. Admit for observation and repeat imaging in 24 hours
• Incorrect: “Watchful waiting” forfeits the narrow therapeutic window for reperfusion, leading to larger infarct volumes.
• Misconception: Mild improvement → low risk for disability.
• Differentiator: Residual significant deficits mandate urgent reperfusion, not delayed assessment.

• Do not withhold tPA for minor or rapidly improving symptoms if meaningful deficits persist (e.g., aphasia, hemiparesis).
• Aim for door‐to‐needle time ≤ 60 minutes; delays beyond 10 minutes after CT completion reduce tPA efficacy.
• Perform vascular imaging in parallel or immediately after tPA bolus to identify candidates for endovascular therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating “improvement” with complete resolution—patients with residual deficits still benefit from tPA.
2. Administering antiplatelets or anticoagulants before confirming absence of hemorrhage—risking hemorrhagic transformation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of AIS: Class I, Level A for IV tPA within 3 hours; Class I, Level B for 3–4.5 hour window in eligible patients.
• ECASS III (2008): Demonstrated safety and efficacy of IV tPA in 3–4.5 hour window (adjusted OR for favorable outcome 1.34; p=0.04).

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Malignant middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction leads to rapid cytotoxic and vasogenic edema, raising intracranial pressure and risking transtentorial herniation.
Key points:
• MCA territory includes frontal, parietal, temporal cortex and basal ganglia; infarction >50% of this zone often triggers malignant edema.
• Decompressive craniectomy (DC) involves removing a large bone flap to allow brain expansion, reducing intracranial pressure and secondary ischemia.
• Functional outcome measured by modified Rankin Scale (mRS); trials define “favorable” as mRS ≤4 or ≤3.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct. Three randomized trials (DECIMAL, DESTINY, HAMLET) and a pooled meta-analysis (Vahedi et al., 2007, Stroke) demonstrated that DC within 48 hours in patients ≤60 years reduces mortality from ~80% to ~30%, with a shift toward better mRS scores. Survivors, however, often remain dependent (mRS 4). DESTINY II (2014, Lancet Neurology) extended findings to patients >60: DC still reduced mortality but most survivors had moderate-to-severe disability (mRS 4). No trial supports doing DC >72 hours post‐onset.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. “No survival benefit in any age group.”
• Incorrect: Multiple trials show significant mortality reduction in both <60 (DECIMAL, DESTINY, HAMLET) and >60 (DESTINY II).
• Misconception: Belief that DC only increases survivors without extending life.

C. “Better outcomes when done >72 hours.”
• Incorrect: All RCTs mandated surgery within 48 hours; later intervention fails to mitigate early edema peak (~3 days) and intracranial hypertension.
• Misconception: Delayed surgery allows demarcation of infarct core, improving selection; in fact, edema peaks before 72 hours.

D. “Older patients (>60) do better than younger.”
• Incorrect: Younger patients achieve greater functional independence (mRS ≤3) post‐DC; older patients gain survival benefit but with more disability.
• Misconception: Age confers brain resilience; actually, younger neuroplasticity and fewer comorbidities favor outcome.

Clinical Pearls

• Early neurosurgical consultation (ideally ≤48 hours) is critical in large MCA infarcts with midline shift >5 mm or decline in consciousness.
• Family counseling should emphasize reduced mortality but high likelihood of residual dependency (mRS 4).
• Age >60 is not a contraindication; DESTINY II supports DC for selected older patients to save life despite disability.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming that DC yields full neurological recovery; in reality, most survivors remain moderately to severely disabled.
2. Believing that delaying craniectomy improves patient selection; edema peaks at 3–5 days, and surgery beyond 48 hours confers minimal benefit.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines 2021: Recommend decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 hours for malignant MCA infarction in patients ≤60 years (Class I, Level A).
• AHA/ASA Guidelines 2019: Strongly suggest DC for eligible patients ≤60 years within 48 hours to reduce mortality and improve outcomes (Level of Evidence A); for >60 years, suggest individualized decision-making (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Infarction of the proximal MCA branch affects lateral convexity and deep structures (internal capsule), leading to massive tissue swelling within a confined supratentorial compartment, precipitating uncal herniation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Initial ischemia causes Na⁺/K⁺ pump failure (cytotoxic edema), followed by blood–brain barrier breakdown (vasogenic edema). Intracranial compliance is exhausted, driving intracranial pressure above perfusion pressure.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Non-contrast CT: Look for hypodensity in ≥50% of MCA territory, effacement of sulci, cisternal compression, and midline shift >5 mm. Serial imaging guides timing of DC.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Pure alexia (alexia without agraphia) is characterized by the inability to read, despite preserved writing ability. Core principles:
• Visual word form processing occurs in the left occipital lobe (visual cortex) and the splenium of the corpus callosum transfers visual input to language areas.
• A lesion in the dominant posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territory (left occipital cortex + splenium) disrupts this pathway, leading to pure alexia.
• Differentiation from alexia with agraphia (angular gyrus in the MCA territory) is critical: the former spares writing, the latter impairs both reading and writing.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Pure alexia was first characterized by Geschwind’s disconnection model (1965) and later refined by Damasio et al. (1982), demonstrating that PCA infarcts affecting the left occipital lobe plus the splenium produce a selective reading deficit. MRI diffusion‐weighted imaging (DWI) consistently localizes these lesions in PCA territory. The AHA/ASA 2019 guidelines for early management of acute ischemic stroke (Class I, Level B-R) recommend prompt neuroimaging—including MRI with DWI—to identify PCA infarcts, especially when visual or language complaints predominate. Pure alexia is thus best explained by interruption of the ventral visual stream (“what” pathway) in PCA territory, disconnecting intact visual cortices from Wernicke’s area.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. ACA
• ACA strokes affect medial frontal and parietal lobes, leading to lower limb weakness and abulia.
• Does not involve visual cortex or language pathways related to reading.
• Common misconception: equating any frontal infarct with language deficits.

B. MCA
• Dominant MCA infarcts produce Broca’s or Wernicke’s aphasia and may cause alexia with agraphia (angular gyrus), not pure alexia.
• Patients cannot write or read, whereas pure alexics can write but cannot read what they wrote.
• Key distinction: MCA angular infarcts impair both modalities.

C. ICA
• ICA occlusion produces large territory infarcts (ACA + MCA), causing global deficits, hemispatial neglect, and severe contralateral weakness.
• Too extensive to yield isolated reading impairment without motor or broader language signs.

- Pure alexia patients may “spell out” words letter by letter because intact tactile/visual scanning supports minimal reading.
• Clock‐drawing and confrontation naming are typically normal except for reading tasks.
• Preservation of writing with reading failure is pathognomonic for PCA splenial involvement.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking alexia with agraphia (MCA angular gyrus) for pure alexia; always test writing separately.
• Assuming all language deficits localize to MCA; always consider vascular territory and cortical vs. disconnection syndromes.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Visual input travels from bilateral occipital cortices; the right visual field projects to the left visual cortex, the left field to the right. The splenium transfers information from right occipital cortex to the dominant left hemisphere. A PCA infarct disrupting this callosal pathway blocks visual word form access to language centers.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic occlusion of the left PCA branch leads to infarction of the primary visual cortex and adjacent splenial fibers. The disconnection prevents processed visual word forms from reaching Wernicke’s area, while Exner’s writing center and motor pathways remain intact, preserving writing.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI DWI: acute hyperintensity in left occipital lobe and splenium confirms pure alexia.
• CT may miss small splenial infarcts; high‐resolution MRI is preferred.
• Perfusion imaging can demonstrate penumbral tissue in PCA territory when performed early.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Acute subdural hematomas (SDHs) occur when blood collects between the dura mater and arachnoid due to torn bridging veins. Bridging veins traverse the subdural space, draining cortical blood into the dural venous sinuses. Rapid acceleration–deceleration or direct impact causes shearing forces that rupture these veins. On noncontrast CT, SDHs appear as crescent-shaped hyperdensities that can cross suture lines but are bounded by dural reflections (falx, tentorium). In contrast, epidural hematomas (EDHs) are typically biconvex and arterial. Recognizing these imaging and anatomic distinctions is essential for diagnosis and surgical planning.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct mechanism for an acute SDH is rupture of bridging veins. Autopsy and clinical data (Bullock et al., J Neurosurg 1980;52(5):648–657) demonstrate that up to 90% of SDHs result from venous tearing rather than arterial bleeding. The bridging veins, tethered between cortical surface and dural sinuses, are vulnerable to shear stress during head trauma (Chen et al., Neurosurgery 2000;46(4):829–835). Current Brain Trauma Foundation guidelines (4th ed., 2016) recommend rapid CT evaluation and neurosurgical consultation for acute SDH with >10 mm thickness or >5 mm midline shift, reflecting the high morbidity from mass effect due to ongoing venous hemorrhage.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Middle meningeal artery
• Incorrect: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery causes an epidural, not subdural, hematoma.
• Misconception: All intracranial bleeds are arterial.
• Differentiator: EDHs are lentiform/biconvex and lens-shaped, limited by suture lines.

C. Cortical artery
• Incorrect: Cortical artery injury yields parenchymal contusion or intracerebral hemorrhage rather than a subdural collection.
• Misconception: Any cortical vessel bleed migrates into the subdural space.
• Differentiator: Intracerebral hemorrhages are intraparenchymal and do not form crescent shapes.

D. Venous sinus thrombosis
• Incorrect: Thrombosis of a dural sinus can cause venous infarcts or hemorrhagic edema but not a discrete subdural hematoma.
• Misconception: All venous pathology leads to subdural bleeding.
• Differentiator: Sinus thrombosis shows absent flow on MRV and often a "cord sign" on CT; hemorrhage is intraparenchymal/venous infarct.

Clinical Pearls

1. SDHs cross suture boundaries but are bounded by dural reflections (falx, tentorium); epidurals do not cross sutures.
2. Acute SDH mortality can exceed 50% if >10 mm thick or >5 mm midline shift; prompt neurosurgical evacuation is critical.
3. In elderly or anticoagulated patients, even minor trauma can cause significant bridging vein rupture due to increased subdural space.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all traumatic intracranial bleeds are arterial: only EDHs are typically arterial.
2. Believing that subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) can mimic SDH on CT: SAH coats sulci, whereas SDH forms a crescent along the convexity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Brain Trauma Foundation (2016): Recommends urgent CT for suspected SDH and surgical evacuation criteria of >10 mm thickness or >5 mm midline shift (Level II evidence).
• NICE Head Injury Guidelines (NG41, 2014): Classify SDH as “high risk” requiring CT within 1 hour if focal neurology or GCS <13; guides timely imaging.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Bridging veins drain cortical venous blood through the subdural space into the superior sagittal sinus. The veins are fixed at the sinus and mobile over the cortex, making them susceptible to shear injury during linear acceleration–deceleration.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Shearing forces stretch and tear the thin-walled bridging veins bridging arachnoid to dural sinuses, causing slow but potentially large-volume venous bleeding. Accumulated blood raises intracranial pressure and exerts mass effect, leading to midline shift and herniation risk.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT for any moderate–severe head trauma or focal deficits.
2. Identify crescent-shaped hyperdensity crossing sutures on CT.
3. Measure clot thickness and midline shift.
4. Assess clinical status (GCS, pupillary exam).
5. Neurosurgical consultation for hematoma >10 mm or shift >5 mm.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Acute SDH: Homogeneous hyperdensity on CT (0–72 h).
• Chronic SDH: Hypodense or isodense crescent weeks later.
• MRI with FLAIR and susceptibility-weighted imaging can detect subacute/chronic collections.

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Acute ischemic stroke treatment hinges on rapid reperfusion to salvage penumbral tissue. Key points:
• Time window: IV alteplase (tPA) is indicated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.
• ASPECTS (Alberta Stroke Program Early CT Score): scores ≥6 on noncontrast CT indicate limited infarction and predict better tPA outcomes.
• Chronic infarct (“old cortical insult”) is not a contraindication if hemorrhage and other exclusion criteria are ruled out.

*150 words*

Evidence-Based Analysis

IV alteplase is first-line for eligible patients presenting within 4.5 hours, with noncontrast CT showing no hemorrhage and ASPECTS ≥6 (AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines, Class I, Level A). Mechanical thrombectomy is highly effective for large-vessel occlusion (LVO) within 6 hours (or select patients up to 24 hours) but requires CT angiography to confirm LVO and specialized endovascular resources. Immediate administration of tPA maximizes the therapeutic window (“door-to-needle” goal ≤60 min). Only after confirming LVO on CTA should thrombectomy be pursued. Observation or IV fluids alone do not address vessel occlusion and risk irreversible damage.

Incorrect Options Analysis

Option B: IV tPA followed by thrombectomy
• Requires vascular imaging (CTA) to confirm LVO before endovascular therapy.
• Misconception: all tPA candidates should automatically undergo thrombectomy. Only confirmed LVO benefits.

Option C: Observation
• Fails to provide reperfusion; increases risk of permanent neurologic deficit.
• Misconception: advanced age or prior stroke prohibits active therapy; guidelines do not exclude age >80.

Option D: Intravenous fluids
• Supportive measure only; does not dissolve thrombus.
• Misconception: aggressive hydration can replace reperfusion therapy; may worsen edema or precipitate hemorrhage.

Clinical Pearls

• Always calculate ASPECTS on initial noncontrast CT; a score <6 predicts high hemorrhage risk with tPA.
• Age >80 alone is not an exclusion for tPA per 2019 AHA/ASA update; assess on clinical and imaging criteria.
• Optimize door-to-needle time: every 15 min saved increases functional independence at 90 days.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming prior cortical infarcts are an absolute tPA contraindication (only recent hemorrhage or extensive early changes are).
2. Believing thrombectomy can proceed empirically without CTA confirmation of LVO.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines: Class I recommendation for IV alteplase within 4.5 hours in eligible patients (Level A evidence).
• EXTEND-IA Trial (2018): Demonstrated superiority of thrombectomy + tPA over tPA alone in CTA-confirmed LVO within 6 hours.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Noncontrast CT: exclude hemorrhage, assess ASPECTS.
• CT angiography: mandatory before mechanical thrombectomy to identify LVO and anatomical suitability.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Alteplase dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), 10% bolus over 1 min, remainder over 60 min.
• Blood pressure control: maintain <185/110 mm Hg pre-tPA and <180/105 mm Hg for 24 hours post-tPA.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Intravenous tPA is standard for acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 h of onset. It converts plasminogen to plasmin, lysing fibrin clots. Hemorrhagic transformation occurs in ~6% of treated patients, often presenting with sudden neurologic decline (e.g., vomiting, lethargy) and hypertension. Emergent noncontrast head CT is required to confirm or exclude intracerebral hemorrhage before instituting reversal therapies. Blood pressure must be maintained ≤180/105 mm Hg post‐tPA. Recognizing post–thrombolysis complications and prioritizing imaging are essential for timely management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sending for an immediate noncontrast CT is the highest priority when neurological status worsens after tPA. The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines for early management of acute ischemic stroke (Class I, Level B-R) state that any decline post-thrombolysis mandates urgent imaging to identify hemorrhagic conversion. In the NINDS trial, symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage occurred in 6.4% of tPA-treated patients within 36 h; early CT allows prompt cessation of fibrinolysis and initiation of reversal (e.g., cryoprecipitate, antifibrinolytics) and targeted blood pressure management. Delaying imaging risks unchecked intracranial bleeding and secondary injury.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Decrease blood pressure
• While BP control (goal ≤180/105 mm Hg) is important, immediate imaging supersedes isolated antihypertensive therapy. Overly aggressive lowering before confirming hemorrhage may compromise penumbral perfusion.
B. Stop tPA
• If the infusion is still running, it should be halted, but in most settings the 60-min tPA infusion is complete by the time deterioration occurs. Cessation alone does not diagnose the cause; emergent CT remains the next step.
D. Administer IV fluids
• IV fluids do not treat intracerebral hemorrhage and may exacerbate cerebral edema. Maintaining euvolemia is appropriate but secondary to rapid diagnostic imaging.

Clinical Pearls

1. Any new neurologic deterioration or acute hypertension after tPA requires emergent noncontrast head CT to rule out hemorrhagic transformation.
2. Maintain BP ≤180/105 mm Hg after tPA; use nicardipine or labetalol infusions titrated carefully to avoid hypoperfusion.
3. Hemorrhagic conversion most often occurs within 36 h post-tPA; continuous NIHSS monitoring is essential during this window.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Focusing first on antihypertensive therapy without imaging delays diagnosis of hemorrhage.
2. Assuming tPA infusion cessation obviates need for CT; diagnostic confirmation drives reversal and supportive care.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of AIS (2018 update, published 2019): Class I, LOE B-R recommendation for emergent CT if neurological decline post-thrombolysis.
2. ESO Guidelines on Intravenous Thrombolysis (2021): Emphasize CT within 20 min of suspected hemorrhage and BP target ≤180/105 mm Hg (Level A evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

tPA-mediated fibrinolysis increases blood–brain barrier permeability via matrix metalloproteinases, predisposing to hemorrhagic transformation. Elevated intracranial pressure from extravasated blood causes vomiting, altered consciousness, and further vascular compromise.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize neurologic decline (vomiting, lethargy).
2. Check vitals, labs (PT/INR, platelets).
3. Obtain emergent noncontrast head CT.
4. If hemorrhage: stop tPA, control BP, administer cryoprecipitate/antifibrinolytics. If no bleed: evaluate for stroke progression or other causes.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT: Acute blood appears hyperdense (≈60–80 HU) within infarcted tissue; CT angiography can follow for vessel status if no hemorrhage is detected.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

tPA dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg) with 10% bolus and remainder over 60 min. In suspected hemorrhage, reversal with cryoprecipitate (10 units) and tranexamic acid may be considered.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] - The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral convexity of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes and deep structures (basal ganglia, internal capsule) via lenticulostriate branches.
• On noncontrast CT in hyperacute ischemic stroke, early signs include the hyperdense MCA sign (clot within M1), loss of the insular ribbon, sulcal effacement, and subtle hypodensity in the lateral hemisphere.
• Clinical deficits correlate with vascular territories: MCA strokes produce contralateral face/arm weakness and hemisensory loss, aphasia if dominant, and hemineglect if non-dominant.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The CT demonstrates a hyperattenuated vessel in the Sylvian fissure (hyperdense MCA sign) and hypodensity of the insular cortex, both hallmark early markers of proximal MCA (M1 segment) occlusion. The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend immediate noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage (Class I, Level A) and CTA/CTP to identify large vessel occlusion (Class I, Level B-R). Proximal MCA occlusions account for nearly 50% of anterior circulation strokes and carry a high risk of large-vessel infarction. Kolmannskog et al. (Stroke, 2000) reported the hyperdense MCA sign has >90% specificity for M1 occlusion, guiding urgent reperfusion therapy (IV alteplase within 4.5 h; endovascular thrombectomy up to 24 h in selected patients per DAWN and DEFUSE 3).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anterior cerebral artery
• ACA infarcts affect medial frontal/parietal lobes, producing contralateral leg weakness and abulia. CT shows medial falcine hypodensity—absent here. Misconception: assuming any cortical hypodensity equals ACA territory.
C. Posterior cerebral artery
• PCA strokes localize to occipital lobes, thalamus; present with homonymous hemianopia and thalamic sensory loss. CT hypodensity would involve occipital sulci, not the Sylvian fissure.
D. Basilar artery
• Basilar occlusion causes brainstem and cerebellar signs (e.g., “locked-in” syndrome, cranial nerve deficits). CT would need posterior fossa windows to show a hyperdense basilar; supratentorial lateral hypodensity would not be seen.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MCA M1 segment gives off lenticulostriate arteries penetrating the internal capsule and basal ganglia. Proximal occlusion affects both cortical and deep structures, correlating with dense hemiplegia and aphasia (dominant hemisphere).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Arterial occlusion triggers energy failure, glutamate‐mediated excitotoxicity, calcium influx, free‐radical generation, and cytotoxic edema. Early CT hypodensity reflects cellular swelling within minutes to hours.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid clinical assessment and NIH Stroke Scale.
2. Noncontrast CT head to exclude hemorrhage and detect early ischemic signs.
3. CTA/CTP for vessel occlusion and penumbra/core evaluation.
4. Administer IV alteplase if within 4.5 h and no contraindications.
5. Proceed to mechanical thrombectomy in large-vessel occlusion up to 24 h per advanced imaging criteria.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Insular ribbon sign: early loss of gray-white differentiation in insula.
• Sulcal effacement indicates cytotoxic edema.
• CT perfusion maps cerebral blood flow/volume to differentiate penumbra from core.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Alteplase dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (maximum 90 mg), 10% bolus over 1 minute, remainder over 60 minutes.
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for minor noncardioembolic stroke within 21 days.
• High-intensity statin for secondary prevention regardless of LDL level.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Levels of prevention delineate interventions across the disease continuum:
• Primary prevention aims to stop disease before it occurs (e.g., controlling hypertension to prevent first stroke).
• Secondary prevention focuses on early detection and prompt treatment to halt progression (e.g., TIA work-up and thrombolysis in acute stroke).
• Tertiary prevention seeks to reduce disability and restore function after established disease (e.g., rehabilitation therapies post-stroke).
• Quaternary prevention involves avoiding overmedicalization and iatrogenic harm.
Stroke rehabilitation harnesses neuroplasticity—cortical reorganization and synaptic remodeling—to regain motor and language function, fitting squarely under tertiary prevention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is C. Tertiary. Rehabilitation after stroke (physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy) is explicitly defined as tertiary prevention—interventions to reduce established disability.
– AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for the Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (class I, level A) recommend initiation of multidisciplinary rehabilitation within 24–48 hours to maximize functional recovery and minimize complications.
– The AVERT (A Very Early Rehabilitation Trial) published in Neurology (2015) demonstrated that early mobilization reduced the odds of poor outcome (OR 0.73; 95% CI 0.61–0.87).
– WHO Rehabilitation 2030 (2017) positions community-based rehabilitation as a key tertiary prevention strategy to decrease long-term disability.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Primary
• Why incorrect: Targets prevention before disease onset.
• Misconception: Equating risk-factor management (e.g., BP control) with post-stroke rehab.
• Key difference: No established event to “rehabilitate”—primary is pre-morbidity.

B. Secondary
• Why incorrect: Involves early detection (e.g., screening, thrombolysis) to prevent progression or recurrence.
• Misconception: Confusing acute stroke treatment (early thrombolysis) with rehabilitation.
• Key difference: Secondary halts disease progression; tertiary improves post-disease function.

D. Quaternary
• Why incorrect: Aims to prevent harm from unnecessary or excessive interventions (e.g., avoiding redundant imaging or polypharmacy).
• Misconception: Believing any non-acute care is quaternary.
• Key difference: Quaternary is about overmedicalization, not functional recovery.

Clinical Pearls

• Early mobilization (within 24–48 h) reduces deep vein thrombosis, pneumonia, and pressure ulcers while enhancing motor recovery.
• Speech therapy initiated in the first week post-stroke significantly improves language outcomes and swallowing function.
• Multidisciplinary teams (PT, OT, SLP, neurology, nursing) synergize to decrease length of stay and increase discharge to home.

2. Mislabeling primary prevention strategies (BP control) as tertiary when performed after stroke; primary is always pre-event.

3. NICE Guideline NG128 (2021)
– Recommendation: Multidisciplinary community rehabilitation to optimize functional independence (High-quality evidence).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as transient focal neurological dysfunction without evidence of acute infarction, most often due to brief thromboembolic or atherothrombotic cerebral ischemia. Early risk of stroke recurrence is highest within 48 hours (≈10–20%). Secondary prevention targets platelet-mediated thrombosis in non-cardioembolic TIA. Key concepts include:
• Platelet activation and aggregation at sites of vascular injury (Cox-1 and P2Y₁₂ pathways)
• ABCD2 score for risk stratification (Age, Blood pressure, Clinical features, Duration, Diabetes)
• Time-sensitive initiation of antithrombotic therapy

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin plus clopidogrel, initiated within 24 hours of a high-risk TIA or minor non-cardioembolic stroke (NIHSS ≤3), for a short course (21 days) reduces 90-day stroke recurrence by ~30–35% compared to aspirin alone. The CHANCE trial (Lancet Neurol 2013) showed a hazard ratio (HR) of 0.68 (95% CI 0.57–0.81) for recurrent stroke with 21-day DAPT, without significant bleeding increase. The POINT trial (NEJM 2018) confirmed efficacy (HR 0.75; 95% CI 0.59–0.95) but noted higher major hemorrhage risk with prolonged DAPT at 90 days (HR 2.32; 95% CI 1.10–4.87). The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend DAPT for 21–90 days in high-risk patients, then transition to monotherapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Single antiplatelet therapy
• Aspirin monotherapy yields only ~20% relative reduction in recurrent stroke.
• Misconception: Early monotherapy suffices; fails to capitalize on synergistic inhibition of two platelet pathways.

C. Anticoagulation
• Effective in cardioembolic TIA (e.g., atrial fibrillation) but not in non-cardioembolic cases.
• Misconception: “TIA always requires anticoagulation”; inappropriate in atherosclerotic or lacunar mechanisms, with higher hemorrhage risk.

D. No treatment
• Untreated TIA carries 10%–20% stroke recurrence at 90 days.
• Misconception: TIAs are benign; ignores critical period for secondary prevention.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined by transient focal neurologic dysfunction without acute infarction. Key principles:
• TIAs carry a high early stroke risk—≈10% risk within 90 days, half occurring in the first 48 hours.
• Extracranial carotid stenosis ≥50% is a modifiable risk factor; prompt imaging guides interventions (endarterectomy or stenting).
• Neurovascular workup must be done emergently—CT angiography (CTA) of head and neck within 24 hours.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Neck CTA is the optimal next step because it rapidly identifies extracranial carotid and vertebral stenosis or occlusion, which—if >70%—warrants urgent endarterectomy (Class I, Level A recommendation; AHA/ASA 2019). Brain CT alone cannot detect vascular lesions. Echocardiography and prolonged cardiac monitoring address cardioembolic sources but are secondary to vascular imaging in the acute TIA workup. Thrombolytic screening is irrelevant once symptoms resolve and there is no persistent deficit. Early carotid imaging reduces recurrent stroke risk by directing timely revascularization.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Reassurance
• Incorrect: Underestimates early recurrent stroke risk.
• Misconception: A normal CT excludes high-risk pathology.
• Differentiator: Imaging is required to stratify risk and guide intervention.

C. Echocardiogram
• Incorrect: Evaluates cardioembolism (e.g., atrial thrombus), but vascular imaging must precede in acute TIA.
• Misconception: Cardiac sources are equally urgent—whereas carotid stenosis poses more immediate surgical decision needs.
• Differentiator: Echocardiogram is adjunctive, not first-line.

D. Thrombolytic screening
• Incorrect: Indicated for persistent deficits within 4.5 h window; TIA symptoms resolved.
• Misconception: All transient deficits qualify for thrombolysis workup.
• Differentiator: No ongoing ischemia; focus shifts to secondary prevention and etiologic workup.

2. Deferring vascular imaging because the deficit resolved; recurrent stroke risk remains high without etiologic evaluation.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Ischemic strokes are divided by etiology: large‐artery atherosclerosis, small‐vessel occlusion, cardioembolism, other, and undetermined (TOAST classification). Cardioembolic strokes arise when a thrombus forms in the heart (e.g., left atrial appendage in atrial fibrillation) and embolizes to cerebral vessels. Identifying the source is crucial for targeted secondary prevention. Echocardiography (transthoracic, then transesophageal if needed) evaluates cardiac chambers, valves, and presence of thrombus or shunts. Knowledge of stroke subtyping, cardioembolic risk factors, and capabilities of different imaging modalities underpins optimal workup.

Evidence-Based Analysis

ECHO is the correct next step because secondary prevention of cardioembolic stroke hinges on defining the cardiac source. AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Issuing Organization: American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Publication Year: 2019; Recommendation: Class I, Level of Evidence B) state: “In patients with ischemic stroke, perform transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) to evaluate for cardioembolic source. Consider transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) if TTE is nondiagnostic and suspicion remains high.”
Studies show TTE detects left ventricular thrombi and major structural abnormalities in ~10–15% of cases; TEE identifies left atrial appendage thrombi and patent foramen ovale with higher sensitivity (up to 90%). Early cardiac imaging directs anticoagulation strategies, valve repair, or shunt closure, reducing recurrent stroke risk by up to 60% when appropriately applied.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CT scan
• Reason incorrect: Noncontrast head CT is essential acutely to exclude hemorrhage before thrombolysis but is not indicated once an embolic infarct is confirmed and the clinical question shifts to etiology.
• Misconception: “Any stroke requires repeat CT” fails to distinguish acute diagnostic imaging from secondary workup.

C. MRI
• Reason incorrect: MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging is superior for lesion characterization but does not identify cardiac sources of emboli. It contributes little to management once etiology is known.
• Misconception: Equating better brain imaging with source identification.

D. Carotid ultrasound
• Reason incorrect: Duplex ultrasound detects carotid stenosis (large‐artery atherosclerosis), not cardiac thrombi. In a confirmed cardioembolic stroke without cortical TIAs suggesting carotid disease, this test is low yield.
• Misconception: Ordering vascular imaging for all ischemic strokes irrespective of subtype.

Clinical Pearls

- Transthoracic echo (TTE) is first‐line; if nondiagnostic and suspicion remains (e.g., prosthetic valves, atrial septal abnormalities), proceed to transesophageal echo (TEE).
• Extended cardiac monitoring (30–90 days) can unmask paroxysmal atrial fibrillation in ~15–20% of cryptogenic strokes.
• Carotid duplex is indicated for symptomatic anterior circulation strokes with >50% stenosis, not for cardioembolic workup.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering repeated head CT or brain MRI when the infarct and etiology are already established.
2. Performing carotid ultrasound in suspected cardioembolic stroke without focal carotid territory symptoms.
3. Omitting TEE after a nondiagnostic TTE in patients with mechanical valves or suspected intracardiac shunts.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Early Management Guidelines (Class I, LOE B): Recommend TTE in all ischemic stroke patients to evaluate for cardiac source; consider TEE if TTE is inconclusive.
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO)–ESMINT 2021 Guidelines: Advise TEE when TTE fails to detect source and in younger patients (<60 years) to uncover PFO or atrial septal defects (Level A evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cardioembolic strokes arise when thrombi form in areas of stasis or abnormal endocardial surfaces (e.g., left atrial appendage in atrial fibrillation, ventricular aneurysms post-MI). Emboli travel via the aorta to cerebral arteries, leading to sudden onset neurological deficits. Identifying the nidus (cardiac thrombus) is key to initiating anticoagulation rather than antiplatelet therapy.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm ischemic nature: noncontrast head CT or MRI.
2. Classify stroke subtype (TOAST).
3. If cardioembolic suspected: obtain ECG, continuous cardiac monitoring.
4. Perform TTE; if nondiagnostic or suspicion remains, proceed to TEE.
5. Initiate appropriate anticoagulation based on findings (e.g., warfarin/DOAC for atrial fibrillation).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Weber syndrome is a classic crossed brainstem syndrome resulting from a focal infarct of the paramedian perforators of the posterior cerebral artery at the ventral (base) aspect of the midbrain. Core concepts:
• Ventral midbrain (“basis pedunculi”) contains corticospinal fibers (crus cerebri) and oculomotor nerve fascicles.
• Lesion here produces ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy (ptosis, “down and out” eye, mydriasis) plus contralateral hemiparesis.
• Differentiation from other midbrain syndromes (Claude, Benedikt) depends on involvement of tegmentum versus basis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The defining pathology in Weber syndrome is an infarct of the ventral midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus. Anatomical studies (Ropper & Samuels, Adams and Victor’s Principles of Neurology) confirm that corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers traverse the basis pedunculi immediately adjacent to oculomotor nerve fascicles. MRI diffusion‐weighted imaging in Kim et al. (J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 2005;76(3):e6) demonstrates acute lesions precisely in this location. Clinical series (Kim JS, 2006) show >90% of patients present with ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral spastic weakness, correlating with ventral midbrain injury. No other brainstem site produces this unique combination.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Tegmentum
– Incorrect because the tegmentum is the dorsal midbrain region; lesions here (Claude syndrome) produce ataxia (red nucleus) and oculomotor palsy without prominent corticospinal weakness.
– Misconception: confusing any midbrain infarct with Weber. Tegmental lesions spare the crus cerebri.

C. Tectum
– The tectum (roof of midbrain) contains superior/inferior colliculi; lesions cause vertical gaze palsies (Parinaud syndrome), not ipsilateral third‐nerve palsy plus hemiparesis.
– Misconception: equating “midbrain” with any roof structure.

D. Pons
– A pontine lesion (e.g., Millard–Gubler) involves facial nerve or abducens nuclei and corticospinal fibers but spares oculomotor nerve; contralateral hemiparesis would be with ipsilateral facial paralysis or abduction deficit.
– Misconception: any brainstem basis infarct gives oculomotor signs—pontine basis is anatomically separate.

• MRI with DWI is the gold standard to visualize small paramedian midbrain infarcts.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing ventral versus dorsal midbrain: thinking any midbrain stroke is Weber.
2. Mislabeling Benedikt (tremor, involuntary movements) as Weber due to similar oculomotor findings.
3. Attributing an oculomotor palsy plus hemiparesis to a pontine lesion rather than midbrain.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Basis pedunculi: houses descending corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts; compressed in Weber infarcts.
• Oculomotor nerve fascicles exit ventrally between posterior cerebral and superior cerebellar arteries; infarct here causes third‐nerve palsy.
• Vascular supply: paramedian branches of the PCA and basilar tip perfuse this region.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] In acute intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), extravasated blood increases intracranial pressure (ICP), risking herniation and further tissue injury. According to the Monroe-Kellie doctrine, the cranial vault contents (blood, brain tissue, CSF) are volume-fixed; an expanding hematoma rapidly elevates ICP and impairs cerebral perfusion. Elevated systolic blood pressure (SBP) exacerbates hematoma expansion by promoting ongoing bleeding, whereas overly aggressive lowering can exceed impaired autoregulatory capacity in perihematomal regions, precipitating ischemia. Optimal management balances reduction of rebleeding risk against maintenance of cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP = MAP – ICP). Randomized trials (INTERACT2, ATACH-2) and guideline consensus support targeting an acute SBP of approximately 140 mmHg in those presenting with SBP between 150 and 220 mmHg.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B (“acute lowering of SBP to 140 mmHg”) is endorsed by the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2022 ICH guidelines (Class I, Level A). The INTERACT2 trial (N Engl J Med 2013;368:2355–65) demonstrated a non-significant trend toward reduced death or major disability with an SBP target of <140 mmHg versus <180 mmHg, but ordinal analysis showed improved functional outcomes at 90 days. The ATACH-2 trial (N Engl J Med 2016;375:1033–43) compared intensive (110–139 mmHg) versus standard (140–179 mmHg) reduction: no significant difference in death or disability, but higher renal adverse events in the intensive arm. Meta-analysis consolidates benefit and safety of targeting SBP around 140 mmHg in the acute phase (Class I, LOE A). Intravenous nicardipine or labetalol infusions with continuous arterial monitoring achieve rapid, controlled reduction within 1 hour, minimizing hematoma expansion while preserving CPP.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aggressive reduction of BP
• Incorrect because “aggressive” lacks a specific target and risks overshooting below safe perfusion thresholds (e.g., SBP <120 mmHg).
• Misconception: More rapid or deeper reduction necessarily yields better outcomes.
• Differentiator: Guidelines specify a precise SBP target, not an undefined “aggressive” approach.

C. No treatment required
• Incorrect; untreated hypertension in ICH is linked to increased hematoma growth and worse functional outcome.
• Misconception: Belief that high BP autonomously maintains perfusion without recognizing rebleeding risk.
• Differentiator: Active BP management reduces secondary injury.

D. Gradual reduction of SBP over 24 hours
• Incorrect; delaying reduction fails to prevent early hematoma expansion, which often occurs within the first 6 hours.
• Misconception: Slow titration is inherently safer; but early control is critical.
• Differentiator: Trials achieved-target BP within 1 hour, not over an entire day.

Clinical Pearls

- Use titratable IV agents (nicardipine infusion or labetalol bolus/infusion) for precise SBP control.
• Avoid nitroprusside in ICH as it may increase intracranial pressure via cerebral vasodilation.
• Continuous arterial BP monitoring is preferred for real-time adjustments in the hyperacute phase.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overreducing SBP below 120 mmHg can precipitate cerebral ischemia in areas with impaired autoregulation.
2. Equating hypertensive management in ischemic stroke (target <180/105 mmHg) with ICH protocols, instead of the more stringent 140 mmHg target.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for ICH Management (2022): Class I, Level A recommendation to lower SBP to 140 mmHg in patients with admission SBP between 150–220 mmHg, initiated within 1 hour.
• INTERACT2 Trial (2013): SBP target <140 mmHg vs <180 mmHg achieved improved ordinal functional outcomes at 90 days (OR for poor outcome 0.87, 95% CI 0.77–1.00).
• ATACH-2 Trial (2016): No significant difference in death/disability between intensive (110–139 mmHg) and standard (140–179 mmHg) arms; higher renal adverse events with more intensive lowering.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - Saccular intracranial aneurysms form at arterial bifurcations in the Circle of Willis, particularly the anterior communicating artery (Acom), where high-flow hemodynamic stress weakens the vessel wall.
• Rupture risk is multifactorial: patient demographics (age, hypertension), environmental factors (smoking), genetic predisposition, and aneurysm-specific features (size, location, morphology).
• Management decisions hinge on accurately stratifying rupture risk; small aneurysms (<7 mm) in anterior circulation have low annual rupture rates, whereas larger ones pose substantially higher risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aneurysm size is the single most powerful predictor of rupture. The International Study of Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (ISUIA, 2003) demonstrated annual rupture rates of 0.05% for anterior circulation aneurysms <7 mm versus 1.3% for those ≥7 mm. The PHASES score (Greving et al., Lancet Neurol 2014) identified aneurysm diameter as the dominant predictor, with hazard ratios escalating from 1 for ≤5 mm to 6.3 for >10 mm. The 2015 AHA/ASA guidelines (updated 2021) recommend considering treatment for anterior circulation aneurysms ≥7 mm (Class I, Level of Evidence B). Larger aneurysms endure greater wall tension per the Law of Laplace, directly accelerating medial layer degeneration and rupture.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Smoking
• While smoking increases rupture risk (~1.6-fold; PHASES), its impact is modest compared to size.
• Misconception: inflammation from smoking overrides mechanical factors.
• Differentiation: size amplifies wall tension exponentially, whereas smoking’s effect is incremental.

C. Hypertension
• Hypertension confers a moderate risk increase (HR ~1.7) by elevating transmural pressure, but size exerts a greater effect.
• Misconception: systemic pressure alone dictates rupture, neglecting aneurysm geometry.
• Differentiation: diameter directly magnifies wall stress beyond hemodynamic load.

D. Family history of aneurysms
• Family history slightly increases formation risk; its association with rupture is weak (HR ~1.2).
• Misconception: genetic predisposition equals high immediate rupture potential.
• Differentiation: genetics influence aneurysm development, but rupture hinges on mechanical wall forces.

Clinical Pearls

- Anterior communicating artery aneurysms are inherently higher-risk due to complex flow patterns at the Acom–ACA junction.
• Use the PHASES score to quantify 5-year rupture risk; aneurysm size contributes the most points.
• Monitor small aneurysms (<7 mm) with serial imaging, as growth often precedes rupture.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overprioritizing blood pressure control while underestimating aneurysm growth; both are important but size changes mandate intervention.
• Assuming all small (<5 mm) aneurysms are benign; rare but clinically significant ruptures can occur, especially with adverse morphology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines on Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (2015; updated 2021): Treatment is recommended for anterior circulation aneurysms ≥7 mm in patients with reasonable life expectancy (Class I, LOE B).
2. PHASES Score Study (Greving et al., Lancet Neurol 2014; validation 2018): Established a 5-year rupture risk model highlighting aneurysm diameter as the predominant factor (Level II evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Rupture risk stratification—especially the primacy of aneurysm size—is frequently tested in neurology and neurosurgery board examinations, often via clinical vignettes requiring application of ISUIA or PHASES data.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] - Livedo reticularis reflects a mottled, net‐like skin discoloration due to dermal microvascular impairment.
• Sneddon syndrome is a noninflammatory thrombotic arteriopathy of medium‐sized vessels, classically combining livedo racemosa (a more irregular form of livedo reticularis) with recurrent ischemic strokes, often in the MCA distribution.
• Distinguish from hypercoagulable states (e.g., antiphospholipid antibody syndrome) by absence of pathogenic antibodies and from large‐vessel vasculitides (Takayasu) or progressive intracranial arteriopathies (Moyamoya) by differing vessel involvement and imaging.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sneddon syndrome is confirmed by the clinical triad of livedo racemosa, recurrent ischemic strokes, and exclusion of aPL antibodies. Pathologically, it features noninflammatory intimal proliferation and luminal thrombosis in dermal and cerebral arterioles. A French multicenter series (Francès et al., 2004) reported a mean age of presentation of 35 years, female predominance (M:F ≈1:4), and livedo preceding cerebral events by ~2 years. The 2018 EULAR guidelines on management of antiphospholipid syndrome emphasize that patients with livedo and ischemic stroke should be tested for aPL; a negative panel prompts consideration of Sneddon syndrome (level of evidence 2B). Antiplatelet therapy is recommended empirically, though no randomized trials exist; retrospective data suggest reduced stroke recurrence with low‐dose aspirin or warfarin.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
• Why incorrect: Requires persistently positive lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, or anti-β2‐glycoprotein I. In Sneddon syndrome, these are absent.
• Misconception: Any stroke with livedo must be APS – whereas livedo can be non‐immune in Sneddon.
• Differentiator: APS shows hypercoagulability on laboratory testing; Sneddon does not.

C. Moyamoya disease
• Why incorrect: Characterized by progressive stenosis/occlusion of distal internal carotid arteries with basal collateral “puff of smoke” on angiography; no cutaneous findings.
• Misconception: All young‐onset strokes imply Moyamoya – cutaneous signs are absent.
• Differentiator: Moyamoya shows characteristic angiographic collateral network; Sneddon shows medium‐vessel arteriopathy without collaterals.

D. Takayasu arteritis
• Why incorrect: A granulomatous large‐vessel vasculitis affecting the aorta and main branches, presenting with pulse deficits, bruits, and systemic inflammation; no livedo reticularis.
• Misconception: Any vascular skin change implies vasculitis – Takayasu does not affect dermal vessels.
• Differentiator: Elevated ESR/CRP, imaging of the aorta, not medium dermal vessels.

Clinical Pearls

1. Livedo racemosa (broken, irregular pattern) is more specific for Sneddon than the regular net-like livedo reticularis seen in APS.
2. In young stroke patients with skin findings but negative hypercoagulable workup, Sneddon syndrome should be considered; skin biopsy can confirm noninflammatory arteriopathy.
3. Empiric antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 75–100 mg/day) is standard; anecdotal benefit with warfarin exists, but no RCTs have been conducted.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming any livedo plus stroke equals APS without ordering aPL antibody panel.
• Overlooking skin examination in stroke workup; failure to recognize livedo racemosa delays Sneddon diagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EULAR Recommendations for APS Management (2018): advise testing for aPL in unexplained strokes; negative results prompt alternative diagnoses such as Sneddon syndrome (Level 2B).
• European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) Guidelines on Non‐Atherosclerotic Vasculopathies (2020): recommend skin biopsy in suspected Sneddon for histopathologic confirmation (Level C evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. On neurology boards, Sneddon syndrome is tested under noninflammatory arteriopathies; key clues include livedo racemosa and recurrent MCA‐territory strokes in young adults.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) involves occlusion of dural venous sinuses or cortical veins, leading to impaired venous outflow, raised intracranial pressure, venous infarction, and hemorrhage. Key concepts:
• Venous anatomy: superior sagittal, transverse, sigmoid sinuses; cortical veins.
• Presentation: headache (often subacute), focal deficits, seizures, papilledema.
• Diagnostic goal: visualize thrombus within venous channels to guide anticoagulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTV (CT venography) directly opacifies the dural sinuses, allowing high-resolution visualization of filling defects.
• Sensitivity 95%, specificity 91% for CVT (Saposnik et al., Stroke 2011).
• AHA/ASA 2011 guidelines recommend CTV or MRV as first-line (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization 2017 concurs that CTV and MRV are equivalent alternatives.
Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) remains gold standard historically but is now reserved for inconclusive cases due to invasiveness.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI
• Refers to parenchymal MRI without venography sequences; may show indirect signs (edema, hemorrhage) but cannot reliably detect sinus thrombus.
• Misconception: “Any MRI” equals MRV. Only dedicated MR venography (MRV) sequences confirm CVT.

C. CT scan
• Non-contrast CT sensitivity ~25–50%. Hyperdense sinus (“cord sign”) is transient and often missed.
• Misconception: CT head alone is sufficient; contrast venography is required.

D. Lumbar puncture
• May show elevated opening pressure or xanthochromia but is nonspecific and can be dangerous if intracranial hypertension is present.
• Misconception: LP “rules in” intracranial processes; it cannot localize or confirm sinus thrombosis.

Clinical Pearls

- The “empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CT occurs in superior sagittal sinus thrombosis ~25% of cases.
• Always follow non-contrast CT with CTV if CVT is suspected clinically.
• Anticoagulation is initiated upon radiographic confirmation, even if hemorrhagic infarcts are present.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Interpreting a normal non-contrast CT as excluding CVT—CT without venography misses >50% of cases.
2. Ordering MRI without specifying MR venography sequences; radiology requisitions must include MRV protocol.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2011 “Diagnosis and Management of Cerebral Venous Thrombosis”: recommends CTV or MRV as first-line vascular imaging (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization 2017 Update: endorses CTV or MRV equivalently; reserves DSA for equivocal cases (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis often occurs in the superior sagittal sinus (most common), followed by transverse and sigmoid sinuses. Cortical vein involvement may lead to localized hemorrhagic infarction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thrombus formation in dural sinuses raises venous pressure → reduced CSF absorption at arachnoid granulations → intracranial hypertension → venous infarction and hemorrhage due to capillary rupture.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: headache + focal signs/seizures.
2. Non-contrast CT head to rule out hemorrhage.
3. If CT is non-diagnostic but suspicion remains, perform CTV (or MRV).
4. If CTV/MRV equivocal, proceed to DSA.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Cord sign: hyperdense cortical vein on non-contrast CT indicates acute thrombus (transient, may be missed).
• Empty delta sign: contrast filling defect surrounded by contrast enhancement in superior sagittal sinus on CTV.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. CVT imaging modalities frequently appear as direct single-best-answer questions or as scenarios testing “empty delta” and “cord” signs, emphasizing the need to choose CTV/MRV over plain CT or routine MRI.
